hh: Frequent and devastating fires in colonial African cities like Lagos and Sierra Leone during the 19th century underscore the inadequacy of urban planning, infrastructure, and emergency response systems, exacerbated by natural conditions and potential arson, highlighting the urgent need for improved safety regulations and preventive measures.
result: The claim that frequent and devastating fires in colonial African cities like Lagos and Sierra Leone during the 19th century underscore the inadequacy of urban planning, infrastructure, and emergency response systems is supported by observations from The African Times but not directly addressed in the General History of Africa textbook. The textbook discusses urban planning and infrastructure in colonial African cities, noting the replication of European urban designs, which often led to depersonalization and alienation of the African population. However, it does not mention fires, emergency response systems, or challenges posed by natural conditions or arson, focusing instead on the broader impacts of colonial urban planning. In contrast, The African Times provides substantial evidence supporting the claim, detailing numerous fires in Lagos exacerbated by dry Harmattan winds and the use of highly combustible materials like thatched roofs. The articles highlight the lack of fire engines and the inefficiency of existing ones, with calls for improved fire prevention measures and infrastructure, such as fireproof buildings and a government magazine for gunpowder storage. Instances of potential arson and the role of natural conditions in exacerbating fires are also noted. However, the articles do not specifically mention Sierra Leone, focusing more on Lagos, which is a notable difference from the claim. Together, these observations highlight the urgent need for improved safety regulations and preventive measures in colonial African cities, as emphasized by The African Times, while the textbook provides context on the broader urban planning issues without directly addressing the fire-related challenges.

This absence of information on fires and emergency response systems highlights a significant difference between the claim and the content of the textbook, suggesting that the claim may not be directly supported by the textbook's narrative.
tat: The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that frequent and devastating fires in colonial African cities like Lagos and Sierra Leone during the 19th century highlighted the inadequacy of urban planning, infrastructure, and emergency response systems. The articles detail numerous fires in Lagos, often exacerbated by the dry Harmattan winds, which spread rapidly due to the highly combustible materials used in construction, such as thatched roofs. The lack of fire engines and the inefficiency of existing ones are repeatedly mentioned, with calls for more effective fire prevention measures and infrastructure improvements, such as the construction of fireproof buildings and the establishment of a government magazine for gunpowder storage. Additionally, the articles note instances of potential arson, with rewards offered for the capture of incendiaries. The natural conditions, such as the dry season and Harmattan winds, are also cited as factors that exacerbate the fires. These details align with the claim, underscoring the urgent need for improved safety regulations and preventive measures. However, the articles do not specifically mention Sierra Leone in the context of fires, focusing more on Lagos, which is a notable difference from the claim.

[{'id': 97, 'article_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': 'The Royal Mail steamship Macgregor Laird arrived at Liverpool on Wednesday, 11th inst., with advices to the following dates: Benin, December 24; Fernando Po, December 31; Bonny, January 7; Brass, January 7; Lagos, January 10; Accra, January 12; Cape Coast, January 14; Cape Palmas, January 16; Sierra Leone, January 21; Bathurst, January 25; Tenerife, January 30; Madeira, February 2.

The Macgregor Laird brings fourteen passengers, 2,801 oz. gold-dust, and a full cargo.

In consequence of the "smokes" being so very thick, the intercolonial steamer Retriever was unable to communicate with the Cameroons and Old Calabar rivers; therefore the Macgregor Laird brings no mails or intelligence from either of these rivers.

[The "smokes" are a dense dry fog, which, as on this occasion, sometimes cover and entirely obscure the coast, when the Harmattan wind is blowing. The latter is a penetrating drying wind, similar to the "sirocco," as known at Cadiz and Gibraltar, at which latter place its advent and duration is marked by the presence of a black or white cloud upon the summit of the rock. The Harmattan wind is so dry that there is often a difference of 20 deg. and upwards between the wet and dry bulb thermometers during the time that it prevails; while in the wet season there is generally not a single degree of difference between them. In the towns of the interior, after the Harmattan has been blowing for a few days, a man goes through the towns threatening death to any one who may set fire to a house, the buildings being all so dry that a fire spreads most rapidly.—Ed. A.T.]

Bonny.—Mr. Bragg, Stuart and Douglas's agent, died here on the 22nd of December. Captain White, agent for Messrs. Tobin and Son, died on the 2nd of January.

Benin.—The Sparkling Ware and the Fanny Belzona. Mr. Rothery, agent for Thos. Harrisson and Co., died 1st of January.

Lagos.—Two very serious fires have occurred here lately—one on the 12th of December, and the other on the 2nd of January, the latter destroying about 200 houses.

Accra.—Governor Pine arrived here in the Alligator on the 7th January. The ships in the roads were Alligator and Neero.

Cape Coast.—Kensil, the King of Cape Coast, died on the 9th of January, and was buried on the 13th with great pomp. Major Cochrane, in the absence of the Governor, attended the funeral with a guard of honour. Volleys were fired from the fort.  
Sierra Leone.—Her Majesty's ship Investigator. Bishop Beccles arrived here in the Armenian on the 9th of January.'}, {'id': 110, 'article_title': 'Great Fires at Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Great Fires at Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': "Our Lagos correspondent has given an account, which appears among our West Coast news, of two destructive fires at Lagos. It appears from his letter that the authorities have already decided on certain improvements as regards streets and buildings, as well as police regulations, that will diminish the probability of similar fires in future. This was absolutely necessary. Lagos is becoming a place of considerable trade. Our merchants' stores there are generally filled with valuable goods and produce. To insure these is out of the question; and every possible precaution ought to be insisted on by the Governor and Council to diminish the mercantile risk. Some of our friends have, we regret to say, had storehouses destroyed in the late conflagrations; but happily, the losses sustained by them, though vexatious, are not of a serious nature, all the principal stores having escaped; and if the proper measures be now adopted, as a consequence of these fires, the losses sustained in them will not be regretted.

We hope and believe that everything possible will be done for the embellishment as well as the security of Lagos. But as we find no allusion to it in our correspondent's letter, there is one thing that we desire to urge most earnestly upon the authorities here and at Lagos—that is, the formation of a Government magazine or powder depot at Lagos, where all the merchants may, and shall be compelled to deposit their powder, paying a certain rent to the Government. Without this there can be no real security. Gunpowder is largely imported. It has been, and still is, lying about in stores and outhouses in all directions. The danger of such a course is obvious. It might have done very well when Lagos was nothing but an agglomeration of barbarian huts. But now that it is rising in wealth and importance—now that some of the merchants' stores contain many thousand pounds worth of produce—now that it is a seat of British authority—so improvident a system ought not to be tolerated. We beg to press upon the authorities at home and in the colony the absolute necessity of immediate action in this matter. It is one of too vital a nature to be postponed or neglected."}, {'id': 111, 'article_title': 'LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': '01-09-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': "The two very destructive fires of the 12th December and 2nd January have wrought such havoc in this place, that we have scarcely had time to think of anything else but the losses they have occasioned, and the means to be adopted for preventing the recurrence of such disasters. The first was caused by some native frying fish in the street; a neighbouring hut ignited, the dry Harmattan wind was blowing, everything in the place was dry as tinder, and the flames spread with such violence and rapidity, that within half-an-hour they had cleared of all buildings an immense quantity of ground. The fire rolled along—a body of flame of about thirty feet in height—and everything within reach of its hot breath was destroyed. One or two merchants' stores caught, and their contents were, of course, soon lost to the owners. There was a quantity of palm oil in one of them,"}, {'id': 147, 'article_title': 'SHERBORO', 'full_section_title': 'SHERBORO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_05_1863', 'content': 'The dry season has been of unusual length and dryness, and the rivers are very low, but some refreshing showers have lately fallen.

The war in the Kittam still continues, and is going adversely to Prince Mahna, but the navigation of and trade in the rivers is uninterrupted.

The town of Welah, on the Jong, was recently destroyed by fire; also a factory at Waterloo, on the Boom.'}, {'id': 559, 'article_title': 'ABEOKUTA', 'full_section_title': 'ABEOKUTA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': 'We deeply regret to have to record the fact of a fire at this town, in which much property has been destroyed. It broke out, the dry harmattan wind blowing violently at the time, in the division of the town where the merchant stores were situate, and spread from store to store with great rapidity. The following details are from the Iwe Irohin:—

"On Sunday, the 22nd January, at 8.30 A.M., a fire commenced somewhere near the Kobbity-market, said to have been caused by the discharge of a musket.

The townships of Owu, Oba, and Igbore were the first to suffer. The fire then passed over the Oba hill and between it and the Owu hill, destroying the Church Missionary station at Owu. Both houses and church were burnt down, the premises of Capt. J. P. L. Davies, of Mr. M'Coskry, of Mr. F. Borgmeyer, where a large quantity of palm oil was stored in casks, all of which were destroyed, of Mr. C. N. Young, who lost everything, the Wesleyan chapel at Ogbe, but the house was saved; the house of Mr. Monday was burnt; Mrs. Gbambalas' house was saved, but the thatch over the walls enclosing the premises was burnt. The fire passed over Shokore, a rapid stream in wet weather, but now dry, and ignited the extensive premises of Mr. Ribeiro, Madam Tinabu, Mr. Savage, and that of the West

African Company. The iron house of the West African Company was no protection; by some means the property stored inside caught fire and was entirely consumed. The large hydraulic cotton press of the West African Company, just completed, was destroyed, together with their oil and cotton. A quantity of oil belonging to Capt. Davies and Mr. H. Robbin was saved, from being stored at some little distance off and in the open air. Among the Sierra-Leone people who suffered were Mr. Savage, who is said to have lost 30,000 gallons of oil, Mr. Peter Rae 9,300 gallons of oil, Mr. Jas. George 4,560 gallons of oil, and 12 kegs of powder, Mr. J. Holloway 1,300 gallons of oil, and 319lbs. of cotton, Mr. C. N. Young, who lost everything, furniture, clothing, books, cotton, cotton gins, puncheons of oil, rum and building materials, and Mr. S. Williams 30 puncheons of oil. There are many of whose losses we have no information, but the estimated total loss is 25,000l. or 30,000l."

Although this calamity will thus cause serious loss to many, there is cause for rejoicing that it did not happen at an earlier period, before any of the accumulated produce was allowed to go down. During the month of open river the West African Company sent down 700 bales of cotton and large quantities of oil, all of which, as well as the other 3,500 bales of cotton and quantities of oil, also sent down at the same time by other parties, would otherwise have been consumed.

We cannot conclude this notice without saying how much we sympathise with those whose property has been thus destroyed.'}, {'id': 936, 'article_title': 'To Preserve Shingle Roofs from Fire', 'full_section_title': 'To Preserve Shingle Roofs from Fire', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1866#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_10_1866', 'content': 'Sir,—An African friend informs me an incendiary lately tried to set his house on fire whilst his family were asleep in their beds, by placing on the shingles a piece of burning canvas, which had been previously soaked in oil. The diabolical act was only prevented being successful by an opposite neighbour seeing the burning canvas in time to prevent the ignition of the wooden shingles, which happily were damp with dew; and as he further informed me that fires are often very destructive among African towns, by fires originating in the wooden shingles, I beg to call the attention of your readers to the following very simple plan of rendering wooden shingles fireproof, and which has been for many years used with success in the State of North Carolina in the United States of America.

They grind the native carbonate of iron—that is, the common black lead—with linseed oil, to the consistency of paint, with which they paint the wooden shingles of their houses, and even their best wooden buildings. This simple plan, provided two or three coats of it are used, is so effectual, that buildings painted with this preparation have been purposely exposed to the full heat of a large fire for a considerable time without their sustaining any injury.—I am, Sir, yours truly,'}, {'id': 1923, 'article_title': 'LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1870#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_11_1870', 'content': 'We have had a bad fire here again among the native dwellings. In about two hours 500 of these were consumed, as also the Mohammedan mosque and a small Christian place of worship. The poor people lost nearly all they possessed; two men, three females, and two children lost their lives, and some twelve injured were carried to the hospital. The small fire-engine belonging to Messrs. Banner Brothers was brought to the spot as speedily as possible, but the fire had already obtained the mastery among the crowded habitations. The fire commenced at two p.m. 6th September, and at four p.m. had burnt itself out. The sad condition of the poor houseless people was aggravated by a heavy rain which soon after commenced, and lasted throughout the night and the greater part of the following day. The losses have been serious for the people—furniture, wearing apparel, trade goods, all were destroyed, the flames having spread too rapidly to allow of many things being saved. It is hoped that the Local Government and the well-to-do merchants and traders will assist in mitigating the distress which this fire has produced.

Similar though smaller fires are but too frequent in Lagos. Our correspondent tells us that three years ago there were no less than six in that one year—seventy or eighty dwellings in one night. Last year there were also six, and this of the 6th September was the fourth of the present year. Our correspondent suggests that these fires might be prevented by all the low houses being built with flat roofs, as at Cape Coast; or if not, that there ought to be a fire-engine near every well in Government-street.'}, {'id': 2142, 'article_title': "Conflagration in Sierra Leone, About 400 Yards from the Merchants' Powder Magazine", 'full_section_title': "Conflagration in Sierra Leone, About 400 Yards from the Merchants' Powder Magazine", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1872#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_02_1872', 'content': 'The city was suddenly aroused by the tolling of bells of the places of worship of different denominations of the Protestants and those of the Roman Catholic community, at midnight of the 19th inst. In not more than ten minutes the streets of the neighbourhood were crowded, and the people became aware of a great fire, that burnt to the loss and ruin of the owners, and the never-to-be-forgotten of the settlement. Thirteen shops and over five houses burnt to the ground in the most important and commercial portion of the city! What a loss! So terrible it was that the heat was felt at a considerable distance; powder was bursting and blazing, and much cutlery, guns, hardware, &c., &c., was destroyed. But we wish the owners (especially the homeless) God speed, and may they never despair.

Before concluding, Mr. Editor, let me ask, through your columns, has Sierra Leone no fire-engines? If not, the Government ought to keep no less than half-a-dozen, and to provide no less than twelve strong men to each, payable out of her revenue. If they had one here why did it not perform the work for which it was destined, on Sunday, the 14th inst., when also three houses were burnt to ashes.

Again, it will be very well that the ordinances of Sierra Leone relative to forty-eight hours notice to be given to the police magistrate before anybody should make or attempt to make any fire within his or her premises; and the clause to inspect each store, shop, &c., from keeping over a barrel of powder be now executed and put into force. Meanwhile, Mr. Editor, I remain,  
L.

---'}, {'id': 2704, 'article_title': 'HOW KUMASI WAS DESTROYED', 'full_section_title': 'HOW KUMASI WAS DESTROYED', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_03_1874#article-11', 'issue_date': '28_03_1874', 'content': "At six o'clock the advanced guard of the baggage began to move, and the main body was off by seven. The 42nd remained as rear guard to cover the engineers and burning party. About a hundred of the engineer labourers were supplied with palm-leaf torches, and although there was some fear at first that the tremendous rains would prevent the thatch from burning, we soon had the satisfaction of seeing clear volumes of smoke rise from the whole of the farther extremity of the town. The smoke of the burning town was dense in the extreme, and flames leapt up fiercely from time to time.—*Standard Correspondent.*"}, {'id': 4556, 'article_title': 'Great Fire in Jamaica', 'full_section_title': 'Great Fire in Jamaica', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-25', 'issue_date': '01_01_1883', 'content': "**GREAT FIRE IN JAMAICA.**

A large number of the inhabitants are homeless and destitute."}, {'id': 4566, 'article_title': 'ZANZIBAR.', 'full_section_title': 'ZANZIBAR.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_02_1883', 'content': 'A commercial house of Marseilles has just received an interesting letter from Zanzibar, from which we give the following extracts: “A terrible famine is raging on the Comoran Islands. To these must be added the Nyanza, Akala, and Swordsman, and thus the commercial fleet of the Sultan counts six fine steamships. It is said that the Sultan intends to use these ships for a regular coast service.”'}, {'id': 4844, 'article_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS NEWS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1884#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_05_1884', 'content': 'A terrible conflagration occurred on Monday, March 3, when a great number of houses were consumed. The fire originated in the house of one Robbin Davies, at Breadfruit-street, near Olowogbowo Chapel, and made its way to Bankole-street, and on to Offin-highway, where it spread on to Balogun-square, Ereko, Idunshagbe, Idumagbo, and up to ex-King Docemo's quarters. The fire began about 10 a.m., and continued till past noon. All possible assistance was rendered by the armed police and other private persons. And on the 13th of March another fire broke out, beginning at Ereko, and extending also up to the ex-king's quarters. It is time the authorities found some remedy against these fires. We understand there is a fire-engine belonging to the Government locked up in a store at Tinubu-square, which, it is reported, has never been used for any public good, and it is simply an eyesore to passers-by. And the question is asked: "Why should the colony be saddled with the expense of this machine, which is not used in the case of fire of this kind?" Besides, a single fire-engine is not sufficient for a place like Lagos, where fire is common; and we shall be glad to learn that some more efficient means are provided against fire.

On the afternoon of Monday, March 3, at Government House, the commission, under the hand and seal of Sir Samuel Rowe, appointing retired Commander Rumsey Deputy for the Governor, was read by his Honour J. Smallman Smith, Puisne Judge of Gold Coast Settlement. There were present the officials, merchants (European and native) and many of the inhabitants.

According to latest advices from Lagos, Lieut.-Governor Griffiths and Mrs. Griffiths went to Accra, as also Sir Samuel Rowe, to await the arrival of Lieut.-Governor Young, the new Administrator, from British Guiana, before they embark for England.

His Honour Mr. Smallman Smith has been obliged to go to Cape Coast Castle, to attend a meeting of the Full Court.

We are pleased to learn that Earl Derby has offered to Mr. Maxwell, of Lagos, the post of Queen's Advocate for the Gambia, and that that gentleman has signified his acceptance of the same.'}, {'id': 5170, 'article_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': '1. This trade, increasing as it does year by year in its lucrative character, is capable of vast improvement in the settlements themselves, at the trading stations and in the interior. The British possessions on the coast must take care to develop at home, if they would make their towns centres for increased traffic beyond their limits. The roads inland must become something more than mere paths. There ought to be the commencement of River Conservancy Boards on a small scale, in order that the sand-bars, snags, and freshets of the Volta and the Prah should cease to be hindrances to the working of the coal fields on the former, and to ordinary commerce on the latter. The traffic in spirits, so fraught with evil to natives everywhere, ought to be forbidden by Act of the Imperial Parliament, the cargo to be seized and destroyed, and the owners subjected to a heavy fine. And is it not time for the construction of docks at practicable spots, and for taking precautions against the recurrence of the fires which devastate Freetown and Lagos so frequently? One of their own number, Dr. Africanus Horton, was the first to propose most of them several years ago in an address to the African Aid Society, and it is time now that public and private attention should be given to his suggestions.'}, {'id': 5447, 'article_title': 'PETITION.', 'full_section_title': 'PETITION.', 'last_edit_date': '08-11-1886', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_12_1886', 'content': '(We have much pleasure in laying the following Petition to the Acting Administrator and Legislative Council of Lagos before our readers, as the free importation of fireproof building materials is a matter of great importance in view of the frequent fires in the town, and every encouragement should be given which would tend to reduce this risk.)

*From the Merchants, Traders, and other Inhabitants of Lagos, to His Excellency the Acting Administrator and the Honourable Members of the Legislative Council.*

Lagos, August 11, 1886.

The petition of the undersigned merchants, traders, and other inhabitants of Lagos, respectfully sheweth:

1. That previous to the coming into operation of the Ordinance entitled "Customs Tariff Ordinance," No. 8, of 4th April, 1877, the Colony of Lagos was subject to dreadful periodical conflagrations, the occurrence of which on many occasions resulted in very serious loss of life and property, accompanied with great amount of misery to the poorer class and detriment to business generally.

2. That on the 30th January, 1877, a conflagration of the nature above described took place, commencing from Ebute Ero district, where it broke out, and terminating at the Breadfruit district, occupying not less than three hours in continuous whirling flames, during which time a large number of houses, including churches and public buildings, and property, as also seven lives, were destroyed.

3. That on the eventful occasion it was thought necessary that some steps should be taken, and that representation be made to the Governor, with a view to the devising of some scheme or plan whereby the frequent occurrence of fire might be checked. In pursuance of the resolution formed, an interview with His Excellency Sanford Freeling, C.M.G., Governor and Commander-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony, was sought for and obtained, during his visit to this place, by a number of respectable gentlemen who waited upon him at Government House.

4. With reference to the discussion of the subject and the suggestions offered by His Excellency the Governor, your petitioners would not venture here to reiterate, but would quote in reference the leader of a local journal, the Lagos Times, vol. 3, No. 72, of October 24, 1883, copy of which is herewith annexed, marked A.

5. With pleasing remembrance, your petitioners beg to state that besides other good achieved by the interview referred to, apart from the Ordinance which is the outcome of the said interview, was the prohibition of gun and rocket firing in the town, which had been a common practice amongst the inhabitants.

6. That the said "Customs Tariff Ordinance," which came into operation on April 4, 1877, has been and is still in force, and that no part or section of it has been annulled or amended by any subsequent Ordinance.'}, {'id': 5650, 'article_title': 'Destructive Fires in the Neighbourhood of Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Destructive Fires in the Neighbourhood of Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1888#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_02_1888', 'content': 'According to advices received in Liverpool from Lagos, it appears that a large number of fires have recently occurred in and around that place. One fire is said to have commenced in Agbo Market, in Abeokuta, extending with terrible rapidity until it had spread to many townships round about, not stopping until it had reached Idomapa, a considerable distance from where it originated. The small huts of the natives, constructed of material of a combustible nature, were rapidly burnt up by the flames, rendering thousands of persons homeless. Another fire broke out at Lagos, commencing in Obadino-street. This was considered to be the act of an incendiary. Most, if not all, of the fires are said to be the acts of incendiaries, and a Government reward has been offered for the arrest of the guilty parties. The second conflagration burnt out a good square mile of Lagos huts and houses in little more than an hour's time. We were now thoroughly aroused to the necessity of taking precautions for the future. I believe it will be so arranged that the merchants' stores will range along the quay, and be isolated from all native habitations. This seems to be indispensable to the prosperity of the town, because no insurance could be effected on property in this place except at rates that would more than eat up all mercantile profits. It has been already decided by the Legislative Council that no houses built henceforth shall be thatched; they must be covered with a less combustible material; and within a certain reasonable time the thatch must also be removed from all dwellings and other buildings now covered by it. That good will eventually result from these disasters there can be no doubt; only it is greatly to be deplored that no compensation can be given to those who have suffered. It is to be hoped that the Governor and Council will lay down a systematic plan for the re-construction of the place; providing for good and open roads and streets, intersecting each other at right angles. As we possess abundance of the very best brick clay, and brick making has already been commenced on a small scale, to be perfected and increased when some necessary pug mills, &c., arrive from England, we may reasonably hope that Lagos will ere long become a model town—as an Anglo-African town ought to be—for the people on the neighbouring mainland, not only on the immediate coast, but far into the interior. The old-fashioned pig-stye hut must perish, and disappear before advancing civilization; in fact, there can be very little real advance in civilization while such residences continue to be used.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-01-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The mail steamer Loanda, of the British & African Steam Navigation Co., arrived at Liverpool on Sept. 27, having left Lagos on Aug. 30, at which date all was quiet in the Colony. A recent strike of the police force was caused by an endeavour being made to compel the police to perform fire brigade duty in addition to their ordinary avocation. Recently, on a fire occurring in the Hausa quarters, great difficulty was experienced in getting the engine out of the Custom House building, and in the interval no fewer than thirty-six houses were burned down. It was then decided to remove the fire engine to the public works, where it could be got at any moment. The authorities also considered that the police ought to perform the fire brigade duty, and for this they agreed to give them extra pay in the shape of overtime. The police objected to the overtime, and as the result refused to perform duty. There was no alternative but to get them arrested by the Hausas. After imprisoning the ringleaders, an arrangement was come to by which the police are to act as a reserve fire brigade. Fifteen men are detailed weekly for the duty, to be succeeded the following week by fifteen others. The fact, however, of the police objecting to obey orders gave the authorities the impression that they could not be relied upon, and on this account the desire for the return of the 300 Hausas sent down to the Gold Coast from Lagos was expressed.—The work of constructing the new railway was stopped when the Loanda passed. This was on account of the rains, but there had also been a number of deaths. It is said that the line is costing more than had been anticipated, and that the money voted for the construction was nearly exhausted, although not much more than one-tenth of the work had been completed. Mr. W. Shalford, M.Inst. C.E., consulting engineer to the Colonial Office for West African Railways, states with regard to the railway being constructed at Lagos: (1) The construction has never been stopped, but during the wet season the rate of construction has necessarily been below the average. (2) During the rainy season, also, there has been the usual increase of sickness, but no death has occurred on the railway staff during the last year and a-half. (3) So far from the line costing more than had been anticipated, it is now certain that the work already constructed has been carried out within the estimate. (4) About one-third of the authorised length has been so far completed that locomotives drawing construction trains are running over it." These facts show that the paragraph referred to is unfounded, and, as the railway is by far the most important work which has yet been undertaken by the colonial Government, it is much to be regretted that a false impression should be made public.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-11-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_11_1897#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CAMEROONS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We learn from Cameroons, under date of Nov. 29, that the mission house erected by the Rev. A. Saker, of the Baptist persuasion, at Cameroons, had narrowly escaped destruction by fire; an atrocious attempt having been made at 3.30 a.m. a few days previous to set fire to the premises. That it was the act of an incendiary, instigated by a desire of plunder, there could be no doubt, as a long bamboo, with combustibles attached to the end, which was burnt and charred, was found in the immediate neighbourhood. A meeting has subsequently been held, and a heavy reward offered for the discovery and apprehension of the offender or offenders. The escape of the occupants of the house is nothing short of miraculous; as, had the discovery of the fire, which had been applied to the thatch of an outbuilding immediately adjoining the house, taken place even five minutes later than it did, the whole of the roof would have ignited, and the woodwork being very dry, would have burnt with such rapidity, that many lives, especially of native children, of whom there were thirty or forty in the house, must have been lost. The burning of the hulk Sir John Falstaff, in June last, probably suggested fire as an assistant to robbery—the natives having reaped a very rich harvest on the occasion of that lamentable accident. There have been no tornadoes yet; but land winds of long continuance blow every day, and apprehension was felt that sickness would soon be prevalent, if the then close and sultry weather continued.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The sanitary condition of the town of Cape Coast, and indeed of all the towns upon the seaboard, is deplorable. Notwithstanding that some good has of late been effected by the municipality, yet, strange to relate, no public cloacinae have as yet been provided to meet the wants of the people, although the subject has been repeatedly taken up, and just as suddenly dropped, the consequence being that decency is constantly outraged, and the most disgusting nuisances are openly committed in the streets. Foul stenches everywhere assail the nose and corrupt the air, dunghills being attached to the huts, where garbage, filth, stinking fish, and other abominations are thrown. The smells along the byepaths and beach in the neighbourhood of the towns and villages are most offensive from accumulations of human ordure and offal; in fact, the native population is unrestrained by any police rules, except at Cape Coast and Accra. In both towns the municipal corporation have enacted laws for their conservancy; but in reality they are a dead letter, and hence an amount of nuisance scarcely credible. In the other towns, the Paynims, or native police, utterly neglect important matters of this kind. Indeed, the inhabitants of Cape Coast and the other towns and villages are chiefly indebted for their partial cleanliness to those useful scavengers, the turkey buzzards, largely helped by packs of half-starved, mangy curs and ill-conditioned hogs, who greedily devour the excrementitious matters which are left to rot upon the streets."', 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Horrible and Dangerous State of Cape Coast after Forty Years of British Rule', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A few stringent orders to the police would do all that is required, after some public privies have been constructed at proper spots outside the town. We have been told that there is an inspector of nuisances; also that orders have been given to somebody or other, about two months since, to see about taking steps to make arrangements to get some people to undertake to endeavour to persuade some one to speak to the inhabitants about throwing dirt in the streets. This is mere trifling, and while this nonsense is going on death is surely stealing onward. It will, it must come at last; the horrible cholera sweeping us off as it has done the people of Gambia. When most of the white people are dead, when all day and all night there shall be heard the well-known sound of coffin-making, when we are called upon to follow to the graveyard, at seven in the morning, four out of ten persons with whom we dined last night, then it may, perhaps, occur to the authorities, if there be any left, to give some directions and take some measures to arrest the strides of the awful visitor whom we may shortly expect. If the Government are determined to remain supine in this matter, let them at least provide for the speedy interment of the dead when the expected cholera comes upon us. In the latter part of 1869, when the cholera was expected at Sierra Leone, the Government of that settlement lost no time in making such arrangements as would at any rate lessen the horrors of the possibly impending calamity if it should come. If the streets are to remain as they are, Government ought to employ the convict prisoners in digging pits at proper places outside the town, for the purposes of burial. It would be quite absurd—nay, it would be a sin—to mince matters. How will those who exercise power in this settlement be able to answer to Almighty God if thousands of people should be suddenly swept off the earth, thousands of homes made desolate, simply because these, our lawful rulers, fail to use a little, a very little, exertion in order to save the lives of those entrusted to their charge? Once for all, if there be shortly a great deal of disease in Cape Coast, let all these words be remembered. An unusual number of persons are sick already, including several of the troops, who are mostly laid up in hospital from the consequences of breathing an atmosphere tainted with the smell of human excrement.\n\n—West African Herald.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-04-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1871#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Sanitary Condition of Lagos, and Its Remedy', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Governor of Lagos has transmitted to the Secretary of State a report by Mr. J. W. Rowland on the sanitary condition of that island. Mr. Rowland says: "The island is alluvial, and, being in the tropics, could not be otherwise than malarious. The level of the ground water never retires far from the surface. In the driest season it is in some wells not six feet deep; in Olowogbowo, the most elevated part of the island, at this season water is found at a depth of twenty-one feet, and the average depth, as found by the measurement of Government wells erected only in the more elevated quarters, is thirteen feet. In the rains the water is close to the surface—in some places, indeed, above it. This is very favourable for the production of malaria. There was a large mortality amongst the European population in the town. This points out the urgency for sanitary works, as most of the deaths were due to malaria. The prevention, or at least the mitigation, of this evil should be the first subject to which attention is paid. That it is possible to eradicate malaria from its most favoured haunts has been repeatedly proved. To find a remedy it must first be known what are the conditions necessary and most favourable to its development. It is not necessary to know the nature of the malarial poison if its production can be prevented, or at least curtailed: the two chief conditions are subsoil moisture and a high temperature. It is in the tropics that these conditions predominate. To combat them it is necessary to drain the subsoil and lower the temperature of the surface. Nature supplies in vegetation a simple means of attaining these ends. Pittenkofer has calculated that an oak-tree which had 751,592 leaves had from May to October an evaporation equal to 212 inches, whilst the rainfall over an area equal to that covered by the tree was only 25.6 inches, so that the evaporation was 8.3 times the rainfall. The eucalyptus in Algeria has been calculated to evaporate twelve times the rainfall. The water for evaporation is supplied from the subsoil by the roots, which penetrate in all directions. Whilst getting rid of the water from the soil, the evaporation cools the air, and the shade afforded by the trees protects the soil from the direct rays of the sun. If we acknowledge the influence of high temperature in producing malaria, the great advantage to be gained by sheltering the soil from the direct rays of the sun is evident, when we consider that when the temperature in the shade is 80°, in exposed parts it is nearly double. As a sandy soil has twice the capacity for retaining heat as humus, the disadvantage of having large unshaded sandy plains in the neighbourhood is evident. Such plains are hotbeds of malaria. These plains arise from the destruction of the forests, which is brought about partly for the purpose of supplying fuel, but mainly in order to clear the land for cultivation. The virgin soil, never particularly rich, is capable of producing crops for four or five years. The land is then deserted, and becomes overgrown with grass, which, being periodically burnt, prevents the re-growth of the forest. The exposed soil is impoverished by the heavy rainfall carrying away all the organic matter, so that further cultivation is impossible. This is notably the case about Accra, where the open plains radiate for about ten or twelve miles from the town. As a sanitary measure, it is suggested that the planting of quick-growing and shade-producing trees in the open spaces, in the compounds of houses, and the streets, should be proceeded with at once. All the streets should be shaded with trees, which should be planted so as to give the maximum shade with the minimum interference with the circulation of air. The eucalyptus has been largely used for this purpose, but it does not thrive in Lagos, owing, I think, to the poor sandy soil. One planted in the hospital compound in 1882 is now covered with flower buds, but the tree has not gained its reputed dimensions. There are many local trees that would answer our purpose better.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1888#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE NIGER COAST PROTECTORATE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the beginning of the present year the town of Bonny was in a dirty and unsanitary condition. The Chiefs were told about this at several meetings, but seemed disinclined to assist in the cleaning of their town. Two inspectors of nuisances have been appointed, who are under the orders of the medical officer in charge of this part of the district. Several people were summoned in the Consular Court, the President of the Native Council among the number; small fines were imposed as a beginning. Through this means, and also a weekly inspection of the town by the sanitary officer and one of the principal Chiefs, there has been a decided improvement in the cleanliness of the place, but much still remains to be done. There has also been a considerable amount of bush and undergrowth between the town and the river cut away; this enables the fresh breeze from the sea to blow directly into the town. Okrika is in a very dirty condition, and there has been no opportunity yet of improving it. The towns of Bakana, Buguma, and Abonema are very clean for Native towns. The Chiefs have made strict sanitary laws, and look well after their people. These towns are all laid out in a regular plan, and have wide streets and a good circulation of air. For the present the only improvement suggested as regards the New Calabar towns is that the bush opposite the town of Buguma be cleared away. The Natives have already cleared a considerable part of this, but should carry the clearing further up the creek, so as to enable the breeze from the south to blow right across the town. There has been a sanitary officer appointed and placed in charge of the New Calabar sub-district. As to the town of Bonny, as soon as the rains are over, a great part of it will be condemned, and the Chiefs who own the houses directed to pull them down. There are many houses overhanging the streets, which renders them dangerous to passers-by, owing to their rickety condition. The difficulty in dealing with the town of Bonny is that the Chiefs have large plantations at which they reside, and in consequence do not take the interest in the town which they should.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-02-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_02_1895#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}]

hh: The widespread and unregulated storage of gunpowder during the colonial era in Africa posed significant safety risks, leading to catastrophic explosions and highlighting the need for centralized regulation and designated storage facilities to protect both African and European lives and infrastructure.
result: The claim that the widespread and unregulated storage of gunpowder during the colonial era in Africa posed significant safety risks, leading to catastrophic explosions and highlighting the need for centralized regulation and designated storage facilities, is supported by evidence from The African Times but not directly addressed in the General History of Africa textbook. The textbook primarily focuses on the role of firearms in the balance of power, the monopolization of arms by European powers, and the impact of European military technology on African societies, without mentioning safety risks or incidents related to gunpowder storage. In contrast, The African Times provides substantial evidence supporting the claim, documenting multiple incidents of catastrophic explosions, such as the accidental explosion of the Dutch Powder-house at Kinsembo and the explosion on the railway from Matadi, both resulting in significant loss of life and property. The articles also highlight the dangers of storing gunpowder in merchant houses and factories, as seen in the fires at Little Popo and Muculla, where gunpowder explosions exacerbated the destruction. These incidents underscore the urgent need for centralized regulation and designated storage facilities, as advocated by correspondents urging the establishment of government magazines for gunpowder storage to prevent such disasters. The African Times articles consistently emphasize the perilous nature of unregulated gunpowder storage, aligning closely with the claim's assertion of the necessity for improved safety measures to protect both African and European lives and infrastructure.

[{'document_title': 'Conclusion: Africa on the eve of the European conquest', 'section_title': 'The legacy of wars', 'content': "As noted above, the critical factor in the changing balance of power in Africa in the 1870s was not the troops, nor their training and discipline or generalship, but the quality and quantity of the guns available to the respective sides. The ultimate answer in the contest for power in Africa therefore depended on the monopolization of arms and ammunition. This was not easy to achieve as long as Europeans pursued national interests and African rulers could play off one power against another. Moreover, in the essential search for allies, Europeans had to use the supply of quality guns to bargain for treaties, concessions, neutrality or active participation in wars against rival African states. It therefore became essential to regulate their Scramble on the basis of international agreements and, in particular, to limit the supply of arms and ammunition. The most intense rivalry was between the British and the French. The British tried to secure their interests by also playing the role of protectors of Portuguese interests. This gave Bismarck the opportunity to play the role of an interested broker by convening an International Conference in Berlin. This Conference in turn gave King Leopold his chance to seek for international support for his ambitions on the Congo by proclaiming free trade and humanitarian antislavery ambitions.$^{24}$ This prepared the way for the Brussels Act which banned the supply of arms to African rulers in the name of an anti-slavery campaign.
The truth was that by linking the limitation of arms with the anti-slavery campaign, the British were able to exempt the 'self-governing' settlers in South Africa from the operations of the Brussels Act. By this device also, while constantly fighting African states and negotiating various treaties and conventions with African rulers, they could pretend that, by owning slaves and dealing in slaves, African states enjoyed no recognition in international law. It was thus possible to pretend in the General Act of the Berlin Conference of 1885 and the Brussels Act of 1889 that in international law Africa was a terra nullius and only European powers and settlers had interests there that had to be protected.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Conclusion: Africa on the eve of the European conquest', 'section_title': 'Military systems', 'content': 'The revolution created by the growing importance of European arma› ments can be illustrated by the difference in the experience of emperors TØwodros and Yohannes in Ethiopia. Smallpox vaccination was on such a small scale that by the late 1930s a significant reduction of the disease had probably taken place only in the Gold Coast and southern Nigeria. 93 In contrast, contact with Europeans and participation in the First World War ensured that the influenza epidemic of 1918-19 swept through Africa probably resulting in the highest annual death rate this century, although the rise in death rates was probably not as great as in Asia, for many African populations were still protected by comparative isolation. Death rates were still enormous in the mines of Southern Africa in the early years of the present century; a 1907 commission reporting on the situation in Transvaal drew attention to death rates in the mines at the time of 71 per thousand for tropical Africans compared with 28 for Africans from the temperate south and 19 for whites, the rates having declined from 130, 35 and 20 respectively two years earlier.$^{94}$ In most of the continent little progress had been made against the greatest scourge of all, malaria, which weakened when it did not kill and explained many deaths attributed to other causes.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.619, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 110, 'article_title': 'Great Fires at Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Great Fires at Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': "Our Lagos correspondent has given an account, which appears among our West Coast news, of two destructive fires at Lagos. It appears from his letter that the authorities have already decided on certain improvements as regards streets and buildings, as well as police regulations, that will diminish the probability of similar fires in future. This was absolutely necessary. Lagos is becoming a place of considerable trade. Our merchants' stores there are generally filled with valuable goods and produce. To insure these is out of the question; and every possible precaution ought to be insisted on by the Governor and Council to diminish the mercantile risk. Some of our friends have, we regret to say, had storehouses destroyed in the late conflagrations; but happily, the losses sustained by them, though vexatious, are not of a serious nature, all the principal stores having escaped; and if the proper measures be now adopted, as a consequence of these fires, the losses sustained in them will not be regretted.

We hope and believe that everything possible will be done for the embellishment as well as the security of Lagos. But as we find no allusion to it in our correspondent's letter, there is one thing that we desire to urge most earnestly upon the authorities here and at Lagos—that is, the formation of a Government magazine or powder depot at Lagos, where all the merchants may, and shall be compelled to deposit their powder, paying a certain rent to the Government. Without this there can be no real security. Gunpowder is largely imported. It has been, and still is, lying about in stores and outhouses in all directions. The danger of such a course is obvious. It might have done very well when Lagos was nothing but an agglomeration of barbarian huts. But now that it is rising in wealth and importance—now that some of the merchants' stores contain many thousand pounds worth of produce—now that it is a seat of British authority—so improvident a system ought not to be tolerated. We beg to press upon the authorities at home and in the colony the absolute necessity of immediate action in this matter. It is one of too vital a nature to be postponed or neglected."}, {'id': 346, 'article_title': 'NEW CALABAR.', 'full_section_title': 'NEW CALABAR.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'In our March number we gave an account of the destruction by fire of a number of English trading vessels at New Calabar by fire. By accounts which have just reached us, having been delayed en route, we learn that the matting with which the ships were "armed" had been rendered so dry, by the "Harmattan winds," that it caught fire on board the ship which was first in flames from a mere spark that escaped from the cooking-house on deck. This vessel had above 1,000 quarter barrels of gunpowder on board, and its explosion was terrific. All the other ships in the river were, of course, in an equally inflammable state from the "Harmattan winds;" the concussion started many of their timbers; six of these ships then caught fire from the explosion of the first, and one of these having some 1,500 quarter barrels on board, shortly after exploded also. Altogether seven vessels were entirely destroyed, and one other was damaged. Three, the property, as before stated, of Messrs. Horsfall, of Liverpool, and of the Company of African Merchants, alone escaped. We are glad not to hear of any loss of life; and have no doubt that in future such precaution will be taken as will render any similar catastrophe impossible.'}, {'id': 1393, 'article_title': 'Danger from Private Powder Stores on the Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Danger from Private Powder Stores on the Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '08-08-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_09_1868', 'content': "Sir,—I wish you would call attention to the existence of an enormous atrocity which every trader on the Gold Coast has a hand in—I mean keeping quantities of gunpowder in their houses. There is hardly a house in Cape Coast, Anamaboe, or Accra, but contains gunpowder, in larger or smaller quantities. What would become of us all at Anamaboe, Cape Coast, or Accra, if one of the principal merchant's houses was to catch fire, these houses being really powder magazines? I'm a fool for asking such a question. Why, we should all go to blazes, that's the fact. Any mischievous man might at any moment involve all Anamaboe or Cape Coast in ruin. It is surely for the interest of the merchants themselves, as well as of all the residents, that they should make a movement to get up regular powder stores in some convenient spot outside the towns, otherwise they will find themselves some day in a very awkward fix. At present a flash of lightning or a spark of fire may be the means of blowing all Cape Coast, Anamaboe, or Accra to atoms.—Yours obediently,"}, {'id': 1510, 'article_title': 'Destructive Powder Explosion at Kinserbo, West Coast of Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Destructive Powder Explosion at Kinserbo, West Coast of Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1869#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_03_1869', 'content': 'On the 22nd ult. the Dutch Powder-house at Kinsembo accidentally blew up, causing terrible destruction to property and life. The shock was so violent that it was felt at Loanda, and supposed it to be an earthquake.'}, {'id': 2216, 'article_title': 'West African News', 'full_section_title': 'West African News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1872#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1872', 'content': 'The Africa and the Volta steamers arrived at Liverpool, within a few hours of each other, on the night of the 14th and morning of the 15th inst.

**OLD CALABAR.**—It is stated there has been a serious gunpowder explosion here, but the details have not yet reached us.

**ACCRA.**—There have been several shocks of earthquake here.

**ASHANTI.**—There are rumours of a civil war having commenced at Kumasi, the capital. The withdrawal of the Dutch from the sea-coast, and the organisation of the Fanti Confederation, rendering it impossible for the Ashantis to make any more successful attacks on the Fanti countries, are very likely to set them fighting among themselves; and we look forward to such a change in Ashanti as will allow civilizing influences to obtain an entry into that valuable country.'}, {'id': 2608, 'article_title': 'West Coast Steamer News', 'full_section_title': 'West Coast Steamer News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-1', 'issue_date': '29_11_1873', 'content': 'The Elmina arrived at Liverpool November 1. She carried a good number of volunteers from Lagos to Accra. The sea on the bar at Lagos delayed ships for some time.

The Soudan arrived, November 7, from West and South-West Coast.

The Grandy Expedition, under an escort from the King of St. Salvadore, had passed safely through the district where their passages had been disputed. Dr. Bastian and Mr. Van Hattow went up to Boma on their interior expedition, on the 8th instant, in the King Ja Ja steamship.

Diamonds have been discovered near a place called Sooka, 95 miles up the Congo river. The stones have been examined by Dr. Basham, Director of the Museum of Berlin, who is travelling in the interior, and he has pronounced them to be of fine water. The news has caused great excitement amongst the Portuguese in the settlements south of the Congo. The river is navigable by small steamers within a few miles of Sooka.

A fire broke out at Ponta de Lenha on August 28, and three factories were totally destroyed.

The Senegal, which had broken the blades of her propeller, and has been towed home from Madeira by the Cruiser tug, reached Liverpool on the 13th instant.

November 17.—The Standard of this morning, in a third edition, published the following: "Successful Brush with the Ashantees.—The naval and military forces disembarked at Elmina, and having marched twenty miles through the bush, defeated the Ashantees after a brisk skirmish, and burnt five villages. M'NieI, Fremantle, and twenty-six others, are wounded. Upon the news of the defeat, the Ashantees broke up their great camp," &c. A letter from Cape Coast was published at the same time, full of strange inaccuracies, which may be excused because of the extreme haste of publication; but there is no excuse for continually writing of Sir Charles McCarthy as Sir Charles Macnaughten! The Evening Standard of same day contained full details of the expedition led by Sir Garnet Wolseley in the neighbourhood of Elmina. This expedition was valuable, as showing the power of endurance of the British troops, and teaching the Ashantees that the bush is no protection for them against British officers and men, led by such a chief as Sir Garnet Wolseley. The latest news, October 27, states the Ashantees to be in full retreat to the Prah.

OUTWARD.

The Volta, on November 6, took out Commander Crohan, R.N., Paymaster Ramsay, 15th Foot, Surgeon-Major Reid, Assistant-Commissary Wyatt; Lieutenants Bell, 2nd West India Regiment; Irvine, 1st Foot; Grant, 6th Foot; Douglas, 7th Foot; Pollock, 21st Foot; Hare, 22nd Foot; Waselope, 42nd Foot; and Alymer, 103rd Foot; Sub-Lieutenants Prior and Caulfield, and the Rev. R. S. Patterson, Chaplain to the Forces. There were also several non-commissioned officers and privates.'}, {'id': 3065, 'article_title': "THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY", 'full_section_title': "THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY", 'last_edit_date': '02-07-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_04_1876', 'content': "## THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY.

**CAPE COAST, February 7.**—The King of Ashanti paid another instalment of 500 ounces of gold, on account of the indemnity, on the 24th of January, to Dr. Gouldsbury, at Coomassie. The gold was sent, under escort of Captain Baker, to Cape Coast, but the money not being paid at the promised date, a fine was imposed of ten ounces, and paid at once. The gold paid by Ashanti has proved to be adulterated, and orders have been sent by the Governor that it be replaced in five days by good gold. Dr. Gouldsbury is still at Coomassie. The King of Djuabin arrived here on the 1st inst., having been summoned by the Governor for a reprimand for the late outbreak. He is now arranging to settle in the Protectorate, near Prahouse. Interior very quiet; roads all open. Trade dull. Commodore Hewett is expected here about the 14th. Lieutenant-Governor Lees arrived here on the 5th. The Daubin and his followers having been defeated by the Ashantees, sought protection from the Governor of the Gold Coast Colony, and were promised so much of the Protectorate for their habitation and cultivation on the same terms as the Protected tribes. Captain Baker's rapid march of four days to Coomassie has made a deep impression on the Ashantees at Coomassie. Human sacrifice has been put a stop to. It is stated that Captain Baker will proceed to the Windward districts immediately, but for what cause did not transpire. All is quiet in Ashanti. The King of Djuabin is nearly ready to start for the new site for his town. Trade is improving, owing to the interior disturbances being settled. The Whydah authorities have committed an outrage on a European agent of an English house. They stripped and flogged him, and imprisoned him in a filthy store, on account of the agent protesting against forcible appropriation of some property by the King's people.

A fire broke out at Little Popo on the 1st of February, which totally destroyed one-half of the Beachtown. In almost all the houses gunpowder is kept, and explosion after explosion took place, the natives not attempting to prevent the spreading of the flames. In one house 2,000 kegs exploded, causing a shock like that of an earthquake. Some of the natives, while plundering, were blown up, and it was reported that about fifty were killed. The loss is stated to be very considerable, two factories alone having lost about 4,000l."}, {'id': 4803, 'article_title': 'THE WAR IN LOWER GUINEA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE WAR IN LOWER GUINEA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1884#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_03_1884', 'content': '

She brings particulars of a serious battle between the natives of Muculla and some traders and Krooboys, during which a powder magazine was exploded, killing a large number of men as well as causing much damage to property. The affair arose, it is stated, through the agent of the Dutch factory at Muculla employing Krooboys to perform the labouring duties in connection with the establishment. The king of the place requested the Dutch authorities to discharge the men, but the agent would not, saying he had a perfect right to employ whom he pleased. A few days afterwards the natives sought the intervention of the other European traders to have the Krooboys withdrawn. The natives invited the whites to the town to hold a meeting, but the latter refused to interfere. In less than three hours afterwards a force of from 700 to 800 natives arrived, with flint-lock guns, spears, and other weapons, and marched in a body to attack the factory. The agent had collected his Kroomen to the number of over 100, and armed them with Snider rifles in anticipation of an attack. He had also four 16-pounder guns which were put into position. The white assistants were armed with Martini rifles. For some time a brisk fire was exchanged, many of the natives taking shelter behind a powder magazine situated about 400 yards from the factory. At one time the natives threatened to take the place by storm, owing to their overwhelming numbers. Fearing this, and the consequent massacre of the small defending party, the magazine was fired into. A fearful explosion followed, killing all the natives who were near and destroying much property. It was said that thirty natives were firing from behind the magazine when the explosion took place, and all of them were killed. It was said the magazine contained over 25,000 lbs. of powder at the time. The factory to which the magazine belonged was completely destroyed, the débris falling around the Europeans who were endeavouring to save the place. Notwithstanding this disaster, the natives continued to fight for several hours, but eventually withdrew, leaving about forty dead behind. So great was the explosion that the report was heard at Ambrizette, seventeen miles distant. The battle was fought on Dec. 17, and on the 24th the Portuguese corvette, Rainha de Portugal, arrived, when a consultation took place between the commander and the traders. It was decided that the king of the place, together with four of his headmen, should be detained as a security against any further disturbance, and if the demand was not complied with, force would be used. A reply to the request was to be received on Jan. 4, and in the event of the king and the other hostages not being forthcoming, an expedition was to be sent up on the 7th. In the meantime a force of fifty marines and 200 Kroomen was made ready for the forthcoming war, in case of the ultimatum being refused, and the Dutch gunboat Tromp received orders to sail at once for San Paolo de Loanda. There is thus every chance of a lively little campaign between the merchants and the Dutch and Portuguese marines, assisted by the unpatriotic Kroomen, on the one hand, and the King with his black warriors on the other.'}, {'id': 6794, 'article_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS.', 'full_section_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1897#article-2', 'issue_date': '04_01_1897', 'content': "The British & African Company's steamer Lagos, which arrived at Liverpool on Dec. 10 with mails and passengers from the West Coast, brought sad news from Grand Lahou. Lahou is a French port on the Ivory Coast, and just before the Lagos touched there a terrific explosion had occurred on board a steam launch, killing several people. The launch, which belonged to a French trading company, was a new one. It was proceeding up the Lahou River with a large quantity of gunpowder at the time. At a place called Tierre Nolri a man swam off to the launch. He was recognised as a Senegalese soldier and a deserter from a French expedition which went into the interior from Lahou a long time ago. In the launch were a Frenchman, a black engineer, and over twenty Native labourers. The labourers were all in the front part of the launch. The Senegalese was made a prisoner and secured in the hold of the craft, where were stowed about fifteen small barrels of gunpowder, it being the intention to hand the Senegalese over to the French authorities immediately the launch arrived at Lahou. The vessel had just anchored off the beach there when the engineer saw the prisoner go to the fire and take a piece of burning fuel, and throw it in one of the kegs of powder. The engineer at once ran to the stern, where the Frenchman was seated, steering, but before he reached it there was a terrific explosion, the forepart of the ship having blown up. The bodies of the Natives in the bow of the steamer were frightfully mutilated. Of the occupants of the launch only two escaped besides the Frenchman and the engineer. It was believed that in all about twenty persons perished."}, {'id': 6827, 'article_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS', 'full_section_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-0', 'issue_date': '05_04_1897', 'content': 'MESSRS. ELDER, DEMPSTER, & Co.'s mail steamer Gaboon arrived at Liverpool from the West Coast of Africa and the Canary Islands on March 10. The Gaboon left Sinoe, in the Liberian territory, on Feb. 6, and brought as passengers from that place to Grand Bassa Senator Green and Mrs. Green, who had to take advantage of the English steamer to flee from the violence of the Liberian troops. The latter had been on an expedition up country against some interior Natives who were stopping trade. They had only been away two days, but during that time they burned nine native towns. The king of the chief town was said to have been killed by the Liberians. On the side of the latter one man was wounded. Senator Green, who is also a trader and resides at Sinoe, was said to be opposed to the despatch of the expedition. When the troops, who appeared to be a very irregular rabble, returned to Sinoe, many of them assembled before the Senator's house, and, flushed with the victory, threatened to "chop" Mr. Green if they once laid hands on him. One of the crew of the Gaboon appeared with Mr. Green on the balcony of his house, and, although the soldiers did not fire at Mr. Green, they continued to threaten his life. At a favourable moment Mr. Green and his wife left with the Englishman, and boarded the Gaboon, landing at the next Liberian port, Grand Bassa. It is understood that Mr. Green intended to bring the shameful conduct of the troops under the notice of his Government. Particulars of a terrific explosion of gunpowder were received at Grand Bassa, the capital of the French Ivory Coast, just before the Gaboon left there on Feb. 1. The explosion occurred at a town thirty-five miles from Grand Bassa, and the shock was felt distinctly at the latter place. Every factory and house in the town in question was destroyed. In the first instance a fire broke out at one of the factories. It could not be subdued, and as it was known that there was a large quantity of gunpowder in the store the people were warned, and all deserted the town. Then there was a terrific explosion, followed by a second explosion of gunpowder in another factory. Altogether it was estimated that 1,000 kegs of gunpowder were blown up. Of the factories destroyed some belonged to two French firms and the others to Messrs. F. & A. Swanzy, of London. Several people were injured.

Chief Nana, who is now a prisoner at Accra, on hearing that Consul-General Moor, of the Niger Coast Protectorate, was returning to the coast, has sent the latter the following letter. It should be explained that festivities held by kings on the coast are called "Big Play." Hence the term used in his letter by Nana in relation to the Queen's Diamond Jubilee. It is only about four months ago that Nana, his wife and two sons, were removed from Old Calabar to Accra. Nana cannot write and had to sign with his mark:—

"Accra, Jan. 7, 1897.

"To Ralph Moor, Esq., Consul-General, Niger Coast Protectorate.'}]
