[{'document_title': 'Disastrous Explosion in the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': '### DISASTROUS EXPLOSION IN THE CONGO STATE.

A **terrible** explosion, which caused the loss of fifty or more lives, lately occurred on the railway which runs from Matadi, on the Congo. This is the second event of the kind which has happened within a very brief period, though in the previous case the loss of life was very much less. Particulars of the catastrophe have reached Liverpool, from which it appears that a train travelling from Emposi to Matadi with a number of Europeans and Natives in it collided with a waggon containing fifty-four boxes of dynamite and eighty-two barrels of gunpowder, which was to have been attached to the rear part of the train. A fearful explosion followed. The report was heard down at Matadi, and for many miles along the banks of the river. The car with the explosives had disappeared, and in its place was a huge excavation like a ravine, the rails of the line being twisted into all shapes. The engine itself was turned completely round and destroyed, while piled on top of it were the carriages containing most of the passengers. The officials from Matadi, hearing the terrific noise and guessing its cause, made all speed to the spot. The British & African Steam Navigation steamer Lualaba was also lying at Matadi, and Captain Murray with his officers and the ship’s doctor, hastened to the scene of the catastrophe. The only doctor of the place was in the train, and he was seriously injured. The surgeon of the British steamer rendered all assistance in his power, and the wounded and the dying were carried to a temporary hospital. Three of the white officials were killed outright, whilst a fourth—M. Legene, the head of the Société Anonyme Belge—succumbed to his injuries on the following day. From the bodies and the portions of the human remains collected after the disaster it was computed that about twenty blacks and four whites had been killed by the explosion, but on a count being made next day twenty-six others were missing, and it is feared that these had been hurled into the Congo and been carried away. The people of Matadi were most thankful for the efforts of the English crew, the doctor of the steamer being particularly energetic in rendering medical aid to the sufferers. The bodies were buried in the little cemetery at Matadi; but for the most part they were quite unrecognisable.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1893#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Recent Robbery of Gunpowder from the Lagos Powder Magazine', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—I shall feel obliged by your stating in the African Times that the opinion here is that it was owing to the carelessness and negligence of the Assistant-Collector and Treasurer of Lagos, whose business it was, as head of that department, to have a monthly inspection of the accounts and stock of the Magazine, that gunpowder to a considerable amount was recently stolen and carried away from the magazine; that had the Collector exercised due vigilance in the execution of his duty, such extensive robbery, which seems to have been carried on for months together, could certainly have been prevented. It is also stated here that even when a subordinate officer pointed out officially, on two different occasions, the very unsafe condition of the locks of the Magazine, no steps whatever were taken by the Assistant-Collector either to change the locks or report the matter to the authorities.

Should such amount of culpability really lie at the Collector's door, we trust the authorities here will never think of recommending, nor Lord Carnarvon sanction, that the colony be burdened with the payment of nearly 400l., the value of the said gunpowder (an actual waste of money at a time when the Government is greatly in need of a considerable sum for the erection of public buildings), but that the Assistant-Collector and Treasurer be held liable for the same; a course usually adopted with officers in similar cases, in order to impress them with the fact of their responsibility.

Many instances are given us to indicate that the present state of affairs in the Assistant-Collector's department is most deplorable, but we will only give two out of those we have by us.

1. In the days of previous Collectors, the salary of clerk in charge of the Magazine was 100l. per annum; and this officer was called upon to give two sureties of 125l. each for the faithful performance of his duties. But, for no reasons whatever that we can understand, the present Collector, in framing the estimates for 1876, at the time he performed the duties of Assistant Colonial Secretary in conjunction with the duties of his own office, reduced the salary from 100l. to 50l. per annum—an amount which was afterwards found too inadequate to retain the services of a trustworthy officer; and, at the appointment of the clerk in whose time the gunpowder was robbed, the Assistant-Collector failed to call upon that officer to execute the usual bond; we can only suppose because he felt himself not justified in doing so under such a reduced rate of salary. Thus one error led to another.", 'last_edit_date': '1877-06-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1877#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.626, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ARMS IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In a recent letter to The Times, Mr. H. M. Stanley draws an important deduction from the report of recent fighting between the forces of the Congo State and the slave-traders. First he calls to mind the provisions of Article X of the General Act of the Brussels Conference, which stated that Governments exercising rights of sovereignty in Africa should do their utmost to prevent the exit or entry of fire-arms by their inland frontiers, or their passage to regions where the slave-trade is rife. Next from his own knowledge he remarks upon "the extravagant waste of ammunition in the slave-traders' camps" and then asks how it is that these same slave-traders, who "for the last three years have been blazing away as though they possessed exhaustless supplies of gunpowder" could still be so well provided with ammunition as to be able to keep up a heavy fire for several hours upon the Congo State forces. Putting two and two together, the conclusion at which he arrives is that one of the three Governments—Great Britain, Germany, and Portugal—must, in defiance of Article X., have been conniving at the importation of these fire-arms and this ammunition. If this be so, it is easy to see that the march of civilisation in the Dark Continent must be very seriously impeded. Every Government, in fact, can, by winking at the behaviour of its own subjects, very seriously interfere with the well-being of the territories of the other Governments. Unfortunately, it is easier to state the conclusion than to suggest the remedy. England may be able to answer for her subjects, though, considering the difficulties of African administration, it would not be surprising if sometimes she failed to keep all the sheep in check; at any rate, she cannot control the subjects of Germany and Portugal. It is much to be feared that so long as the slave-traders have the commodities wherewith to pay for arms and ammunition there will be found unscrupulous Europeans ready to smuggle them.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1893#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Anti-Slavery Conference', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## THE ANTI-SLAVERY CONFERENCE.
(Concluded from page 101.)

**CHAPTER I.**, on the distribution of the work of the Conference, included a wide range of subjects summed up as measures for the repression of the land traffic—that is to say, for stopping the slave-trade at its starting-point. Most of these appear to be rather in the nature of rules for homogeneous action which each State undertakes to carry out to the best of its ability than in that of international engagements. But there is, however, one subject in this chapter which is of paramount importance—viz., the traffic in firearms.

Some idea of the importance of this question may be gathered from the fact that into Zanzibar alone some 80,000 to 100,000 muskets and rifles are imported annually. Firearms are bartered to Arab traders on the coast for ivory and other inland products, a large proportion of them being the disused rifles of present European standing armies. The object of the provisions of the Brussels Conference on this subject is to protect the negro against his Arab enemy and captor by disarming the latter.

The principle of preserving the native African races was inserted in the General Act of Berlin, by which “the Powers undertake to watch over the preservation of the native races and the improvement of their moral and material conditions.” There was, therefore, no question of principle to discuss. Nor was there any doubt as to interference with the traffic in firearms being indispensable. The difficulties lay in determining the extent to which this interference should be carried, so as to avoid any unnecessary interference with great trading interests and practical disarmament of those who need the arms for their own defence, and to take such measures as would leave no loopholes for the trade to be carried on by different channels.

There were several courses possible. It had to be decided whether the trade throughout Africa should be regulated, or whether the regulations should be confined to the affected district. And also whether the regulations should take the form of prohibition altogether, or be framed on lines of restriction with distinctions.

The French Government made a strong stand in favour of entire prohibition throughout Africa; but the view taken by the Governments of Great Britain, Holland, Germany, Portugal, and Italy was opposed to so radical a step, as going beyond the purpose of preserving the native races and as implying the needless sacrifice of a large mercantile interest without local justification. The Conference came ultimately to the same conclusion. The next question was to determine the area within which the importation of firearms was to be regulated. This zone is believed to extend from 20 degs. of north latitude to 22 degs. of south latitude, from coast to coast across the African Continent between these lines, as well as to 100 marine miles seawards.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.637, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Defenceless State of the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "To the Right Hon. Earl Kimberley, Secretary of State for the Colonies._

Apsley House, Bathurst, Dec. 12, 1870.

My Lord,—I have the honour to bring under your lordship's notice the utterly defenceless state of these settlements, and especially that of the town of Bathurst, the capital of the settlements, the seat of government, and residence of the merchants and principal inhabitants, and the depot for goods and produce of large money value.

Your lordship is aware the troops were withdrawn from here in May last, and although seven months have since elapsed, and one occasion has arisen in that time that a French gun-boat was called in for the protection of British interests in this river, yet no steps have been taken to afford these settlements any protection of any kind, beyond adding ten unarmed men to the police force.

We have not even had the chance visit of one of Her Majesty's ships of war, to give that moral support to an unarmed Government which such a visit is calculated to afford, and the wholesome check it exercises upon marauding chiefs and turbulent natives. On the withdrawal of the troops all arms and ammunition of every kind and description, except the heavy guns mounted on the batteries, were shipped to England, and valuable military stores sold by public auction at enormous sacrifices.

At the sitting of the Legislative Council here on the 3rd inst., I moved for a return of the arms and ammunition at the command of the Local Government. His Excellency Colonel Anton, the Acting Administrator, replied that on his assuming the government in September last he found 137 old smooth-bore muskets, in a disgraceful state of neglect, rusty, honeycombed, and totally unfit for use; that there are no other arms, not a rifle, revolver, rocket-gun, or field artillery, nor any ammunition of any kind, except the blank cartridges for firing the morning and evening gun, and these he had purchased from the commissariat. The Administrator added he had reported the state of the arms to his Excellency the Governor-in-Chief, but no action, so far as the colonists are aware, has been taken upon the subject, but probably your lordship is better informed.

There is no militia, nor has any attempt been made to enrol one, and indeed, without arms and ammunition, it would be a useless body. What, my lord, would be the position of this community in case of native invasion, or even a serious local disturbance?", 'last_edit_date': '1870-12-12', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1871#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AN INTERVIEW WITH MR. H. M. STANLEY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"There would constantly be an immense quantity of goods going up country by rail. At present, on the Upper Congo, Europeans have to content themselves with living in wattled huts or mud forts, roofed over with straw and grass, and there is, of course, great danger from fire. By means of the railway the State could at once transport about a dozen iron stations; and there would soon be erected houses, churches, and schools, all of iron. Then the native chiefs, seeing what the Europeans were doing, would build iron houses, and would likewise require iron warehouses for their goods. The Chief of Kintamo, for instance, already keeps all his goods in iron boxes; while the Chiefs of Old Calabar live in iron houses which have cost from £1,000 to £3,500 each. Then, again, there would be many steamers to be transported in sections, to be put together on the upper side of the cataracts. On the Upper Congo there are at present only seven steamers, mostly steam launches, but to carry on the enormous trade of the 7,000 miles of navigable waterway of the Upper Congo, large and swift steamers will be required, capable of stowing cargo and carrying passengers in comfort. Again, there would be a large trade in timber, and saw-mills would be required to cut it up, which mills would have to be taken up country by railway. Enormous quantities of powder and large numbers of flint-lock guns would also be in demand. All this is without counting the almost limitless trade to be done in cloth goods. I should say that within a reasonable number of years after the making of the railway there would be a trade of about £10,000,000 annually with the natives of the Upper Congo—all in barter."

Pausing here, Mr. Stanley went on to say that there was a sentimental side to the whole question which was worthy of reflection. "We have been enabled," he continued, "with our own modest enterprise to secure something like 1,000 carriers a month to serve us in a country that, when I began work there, absolutely refused to have anything to do with us. Already we have some 400 native soldiers—all of which proves that the natives are friendly and willing to lend their services to the white man for his purposes. When the State can better afford it—which will be not long after the railway is finished—it will be able to enlist 3,000 or 4,000 native soldiers for the protection of the country against the slave-traders. Those stations which are to-day so modest and unoffending, and dare not take arms in their hands against the organized slave-traders, will, in a few months only after the opening of the railway, be in a position to take the offensive and absolutely prevent them from ever setting foot in the Congo State."

"That indeed would be worth working for," I remarked.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1886#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The two very destructive fires of the 12th December and 2nd January have wrought such havoc in this place, that we have scarcely had time to think of anything else but the losses they have occasioned, and the means to be adopted for preventing the recurrence of such disasters. The first was caused by some native frying fish in the street; a neighbouring hut ignited, the dry Harmattan wind was blowing, everything in the place was dry as tinder, and the flames spread with such violence and rapidity, that within half-an-hour they had cleared of all buildings an immense quantity of ground. The fire rolled along—a body of flame of about thirty feet in height—and everything within reach of its hot breath was destroyed. One or two merchants' stores caught, and their contents were, of course, soon lost to the owners. There was a quantity of palm oil in one of them,", 'last_edit_date': '1863-01-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have had a bad fire here again among the native dwellings. In about two hours 500 of these were consumed, as also the Mohammedan mosque and a small Christian place of worship. The agent protested against this interference, as the same kind of guns had been imported and sold by him for some time past, and the action of the Congo Free State authorities was, therefore, beyond comprehension. The head of the State, Sir Francis de Winton, was absent from Banana at the time, but on his return he confirmed the action of Major Parminter, and subsequently issued a notice prohibiting the sale of percussion guns and ammunition in the Congo State. Meantime the Portuguese on the opposite side of the river permit the free sale of the same articles. Mr. Stanley appears to consider that this prohibition had been issued in error. It is said that no offer of compensation has been made to the traders for the loss they will sustain if the restriction remains in force. In the case of the British Government putting a similar order in operation during the Zulu war without due notice, compensation was allowed for the loss entailed. The English merchants supported the claims of the Congo Free State at the Berlin Conference, believing that their operations would not be hampered by unwise restrictions. It is therefore said that this last act, which is so contrary to the unrestricted freedom which Mr. Stanley spoke about when decrying the Anglo-Portuguese Treaty, will not tend to increase the friendly feelings of the merchants towards it. Later advice shows that the order which has been issued formally prohibiting the sale of the guns and ammunition imposes a penalty of £1,000 for any breach of the regulations. It is, however, looked upon as absurd to suppose that the order in question will prevent the guns gaining admission to the territory of the State, as the Portuguese allow unrestricted sale of the same articles on the opposite side of the river, and the natives can easily carry them across in their canoes. It may be mentioned that these percussion guns are ordinary trade muskets, converted into flint locks, and are not in any sense rifles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Troubles in Liberia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Royal Mail steamship Benin, which arrived in England from the West Coast of Africa on Nov. 13, reports a similar incident on her passage along the coast with mails and passengers on board. She called as usual at the Liberian port of Cape Palmas, and anchored a short distance from the two Liberian gunboats Rocktown and Gonorammah. A few minutes afterwards, Captain Keene, of the Benin, perceived flag signals displayed from the gunboats, which he understood to convey the order that he was not to communicate with the shore. Since the Benin had anchored no passengers had come out from either Rocktown or Cape Palmas, two ports about two miles apart, but a number of Krooboys, who were out in fishing and other canoes, boarded the mail steamer. However, in view of the orders flying from the Rocktown prohibiting communication with the shore, the Benin hove up anchor and put out to sea. As she was doing this a shot was sent from the Liberian gunboat, which struck the water a short distance from the Benin. Captain Keene did not think it wise to stay longer, but continued on his course, deciding to protest on his arrival home. The cause of the firing was not known by Captain Keene. If it was in any way connected with the Natives who boarded the Benin from the canoes, surely the gunboats should have stationed themselves off Rocktown or Cape Palmas and prevented the men leaving the shore before the Benin came up. Captain Keene takes the view that the Liberians made a mistake; but this is by no means the first time that a mistake of the kind has been committed by the Liberian gunboats, and it is felt that the risks run by the steamers through these recurring mistakes are too great to be tolerated. It is hoped that the British Government will interfere, for, failing this, it is thought possible that a gunboat may, by mistake, fire and sink a British vessel, in which case the matter would not be so easy of adjustment.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1896#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.627, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sanitariums for West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'M'Carthy's Island, River Gambia, Dec. 20, 1864.

My Lord,—In the editorial article in the Lancet of October 13, page 442, we find the remark that "it is a singular fact in medical geography that from St. Louis, Senegal, on the north, to Mossamedes, on the south, there is not upon the seaboard a single healthy acre of ground. The whole western side of that vast continent (Africa) is one hotbed of disease."

It is well known that in all diseases the great restorative agent is pure air, and this is obtained on lofty ranges, along the seacoast, or elsewhere, inaccessible to the influence of malaria. This fact has been established in India beyond all doubt, and extensively acted upon, irrespective of expense, it being known that life is sure to be saved by it. In the West Indies the same sanitary measure has been taken, in the formation of a camp, at a

New Castle, the attitude of which defies the approach of the most pestilential lithoral poison.

But it appears that, until lately, there has been scarcely any knowledge amongst Englishmen that the West Coast of Africa is garrisoned by British soldiers, whose lives are as precious as any other soldiers, and who go heartily to fight for their sovereign against, not only barbarous tribes, but also against the pestiferous, ghastly miasma that poisons the atmosphere of many parts of this Coast. This was abundantly proved in the late disastrous expedition against the King of Ashantee, where men and officers died without number, and without even seeing an enemy. There has been a great neglect respecting the requirements of the West Coast of Africa, and even a simple account of the Coast, in these enlightened days, is received with the same wonder and surprise as the adventures of Mungo Park and Robinson Crusoe. So little, indeed, is known of it, that in print, in public speeches, and in private conversation, it is termed the most unhealthy region in the world; yet still if one takes the percentage of deaths amongst the different stations of the British Army, irrespective of the great sanitary measures used by the Government, it will be found that many of them were by far more unhealthy than the West Coast of Africa. The African Times has always endeavoured to point this out; and as a proof of it, I may state that some time ago, so great and so frequent was the amount of havoc committed on the soldiers quartered in one of the West Indian Islands by disease, that all but one officer were laid hors de combat, so that the troops were entirely withdrawn, and a notice was sent to the colonial authorities that, should they intend to keep the island, they were to increase their police force.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-12-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.631, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial governance in Cape Coast, exemplified by the efforts of Lieutenant-Governor Hackett and Governor Strahan, significantly altered local infrastructure and health policies by imposing European sanitation standards, often disregarding local customs and needs.
result: The claim that colonial governance in Cape Coast, exemplified by the efforts of Lieutenant-Governor Hackett and Governor Strahan, significantly altered local infrastructure and health policies by imposing European sanitation standards, often disregarding local customs and needs, is addressed with varying perspectives in the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook provides a broader context of colonial governance's impact on local infrastructure and health policies, noting the introduction of sanitary measures in regions like North Africa and the Gold Coast, primarily to protect European populations, which likely affected indigenous communities. It also discusses the imposition of European bureaucratic structures and manipulation of local chiefs, suggesting a disregard for local customs, though it does not specifically mention Hackett and Strahan's actions in Cape Coast. In contrast, The African Times articles offer specific details about Hackett and Strahan's efforts, such as closing an old burial ground, opening a new one, and implementing street cleaning and dust-bin systems, which align with the claim of imposing European sanitation standards. However, the articles also highlight the disregard for local customs, evidenced by forced house removals without compensation and new burial practices, alongside criticism of colonial neglect and ineffective sanitary measures. This suggests that the changes were not as significant or consistent as the claim implies. Additionally, the articles note local resistance and discontent, indicating that the imposition of European standards was not universally accepted or beneficial. Together, these sources provide a nuanced view that both supports and challenges the claim, underscoring the complexities of colonial governance and its impact on local infrastructure and health policies.

It is now impossible to contemplate a significant change in any one of these boundary lines without a major upheaval. Events in the Horn of Africa are beginning to suggest that these imaginary lines on the map of Africa are eternal.

Simensen has concluded, 'this Charter is probably the most detailed documentation that we have from the early period of colonial rule in the Gold Coast of an attempt by commoners to curtail the authority of the traditional elite and assert their own influence more effectively in the fields of jurisdiction and legislation.' 19 The second method adopted by the commoners of the rural areas was the destoolment (deposition) of their traditional rulers, and this became quite a common feature of rural politics in the Gold Coast in the inter-war period.
