But things are sadly changed. This same Government School, which is the only school, except the Wesleyan Missionary\'s, on the Gold Coast, *is now a playhouse.* It has pleased his Excellency the Administrator to introduce discharged soldiers (such as Brown and E. Bayne) into this school as schoolmasters. The latter, who is the present schoolmaster, is undeniably ignorant of the English language; he really speaks no other language but Oquoo. For instance: asking a boy for his book, he says, "Were nar book," &c. I am at a loss to imagine the reason why Colonel Conran could place such persons in this school as schoolmasters (whether from motives of favoritism or benignity), the pupils in which (from the previous instructions given them by a European schoolmaster, John Burns, who was really capable of imparting instruction) are indubitably smart. These boys are now suffering under the hand of the unqualified master, Bayne—a man dull of apprehension, who, fearing his scholars will shame him if he continues them in the school, threatens them with expulsion. His assistants were once astounded to find him arguing with a boy as regards the word *efface.* When the boy used this word, he told him that he never heard it before, and that it is not an English word, and continued arguing till the boy proved the existence of the word by an English dictionary. This may be all very well, but I cannot refrain from telling Colonel Conran through you, as well as the Superintendent, the Rev. Mr. Blake, that it would have been better had his Excellency practically reflected on the orders given from home in matters of education generally, and not become the antagonist of civilians and collegians, who seem to be all especially odious to him.—I am, yours faithfully,', 'last_edit_date': '1866-12-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_12_1866#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When writing last month on the all-important subject of the future spread of Christian civilization in West Africa, we pointed out that educated natives, more or less under the influence of Christian faith, more or less imbued with Christian principles, more or less governed by Christian precepts, are and will be indispensable as a vanguard of the great army of civilization that must be projected upon the ignorant barbarism of heathen Africa whenever the means for such projection shall be arranged. We go further than this, and equally maintain that not only the vanguard of the army of civilization must necessarily consist of educated Africans, but that the army itself must be chiefly composed of them. With this conviction rooted in our mind, the question of education in West Africa has for many years past greatly occupied our attention. The end in view being so great, and of so vast importance primarily to Africa, and secondarily to the whole civilized world, it is natural we should have asked ourself whether the means of education at present employed are adequate for the purpose; and if not, how and by whom those means are to be made so. We have already adverted to the unselfish efforts of the religious societies of Great Britain (and in the case of Liberia, of those of the United States of America) in diffusing among the natives the great blessing of education. The efforts of the Missionary Societies, and more especially of the Church Missionary Society, have been unremitting and gradually increasing in scope and efficiency, until they would seem at last to have culminated in the affiliation of their Fomah Bay College at Sierra Leone to the University of Durham, whereby degrees may be obtained by Africans who have never left their native land. By these efforts of Missionary Societies, the Church of England and the Wesleyan Methodist, all who can boast of any degree of education in West Africa have been rescued from heathen ignorance, and prepared more or less, for civilized usefulness. It was, perhaps, well and unavoidable, though we are far from saying or thinking that it was so, that so all-important a work, if Africa is ever to be rescued from heathen degradation, should have been hitherto left in the hands of the Missionary Societies. But that it ought any longer to be so left, we most emphatically deny. Under those noble efforts of the Missionary Societies, combined with constantly increasing facilities for commerce which steam navigation has supplied, the condition of the British settlements has undergone so great a change, that a continued dependence on missionary effort for the education of the people will, if persisted in, be a gross injustice and disgrace on the part of the British Government. This is so patent that we feel convinced it is only necessary the subject should be urged upon their attention to induce such action on their part as shall wipe away the reproach that now justly attaches to them, and relieve the Missionary Societies from a charge to which their funds, so urgently required for the propagation of Christian truth in other localities in the great heathen world, ought not to be any longer subject. Education ought to be now organized and diffused in and from the British settlements by and at the charge of the local revenues. The inadequacy of means, which as regards the Gold Coast, for instance, might have been pleaded some ten or twelve years ago, when the public revenue there did not exceed annually the sum of seven or eight thousand pounds, can no longer be urged now that the revenue has attained the comparatively magnificent amount of one hundred thousand pounds a year. A similar comparative increase has been experienced at Lagos; and if the revenues of Sierra Leone and the Gambia have not advanced in the same ratio, they are still sufficient, if properly administered, to meet the great and urgent want of public education, under the organization and auspices of the State. A State education is what we now claim for West Africa, and in especial for the Gold Coast and Lagos. A systematic and adequate commencement of it ought not to be any longer delayed. A Liberal Government in Great Britain cannot surely any longer deny to the people of West Africa that of which they have been such earnest promoters, both individually and collectively, at home. It can scarcely be necessary to remind the Earl of Kimberley that, as Crown Colonies, those settlements are altogether dependent upon an initiative from Downing-street; that themselves, the people, even if they felt the need, can do nothing; that the expenditure of the public revenue is entirely at the command of the Secretary of State for the Colonies; and that it now rests with him either to aid in or retard the Christian civilization of West Africa, which cannot progress without a more general diffusion of education than can or ought to be expected from the Missionary Societies of Great Britain. While, however, we are prepared to maintain that it is now the duty of Government to undertake the work of the education of the people, both elementary and higher, in all the West African settlements, we shall confine ourselves more especially at this time to the claims and needs of the Gold Coast and Lagos. The influence that may be diffused from these British settlements in the great work of the civilization of Africa would be immense, and justly entitles them to our especial consideration as regards public education in West Africa. It is from Lagos that the work of civilization must proceed to the moral conquest of the whole of those extensive territories that are bounded by the River Niger, and of that blood-stained kingdom of Dahomey, whose sanguinary customs continue, though of late but little spoken of, to outrage humanity, and exhibit the worst features of ignorant heathen barbarism. In considering the question of State education in Lagos, it is incumbent on the British Government to take into consideration that the public revenue of that portion of the Gold Coast Colony is derived entirely from traffic in the produce of those interior countries; that the spread of civilization increases production; and that therefore, while on the one hand it is imperatively their duty, it is not less their interest, as rulers of this Crown settlement, to devote a portion of that revenue to constitute Lagos a focus of light from Britain, to be diffused throughout the Egba and Yoruba countries, and the territories of their unquiet neighbour, Dahomey. The presence of Great Britain on the coasts of these countries of West Africa, after her own renunciation and denunciation of the infamous and horrible foreign slave-trade, was justified by her presence there being absolutely necessary for securing the final annihilation of that traffic, and remedying in some degree, by the security she gave and the repression she exercised, the fearful results that had been produced there by it, and the outrages on humanity perpetrated at the behests of sanguinary superstitions, which had been made through successive ages its active agents and accomplices. Under her ægis a new condition of things has gradually arisen; and although—such is the tenacity of evil—her presence could not even yet be dispensed with as regards the repression of slave-trading propensities, this repression ought now to be regarded as a secondary, and the spread of civilization the primary, justification of her continued rule. Those who have known this journal during the past twenty years cannot need to be reminded that we have ever laid it down as an axiom that a basis of British power on the Coast is indispensable to the success of missionary enterprise and the progress of civilization in Africa. The natives have become so debased by superstition during ages upon ages of heathen darkness, that they are incapable of believing in anything that does not come to them accompanied by evidences of power. They have such evidence at Lagos; they have it within the mainland territories of the Gold Coast Colony. That evidence will suffice to insure the gradual acceptance of civilization when once the interior populations, as well as those in the Coast towns,', 'last_edit_date': '1880-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1880#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I consider that, as far as may be expected of Missionary Societies, they have been liberal in their efforts to educate the people in some parts of the Coast, and particularly in Sierra Leone, where, besides the Missionary Colleges of the Church Missionary Society and the Wesleyan Missionary Society, the former has had a public Grammar School since 1845, and a Female Institution which is nearly as old, if not older, and training masters from England. The Government is indebted to them for the measure of educated native intelligence which it brings into requisition in its service. These Societies have shown that Africans are capable of any degree of improvement, and created a thirst for learning which the people are now anxious to have satisfied.\n\nI am not aware that their general educational work was subsidized by Government all the while they were at it; and it was hardly to be expected that the people themselves, mostly poor liberated slaves, could have contributed much for its support. The Government holds a position on the Gold Coast; this position is enhanced, and its responsibility increased, by the Act which has recently liberated hundreds of thousands of slaves from bondage, or at least placed them on the way to claim their freedom. Untold blessings to the Coast and the interior of Africa will, I expect, result from it if the efforts to discharge duties and responsibilities are of the right kind, and are properly directed. It is the duty, and will be to the honour of the Government to seek to liberate from slavery the minds of those whose bodies only have been made free. They are yet the slaves of ignorance, superstition, and folly, and can and will do no credit either to themselves or to the Power that has given them the status of freed men if they are left to continue uneducated; nor will they be ever qualified for a proper and wholesome use of the position they enjoy, and the power placed in their hands; and by how much the mind is superior to the body, by so much is the slavery of the mind worse than that of the body. Besides these freed slaves, there is a very large originally free but poor population, who cannot provide schools for their children. The establishment of elementary schools over the whole Protectorate, and the power to read and write in their own language and in others acquired by the people, would be the beginning of their greatness.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.606, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Native Letters from the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Some of your contemporaries have undoubtedly got hold of the bull by the wrong horn—have as undoubtedly read the history of the Gold Coast and of Ashanti, such as is known, with prejudiced and perverted minds, and have consequently treated the public with résumés, précis, and such like articles, from their point of view; and their correspondents, as a rule, have dealt in like manner with the history of these regions, and the position held here by you.\n\nWe will not discuss how you came to assume, nor by what means you assumed, the protectorate of the tribes inhabiting the Gold Coast; it suffices that you have assumed and exercised such a protectorate, and accepted the responsibilities consequent thereon. You have levied taxes, imposed duties, and governed us in every sense as you do your Crown colonies and other dependencies. You make and unmake kings and chiefs; you treat with Ashanti without consulting the kings and chiefs over whom you have assumed such a protectorate; you have divested them of all power and authority over their subjects, and over even their own domestics; you fine and imprison them as you think fit; you legislate for them, make laws, pass ordinances, bills, &c., without consulting them; and by your fiat, can make them vassals to a foreign power, without their being taken into your deliberations. All this, and more, you do; and when, through your thirst for extension of territory and lust for empire—when, through the blundering of your officials, and their crass ignorance and mismanagement, you find yourself launched into a war, you begin execrating us poor fellows, who had no hand in bringing this war about, and talk of giving over a portion of our territory to appease his Majesty of Ashanti, just as though the Gold Coast were British territory, and not merely British protectorate territory, and could be given out in plots, "regardless of what might be thought of it by the Fantees, who seem to be of no use to us or to themselves."\n\nThe writer of these words shows throughout his article a pitiable ignorance of the question he is discussing. He speaks of the Fantees as "a hostile tribe, over whom we have assumed a protectorate, and who have, in the confidence of that protection, given offence to the Ashantees;" and that we "shut out the Ashantees from the Coast at our pleasure;" talks of our "speculating on your assistance to bar the Ashantees from the sea;" of our shielding an Ashantee chief, and thus enabling him to flaunt successful rebellion in the face of the king; and about the treaty of 1831, which he says the Fantees have violated, together with observations of a like nature,—in a strain which exhibits imperfect knowledge of his subject-matter. But he is not alone, as there are others who have written on the Chamah and Tacorady disasters as though the recently-ceded Dutch tribes, and those who inhabit Fanti proper, and those formerly under the English, are one and the same people.*', 'last_edit_date': '1873-10-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The old leaven seems to be strong in Sierra Leone. The Local Government believe more in police and gaols than in the purifying and ameliorating influences of religious education. We say “religious education,” because all education for a long time to come must embrace the religious element, since all the teachers capable of imparting instruction have been educated by one or other of our great Missionary Societies. And well for Africa that it must do so; for education merely secular—education without any attempt to impart with it the restraining influences of Christianity—would curse at least as much as it would bless. Among older communities, the control of public opinion, the existence of a higher moral standard, the general outward profession of religion, may—we do not say they will, but they may—prevent mere secular instruction in schools, to the exclusion of the religious element, from producing those pernicious results which would otherwise most certainly accrue. But in West Africa, among people but lately redeemed from barbarism, and surrounded by a heathen population debased by the most loathsome superstitions and most revolting practices, the results of mere secular education could not be other than deplorable. The old leaven, we have said, still works strongly among the members of the Local Government. The account given on our second page affords sufficient evidence of this. We are glad to have been furnished by it with this opportunity of bringing so important a matter under the notice of Her Majesty’s Secretary of State for the Colonies, whom we know to be especially desirous of extending the ameliorating influences of education among the people of West Africa. We must confess that the contents of the letter to which we have above alluded surprised as much as they have pained us. We had carefully watched the action of the Home Government in the mission of Mr. Laurie and his successor, whose loss seems to be so very justly deplored; and as another Inspector of Schools had been appointed, and there was an annual vote for his services and for the payment of grants-in-aid, it was not possible for us to suppose that a matter in which the Home Government had manifested so deep an interest could be so cruelly neglected. It was beyond our mental reach to imagine a regularly-salaried Inspector of Schools, and no inspection. That such an anomaly should have been permitted is disgraceful to the Local Government, and, we feel convinced, will bring down upon them that rebuke from the Earl of Carnarvon which their conduct deserves. The defrauded schoolmasters, for such indeed they are, have our warmest sympathy; and we thank them for having enabled us to bring the history of their wrongs, and the wrongs of their pupils (for these must necessarily suffer if the schoolmasters are not properly paid) under the notice of the authority which has power to redress their grievances.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ASHANTEE SCHEMES.—TRIBES IN DANGER.—CRUEL GOVERNMENT MISTAKES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—As one of your old correspondents, I do not suppose it to be intrusion to call your attention once more to the subject of my letter to you last year, dated on the 23rd July, 1875. Some subjects may be thought imperatively demanding notice of the officials by your correspondents, but expediency may guide you to lay them aside for a time. Now, I do not know whether the exposition of the following incidents would have any effect to that letter being now noticed.\n\nI wrote you on the 23rd July, 1875, relative to the policy of this Government with relation to Ashanti. The subsequent fate of Juabin, bearing on the indefatigable efforts of Christian England for the civilization of tribes in these regions, and the policy of the local Government of the Gold Coast, present mysterious phenomena to the lookers-on in this country. These are led to think of one building a mud-wall in the rainy season without the precaution of having it covered when it does rain.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.611, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Local Government of Sierra Leone and the Subsidized Schools', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—We, being managers of schools in the colony of Sierra Leone, and representing the general body of school managers, desire to address your Excellency on the subject of the continued withholding of the grants-in-aid allowed by the Government, and to make mention of one or two other matters immediately connected therewith.\n\nYour Excellency will have in remembrance that a few of us had the honour of waiting upon you, a year ago, to solicit that the full amount of grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874, might be paid; the managers having only received that portion of it which was due on account of the average attendance of scholars, and nothing whatever on account of subjects.\n\nThat meeting resulted in a letter from the Bishop to Earl Carnarvon, which was followed up by a despatch from the Colonial Office, referring it for the report of the Lieutenant-Governor; since which nothing has been heard by us of the subject, either from the Colonial Office or from the local Government. Neither have the managers received any grants-in-aid, nor any portion of any grant which has since become due; so that at the present time there are as many as five half-years of grants, in whole or in part, unsettled for and unpaid.\n\nThere are the greater portions of the grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874; and there are the entire grants for the three half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1875, and April 30, 1876.\n\nThe particulars in regard to the grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874, are so plainly stated in the letter of July 24, 1875, from the Bishop to Lord Carnarvon, that we cannot do better than refer your Excellency to that letter, a copy of which accompanied Lord Carnarvon's despatch.\n\nFor the half-year next following November 1, 1874—April 30, 1875—the schools were only inspected and reported on by the Director of Public Instruction; and a few weeks ago we received notes, informing us that the grant for this half-year would be paid; but though it has been applied for through the usual medium, it has not yet been paid.\n\nFor the half-year, May 1—October 31, a few of the schools were inspected at the usual time, and the inspection has since been completed, but the grant has not been paid.\n\nWe need not speak further of the grant for the half-year recently closed, as it is at present all in good time to look for its payment.\n\nWe desire to express to your Excellency how much we are inconvenienced by this withholding of the grants, and how almost impossible we find it to carry on our schools whilst this support from the Government is withheld. The schoolmasters, to whom one-third of the grants is due, are also feeling exceedingly, being deprived of that portion of their salaries.", 'last_edit_date': '1876-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1876#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.608, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Popular Institutions that Ought to be Established in Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—There is an evil practice which is growing every year more and more injurious to the healthy growth of the young inhabitants of the colony, and which, in former years, by proper training, had disappeared; I mean the forcing of their intellect at the expense of their muscular development. In visiting some of the day-schools the other day, I observed that a great many infants, some three or four years, who should be in the open air playing and strengthening themselves, confined to the school-rooms for hours, learning their "A B C," or their "Ba," &c.\n\nThis is wrong in principle; for however desirable this might be for grown-up lads, it is highly injurious to infants.\n\nI have often seen lads about ten or twelve years of age, who show a great precocity in learning, kept for seven hours daily at school. True it is that he can read his Latin delectus well, can go through the first two books of Euclid, and papa looks at him with pride, and says to his visitors, "Tom will make a great man. Jack is a dunce; but Tom masters everything in a minute." Mammas, with dignified pride, says, "Let him read a passage from Horace or Virgil for you to hear"; and the little chap goes through with ease the first chapter in the Æneidos or Georgicon, with as literal a translation as one could like to hear. Papa draws him by his side, and presses him to his heart, and says, "Mon bon garçon."\n\nNow this little fellow is kept away from youthful play and exercise; his knowledge surpasses his physical frame, and he is petted to the extreme. At the age of sixteen he is cleverer than his grandfather, and, perhaps, than all his brothers; but examine him closely; you will find that this fancy exotic, whose intellectual education has been fostered at the expense of his physical development, gives promise of a short-lived, miserable man, who engages the attention and anxiety of the rest of the family. The clever Tom falls far short of the promise he gave in his youth; too true that he still shows a well-fructified mind, but this is an unhappy tenant of a wasted frame.\n\nHow many of our people here ought to learn to appreciate good early training of their children; but I find that the more they are growing in wealth, the more puny, wasted, and weak their offspring are becoming. Our female population believe that it is rude for little boys to play and jump about in the gardens and streets; and as for little girls doing such things, it is not to be heard of. A boy is a greater favourite if he sits down all day with his books in his hand, and will not have himself disturbed by his more playful companions; you will hear Mamma say, "I like him, he is a very good and quiet boy; but Jack is the wildest boy in creation; I don\'t know what to do with him; he is too wild [meaning playful], and I am unable to govern him; I don\'t like him at all."', 'last_edit_date': '1866-02-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1866#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.607, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Late Dr. Livingstone', 'section_title': '', 'content': "...tire though tardy measures were taken to stay the further progress of invasion. The results produced by a first lesson as to the danger of approaching British troops armed with the awfully effective weapons which science has now devised for mutual destruction amongst civilized nations, were improved so soon as an unusually protracted wet season would permit, by offensive movements against the Ashanti enemy, which eventuated in the abandonment of the Protectorate by a miserable remnant of the host which, but a few short months before, had overrun it in ruthless pride. The elements had fought against the invaders, as well as against the homeless masses whose habitations and food supplies they had destroyed. Small-pox of a most infectious type, dysentery, and fever had caused the deaths of above twenty thousand Ashantees. And now the white men, whose look was death, were upon them; and all who had strength to reach the Prah and cross it, did so. This deliverance of the Protectorate was thus accomplished without the Ashantees being really brought into hostile contact with more than some five or six hundred Europeans. But this deliverance was accompanied also by other agencies calculated to produce future good results. Public attention in England was in some small degree directed to those countries, the mere name of which was all that was generally known about them. A small but effective British force was to be sent out from England; a force consisting of some of our most renowned regiments. The daily and the pictorial press must necessarily be represented in the expedition by men of tried ability, who should furnish to the British public detailed accounts of all they should see and hear. By their aid, the Gold Coast countries have had withdrawn from them that veil of ignorance which had hitherto concealed them and their people from the knowledge of the civilized world. True, the reports have not been such as to create any impressions favourable to the Fanti people. It is not our intention here to show (as we intend sooner or later to do) that many of the conclusions of an unfavourable nature, seemingly justified by daily events, were not altogether correct. The change lately recorded in their favour, as regards the Transport Service, since that service has been properly organized, and the men have been looked upon as human beings, and not as mere beasts of burden, has in part removed the odium. But whatever the opinion entertained respecting them, they cannot any more be relegated to the indifference hitherto entertained. Their deliverance from the Ashantee enemy will have cost Great Britain, it may be, one million sterling. The British nation knows as a nation the condition of people in sea-coast towns where the British flag has waved in supremacy for half a century; and the British commerce will not any longer permit people and country over which that flag thus floats, to remain in that state of barbarian filth and at a donment which has up to the present time prevailed. Now, this is a good and a great good, which would not have been effected had the King of Askim been so supported in the first instance, and the united Fantee tribes later, as to have enabled them to clear the country of the invader, without the intervention of a real British force. The British Government will be compelled to one of two courses. Either it must abandon those countries, which will be the signal for their being taken possession of by some other European power, to our great and indelible disgrace; or the British rule must be made effective, and the agencies of civilization be brought to bear effectually on them and on their people. From the first moment of expressed intention to roll back the tide of invasion by British troops, and to punish the wanton aggressor in his own land, it was admitted that the question of supply was the great question to be solved. On this the health and efficiency of the troops must mainly depend. And here the neglect of so many years—neglect against which we had so often protested in vain—rose up in judgment against the British Executive. That question has been solved; with difficulty, a route has been opened to the Ashanti frontier, over which supplies can be carried with no other difficulty than that of their conveyance for so many miles on the heads of human beings. Is it too much to say that that route cannot be allowed ever again to be closed up by the impenetrable bush; that, on the contrary, it must and will be made a solid and permanent highway to the interior for trade and commerce to pass over? We hope it is not too much to say this; and therefore, here again, the present is full of promise. Again, admitting that the Ashanti power was in itself a formidable one, there can be no doubt that much of its prestige, much of the dread with which it was regarded, was owing to the little real information that could be obtained respecting it. From the outset we expressed the conviction that the hostile touch of civilized power, like that of Great Britain, would dispel a great illusion, or destroy even a great fact. In one of the extracts from correspondence, which we insert elsewhere, an opinion will be found expressed, that even though we had not followed up the Ashantees into their own territory, they would have been deterred by their great losses from any further invasion for at least some fifty years. But we do not feel certain of this; and even had it been so, the destructive prestige of their superior prowess would have been heavily weighing on the Coast districts. This is now for ever at an end. The present advance on Kumasi is not by European troops only. Wood and Russell's native regiments, the Akim contingent—the Houssas, Yorubas, and other Africans under Captain Glover, are among the invaders—will be among the temporary occupiers of that city of blood, that human shambles—the capital of Ashanti. The native contingents, acting with the 23rd, the Rifles, and the 42nd, will have seen that fetish charms are powerless against brave men with good weapons in their hands, whether those men be Europeans or Africans; no mist of ignorance will rest any more over the Ashanti countries; no prestige of invulnerability will defend the Ashantees and their capital. The Ashanti pride will also be humbled. Ashanti kings will recognize that they have nothing to gain on the side of the sea-coast territories, save those supplies which they may be able to purchase there from a friendly people. All this promises well for the future. But we look for more than this influence of accomplished events. We look also for the influence of positive stipulations—of conditions imposed by the civilized conqueror on the vanquished barbarian. We look for constant free access from the sea-coast to Kumasi, and to all parts of the Ashanti territory. We look for permission for missionaries to preach the everlasting Gospel of peace there. We look for an entire discontinuance of those horrible human sacrifices which have made Kumasi a name of loathing and abhorrence. We look for the liberty of exploration, by which, directly or indirectly, sooner or later, those great gold deposits which the Kong Mountains undoubtedly contain, shall be utilized for the convenience and benefit of the civilized world. Yes; the past, the present, and the future of this Ashanti War must all combine for great and permanent results, among which will, undoubtedly, be the elevation of the Fantees, and other coast tribes, from that condition of filthy barbarism which makes them at this time a reproach to the civilized protecting power. It has become evident that, if left to their own devices, they would remain from century to century in that disgusting condition which has so horrified the numerous Europeans whom this war has forced to become temporary residents at Cape Coast and Accra. For their own good, as well as for the good of others, they must be forced out of it, by introducing—compulsorily, if necessary—those sanitary laws and regulations, and that public order through the bridling of private licence, which are among the first essentials of progress. The Ashanti invasion has been a terrible scourge—the Ashanti war has been a mighty awakening; and the direct and indirect regenerating influences of both will be such as will make both the invasion and the war most memorable in the history of Western Africa.", 'last_edit_date': '1874-02-26', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/26_02_1874#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.607, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letter from Kpong', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Alas, dear Mr. Editor! I am afraid our local Government here are neglecting one of the most important measures in this affair of the Ashantee war. No blockade can be effectual till it is carried out fully. Although Government has blockaded our frontiers toward the Ashantee territory, yet this part of the country, on the river Volta, is totally neglected, and now open to the Ashantees, where they receive all the munitions of war. In consequence of this, a vigorous trade is going on from this and Adda and Quittah, in salt, tobacco, gin, arms, and gunpowder, in exchange for gold dust and slaves. This is a policy that we stupid people here don't understand. Through this neglect the Ashantees have lately committed some outrages here.\n\nSome time last month the messengers of the King of Ashantee arrived here in the town of Assabi, in the district of Krepee, and under cover of night cut off the heads of two of Her Majesty's subjects, by names Quamlin Savili and Kuaku Dabonnie, natives of Assabi, in our Krepee jurisdiction.\n\nIt has since come out that this outrage was committed by sanction and connivance of the chief of Assabi, by name Quamlin Minta, who is supposed to be intriguing with the Ashantees. On investigating the case before the supreme chief, Nijarkon, it was further proved that Minta has had a criminal connexion with the wife of one of the unfortunate men. He is now bailed out before Chief Nijarkon till something is heard from proper authorities. I will write you something more about this affair, and about the change that has come over the people in other parts of our territories with regard to the Ashantee war. It seems to\n\nme that the sufferings inflicted on the country last year in consequence of the shameful military mismanagement, which allowed the Ashantees to ravage in all directions, have not only put an end to the enthusiasm the people felt when the war began, but quite sickened them of it. The truth is, they do not believe in the English power as they did before the last campaign.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.612, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial Bathurst's establishment on the unhealthy St. Mary's Island, despite health risks and neglect of local needs such as fire-fighting equipment, underscores the prioritization of strategic location over resident welfare.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the claim that Colonial Bathurst's establishment on the unhealthy St. Mary's Island prioritized strategic location over resident welfare. While the textbook does not specifically address Bathurst or St. Mary's Island, it provides a broader context of colonial strategies that align with the claim's theme, highlighting how colonial infrastructure was primarily designed to facilitate resource extraction rather than serve local populations. This reflects a general pattern of neglecting local development and welfare in favor of colonial interests. In contrast, The African Times articles provide direct evidence supporting the claim, detailing the health risks associated with Bathurst's swampy environment, such as the spread of diseases like smallpox and malarial fever, and the neglect of essential needs like fire-fighting equipment. Despite these health concerns, the strategic advantages of Bathurst's location, including safe anchorage and convenient landing-places for trade, were prioritized, illustrating the colonial administration's focus on strategic interests. The articles further criticize the administration for mismanaging funds and failing to address public works, reinforcing the notion of neglecting local needs. Together, these sources highlight the tension between strategic priorities and the well-being of Bathurst's residents, with the articles providing specific evidence that complements the textbook's broader insights into colonial practices.

The articles highlight the health risks associated with the location, noting the unhealthiness of Bathurst due to its swampy environment and inadequate drainage, which contributes to the spread of diseases like smallpox and malarial fever. The articles also mention the neglect of local needs, such as the absence of fire-fighting equipment, which exacerbates the vulnerability of residents to fires. Despite these issues, the strategic location of Bathurst on St. Mary's Island is emphasized, particularly its suitability for trade due to the safe anchorage and convenient landing-places, which outweighs the health concerns and the reluctance of merchants to relocate. This prioritization of strategic location over resident welfare aligns with the claim. Additionally, the articles criticize the colonial administration for its mismanagement of funds and failure to address essential public works, further supporting the notion of neglecting local needs. Overall, the articles corroborate the claim by illustrating the tension between strategic interests and the well-being of Bathurst's residents.

[{'id': 591, 'article_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'full_section_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '03-09-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '24_04_1865', 'content': 'All labour is performed by the domestic slaves of the family, who, as a rule, are kindly treated, and are not often parted with, except under circumstances of necessity.

There is some reason to suppose that coloured traders and trading agents, when following their avocations at a distance from the settlements, occasionally engage in slave-dealing transactions with the natives; but these operations are conducted beyond British jurisdiction, and as yet it has been found impossible to bring any case home to an offender.

In point of unhealthiness the climate of the Gambia probably varies little from that of the other settlements. There is considerable sickness during and after the rains; but many of the merchants, finding that their business makes but light demands upon them during that season, are in the habit of passing in England the worst months of the year. Military officers who suffer in health to any considerable extent are at once invalided, and civil officers are afforded every facility for obtaining the advantages of a change of climate: thus not only are very few Europeans compelled to remain in the colony for any length of time without a change, but there is also a consequent diminution in the number of deaths from the effects of the climate.

It has often been urged that the unhealthiness of the Gambia is largely due to the unfavourable situation of Bathurst, the capital and seat of trade, on the low-lying and swampy Island of St. Mary, and it has been suggested that a great improvement would be effected in this respect by the removal of the seat of government to the more airy and elevated situation of Cape St. Mary.

There can be no question of the superior healthiness of the Cape, and on this account alone the transfer would be very desirable; but

although the government offices might be removed there, it is certain that the merchants would not on this account alone consent to incur the heavy expense of moving their store-houses and long-established places of business from the safe anchorage and convenient landing-places of the river to the exposed situation of St. Mary, which is in no respect so well adapted for the purposes of trade. So long, therefore, as Bathurst remains the seat of trade, it is necessary for its convenience that the custom-house and other public offices connected with it should not be removed from its neighbourhood.

One cause of the unhealthiness of Bathurst is the existence in the immediate neighbourhood of the town of an offensive and pestilent swamp; but from a recent report of Major Clarke, R.E., it appears that, for the sum of about 7,000£, the whole space, covering nearly 1,000 acres, could be closely and efficiently drained. Unfortunately, the circumstances of the colony forbid the hope that it will for a considerable time to come be in a position to afford this outlay, even for a work of such paramount importance to its interests.'}, {'id': 1300, 'article_title': 'Deplorable Fires at Bathurst.—No Fire-engine There!', 'full_section_title': 'Deplorable Fires at Bathurst.—No Fire-engine There!', 'last_edit_date': '03-19-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1868#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_04_1868', 'content': "Sir,—We are not only surprised and distressed at the prevalence of fires, by which many houses here are now consumed, but are also quite at a loss how to account for them. There was one of these fires on the 6th instant, and another yesterday evening, the 18th—this last, a great one, destroying about twelve lots, containing some twenty houses. The poor residents lost all their property because no sufficient assistance was rendered. The fire began at half-past 10 P.M. At five minutes past 11 the troops of the garrison came from their barracks, with their officers, &c., but without any fire-engine, any fire-buckets, or anything to show an intention on their part to assist in putting out the fire. As the Military Department do not keep such things as a fire-engine and fire-buckets, don't you think it is time that the Administrator or the Colonial-office should take the proper steps to provide one, out of our Revenue, for the Civil Department, and for the service in this town of Bathurst? There ought to be one at the police-station ready for service whenever it may be wanted. If we had any voice in the spending of the public money raised here we should have got a fire-engine and fire-buckets for the public use long ago. They would be a great boon to the poor people, and prevent a great deal of distress.—Yours truly,"}, {'id': 6031, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-7', 'issue_date': '07_11_1890', 'content': "The latest accounts from this settlement are not too cheerful, the Administrator and the colonial surgeon being the only European officials fit for duty. The colonial engineer died on Oct. 1 from a severe attack of malarial fever, after a residence of only three months in the colony. On Sept. 22 he accompanied the Administrator to Albreda, and while there the best accommodation was afforded by a house belonging to a French merchant which is built on a swampy and unwholesome site, the dangerous character of which was increased by torrents of rain which fell the day after their arrival.

The steam yacht which conveyed the Administrator to Albreda proceeded to M'Carthy's Island, 100 miles further up the river, and it was his Excellency's intention to return to Bathurst by her when she was able to fulfil her mission, but owing to a strong current caused by the heavy rains she was delayed much beyond the time expected. In the meantime the colonial engineer had contracted fever, and the Administrator decided to proceed to Bathurst in an open boat, a distance of 16 miles, so that medical advice might be obtained. A start was accordingly made on Sept. 26, and Bathurst was safely reached. Here Mr. Hingeston received immediate attention, but, in spite of every remedy, he succumbed to syncope. At the same time Lieut.-Colonel Tighe, the superintendent of police, was lying seriously ill of a like complaint, in a portion of the quarters occupied by the colonial engineer, and to save the shock, which in all probability would have killed him, he was removed to Government House, and the news of his comrade's death kept from him as long as possible. Colonel Tighe rallied from the attack, but he has been invalided to England, as it was thought improbable that he would thoroughly regain his health without a radical change.

There can be no doubt that the town of Bathurst during a heavy rainy season is one of the most unhealthy places in the world. St. Mary's Island, on which the town is built, is a perfectly flat sand bank with a considerable admixture in the soil of the ooze of the great river Gambia. It is well-nigh impossible to drain it, although attempts have been made. Certain it is that many of the drains do not act, and without great expense no effective system of drainage could be accomplished.

Unfortunately the deep water is on the St. Mary's side of the channel, otherwise the town would be far more healthily situated on the mainland at Borra Point.

The rainfall up to last report has been 59 in., as compared with 32 in. in 1889 for the whole year."}]
tat_extra: [{'document_title': 'MISAPPLICATION OF THE GAMBIA REVENUES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It does not much matter in which of the British West African Colonies and Settlements we inquire as to the expenditure of the revenues raised there. The same practice is found to prevail in all of them, with some exception as regards Lagos, where works of public utility have been allowed a share. There is the same squandering of the public money upon official favourites everywhere, and everywhere an almost total neglect of those matters upon which the progress of towns, and districts, and countries depend. But for the present we will take Bathurst. Look at Bathurst. The imposts on trade and commerce have been, within the last three years, most prejudicially increased because of former lavish extravagance. The revenue must be above 20,000l. a-year. The colonial steamer for protecting and assisting trade up the Gambia, which formerly absorbed some 5,000l. a-year, has disappeared from the estimates and from river navigation, and what is being done with the money? In March last we were called upon to notice that, although the revenue has for many years past fluctuated between 15,000l. and 20,000l. a-year, not even a fire-engine has been provided for the town of Bathurst, so that when a fire breaks out in any of the native habitations, there are none of the means used in civilised countries for arresting its progress; there is a general danger, and much loss and privation is the result. In our June number an intelligent correspondent says that on all sides there is deterioration and no renewal—the sea-wall has been allowed to go out of repair, the roads are neglected and have become almost useless; while the writer of another letter in the same number inquires why such and such houses are hired by the local authorities unnecessarily at a great expense of public money, and only for the advantage and profit of some favoured individuals. It is from beginning to end a system of waste. There is so much a-year to be spent, and the question has been, not how much good may be effected for the Colony with it, but who is to have a share in it? Is it not shameful? Is it any wonder that the people complain? Little or nothing done for education; nothing for the assistance or protection of trade on the river; no bridge built over Oyster Creek, so that there may be always an open road into the healthy districts of British Combo;* not even a fire-engine to save the houses of the poor people from destruction; sea-wall out of repair, and roads neglected. We only give these as a sample of the really vital necessities that are not attended to, while what is amply sufficient for these purposes is uselessly squandered in other directions where it only benefits unjustly a few favoured individuals. Do not let us be misunderstood. We do not accuse the present chief local authority, the present Administrator, of squandering the revenue by any acts of favouritism. The worst we should say of him is that he allows the continuance of abuses scandalously perpetrated by others, such as the rental of the houses mentioned by "Public Interest" in our June number. Rather, the complaint made against Admiral Patey is, that having succeeded in getting a large sum into the colonial chest, he is not willing to expend any of it even on those most indispensable works—roads, bridges, and sea-wall.† For a moment there is a fit of official parsimony, and the misapplication consists in shutting that money up in the chest in useless inactivity, which ought to be made the instrument of present and future good to the colony. We venture to call the serious attention of the Administrator, Admiral Patey, to these things. Why should he not make his administration memorable on the Gambia by the correction of old abuses, and the application of some portion of the surplus funds he so happily possesses, on objects that will bring him thanks and blessings from a grateful people. Let him begin by importing that most necessary adjunct of civilisation, a fire-engine; and then form a volunteer fire brigade; teaching the natives how they may most usefully employ themselves in extinguishing a conflagration. We really long for the opportunity of praising Admiral Patey or some other of our West Coast administrators. We have volumes of laudation ready for them if they will only give us proper occasion for using it, for the fact is they have afforded us so little chance of applying any portion of it during the past eight years, that the accumulation on hand is quite embarrassing. We should like to see a healthy emulation among them as to who should establish a claim to the largest portion of it. Will an emulation in good, among West Coast officials really show itself, and gratify our anxious desires? Alas, we are long waiting for it.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': "That virulent small-pox should be carrying off daily its ten or a dozen victims from among the small native population of Bathurst, or that any other fatal epidemic should be committing its ravages there, ought not to be a matter of surprise with any one who had read the accounts we have given from time to time, and very recently with added emphasis, of the infamous absence of all adequate sanitary regulations for making the place a safe habitation for human beings, whether white or black. We have, as our readers well know, felt the most serious apprehensions that the yellow fever, which had visited Senegal, would descend to Bathurst, as offering a most tempting field for it to revel in. Happily, however, according to latest advices, it seems to have spent its energies at St. Louis, and has died out there. But we were not surprised to hear that while the yellow fever was at the Senegal, a virulent smallpox should have broken out among the natives at Bathurst, it having been almost invariably the case that whenever yellow fever made its appearance among the Europeans on that part of the Coast, there should be a great mortality from small-pox among the natives, who do not suffer from yellow fever, as neither do the Europeans from the native small-pox. In a letter from the Gambia which we insert in this present number, it will be seen that the Secretary of State for the Colonies had instructed Sir Samuel Rowe to call at the Gambia on his passage down the West Coast, to inquire into the great neglect and abuses of which we have so often and so vehemently complained. Unfortunately, owing to the pressure of the scare at Cape Coast, Sir Samuel will not have been able to make that visit and inquiry. We are very sorry that this is the case; but, nevertheless, we do venture to hope that the mere fact of such a visit and inquiry having been ordered by the Colonial Office will impel the authorities to make extraordinary efforts to set their house in sanitary order, and that we shall not have again to complain of a state of the burial-ground, the drains, and the general absence of sanitary regulations, such as we have had the painful duty so often to expose and comment upon. The strange neglect by British authorities in almost all the Coast towns of ordinary means to purify the atmosphere is a great disgrace to us as a nation. What has been done at Calcutta, in the East Indies, once as unhealthy a residence for Europeans as any one of the West Coast towns, might long ago have been done in these also. We would ask our readers to glance for a moment at the complaints about the state of Quittah, where a considerable revenue is already raised, and where a much larger one might, it is stated, be raised by a modified scale of Customs' duties, such as would put an end to the temptation of smuggling from the neighbouring sea-coast villages without British jurisdiction. Disgraceful is a word scarcely strong enough to apply to such a state of things. It is a lamentable fact that, so far as the Government is concerned, we do not carry civilization and civilizing efforts with us. Our officers are content to sit upon dung-heaps, surrounded by the most atmospheric-poisoning filth, to collect their Customs' duties; and then we complain of the fatal atmospheric impurities of so many of the sea-coast towns. Is it too much to hope that the new Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony will find some remedy for this fearful state of things? As a medical man, we hope that he will prove to be sensitive in this matter. We feel that he has Herculean tasks before him. His predecessors have done so little that there is overwhelming work for him to do, unless he be allowed to appoint subordinates whom he can imbue with his own spirit. We would venture to ask his Excellency's consideration of our Quittah letters. They are brief and plain, but to the point, and, we think, well worthy his attention, so soon as his settlement of the Ashanti episode and the important Lagos question referred to in our last will permit. Our support may not be of much importance, but, such as it is, it will be heartily given to him in every effort to make British rule a mighty civilizing agent and a real blessing to the Gold Coast countries and their people.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.612, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bathurst Complaints', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are indeed pained to learn, from the Memorial addressed by some of the native inhabitants of Bathurst to the Governor-General at Sierra Leone, that the injudicious and dangerous economy and neglect which we have in other years exposed continues at this town on the Gambia. This indifference and neglect, which we feel justified in designating criminal, not only interferes with the progress of civilization, but subjects the community, both European and native, to renewed outbreaks of those destroying pestilences which have from time to time decimated the town of Bathurst. Year after year the educated native inhabitants, as well as Europeans, have protested against the continued permission by the authorities to the natives from the river villages who flock to Bathurst for trade, to perambulate the town in a state of nudity, and perform all the operations of nature when and where they choose, without the slightest regard to decency, and in defiance of all sanitary regulations which ought to be enforced in any town under British rule and law. We are at a loss to understand why such things should be—why British officials should continue to tolerate them, as if a decree had gone forth that it was not desirable that the blessings of civilization should extend in Africa. Bathurst, and all other towns on the Coast under British government, ought to be brought fully under civilized regulations, and become spots from which civilization should radiate into the neighbouring territories. That they should not be this, is a gross neglect of duty on the part of the authorities, and reflects deep disgrace on Great Britain. It is absurd to suppose that there could be any real difficulty in insisting upon public decency within the town of Bathurst. While the unclothed natives from the river villages are allowed to come into the town in their unclothed condition, and treat the town in every way as if it were the bush or fields in which they reside, they will no doubt continue to do so, and look with ignorant and barbarous contempt upon the inhabitants who are not permitted, and would no longer permit themselves, the offensive freedom from all self-restraint which they, the "untutored savages," enjoy. Is it too much to expect that British authority will now at last interfere on the side of decency and health? The "untutored savage" would not forego the substantial benefits he or she derives from his or her visits to Bathurst because compelled to wear a proper cloth and conform to certain sanitary regulations; and, accustomed to these self-restraints within the town of Bathurst, they will thus have entered, however superficially, into the arena of civilization, and become more accessible to the propaganda of civilization among themselves. Important, however, as this change for which we call would really prove to be, it is but secondary when viewed in connection with that continued neglect of the drains, and that continuous horrible condition of the place of sepulture, respecting which the Memorialists protest. Everyone who has watched and recorded the ravages of epidemics on the West Coast of Africa must remember but too well the awful visitations to which Bathurst has been subject. Only last year it was threatened with one of them, and not a few persons perished from its advancing breath, when, happily, a sudden meteorological change drove back the fearful enemy. In some of our letters we find fears expressed that the present season may be rather an unhealthy one on the West Coast, and the mere suspicion that it will be so ought to induce precaution on the part of individuals and authorities. The latter are to a certain extent answerable for the lives of the population over whom they rule; they are fully answerable to the extent of removable causes; and among removable causes, that of pestilential drains, of filthy thoroughfares, and of graveyards in which the decaying dead are exposed to public view, filling the atmosphere with poisonous gases, must certainly be included. By the time this number of our journal reaches Bathurst the fiend of pestilence may—though we fervently pray it will not—may, we say, be upon the town. Should such, unhappily, be the case—should there be a new holocaust of victims offered up on the shrine of official incompetency, indifference, or neglect,—we shall cry loudly for retribution on those who shall have thus trifled with the lives of a community, to protect and defend which is one of the most sacred of the duties with which they are charged.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Virulent Small-pox at the Gambia, Quittah Impurities, &c.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "That virulent small-pox should be carrying off daily its ten or a dozen victims from among the small native population of Bathurst, or that any other fatal epidemic should be committing its ravages there, ought not to be a matter of surprise with any one who had read the accounts we have given from time to time, and very recently with added emphasis, of the infamous absence of all adequate sanitary regulations for making the place a safe habitation for human beings, whether white or black. Our support may not be of much importance, but, such as it is, it will be heartily given to him in every effort to make British rule a mighty civilizing agent and a real blessing to the Gold Coast countries and their people.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.613, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst and other parts of the River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In close proximity to the town, towards the left, there was an extensive mangrove swamp, not provided with a natural embankment, and not even by a proper artificial one; consequently, the poorer inhabitants in its neighbourhood were in constant dread of being swamped one fine morning by the overflowing of its banks. I was told that in 1847 and 1851 the rains were so heavy, that the water made its way into the town, a large amount of property was destroyed, and some of the houses were under water. There was a rivulet right through the town; the pedestrians were put to fearful inconvenience and distress; children dare not come out of the houses unless carried. There were few drains, and most of those were in bad condition. There was no proper road to Cape St. Mary's, but a mere footpath, and mostly covered with water. With these partial observations, we retraced our steps towards the beach, and found that our aquatic earth, as the King of Dahomey would call a large steamer, was alongside the jetty of one of the principal merchants. Of course, the swamp so near the town produced the most unhealthy emanations, most prejudicial to European constitutions. But it cannot be said that Bathurst was always in this state of dangerous neglect, because in the time of Governor Randle, in 1838, a capital sea embankment was made with mangrove plants and the trunk of the Talipot Palm. Our vessel suddenly came to anchor, to our great surprise, as we had intended to have a jolly good turn out on shore, and on inquiry we were told that the pilots would not conduct vessels to their safe anchorage in this intricate river at night. We grumbled and stamped our feet, but were obliged to succumb to the will of the pilate, and remained. Before break of day, however, steam was again up, and we were introduced, through deep channel by uncertain turnings amongst the sandbanks on the mouth of the river, to the anchorage opposite Bathurst.\n\nIt was in the rainy season of August, 1856, that I thus first visited St. Mary's. The night before there had been heavy rain. The appearance of the front buildings was indeed picturesque, white houses beautifully laid out, peeping through a row of bushy trees, unlike Sierra Leone, where the backs of the houses fronting the sea are in a demi-semi state of dilapidation, a standing disgrace to the colony.
