On inquiry we found that there was no hotel, and no place of accommodation; and therefore, after a brief consultation with my companions, we agreed to make a regular inspection of the town. The condition of the back streets produced a rather unfavourable impression, those especially in the soldiers' and the Mohammedan town were in a state of swamp and dirt; there was very little drainage, the streets were covered with water knee-deep, and, as I was told by our guide, visiting from one house to the other was most difficult in some parts; in fact, he repeated the antiquated story that at times some of the people were obliged to visit by canoe; but this statement, in my second visit of 1864, I heard indignantly denied by natives of the Gambia, and from their countenances read that it was the production of an over-heated imagination.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.611, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sanitariums for West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'M\'Carthy\'s Island, River Gambia, Dec. 20, 1864.\n\nMy Lord,—In the editorial article in the Lancet of October 13, page 442, we find the remark that "it is a singular fact in medical geography that from St. Louis, Senegal, on the north, to Mossamedes, on the south, there is not upon the seaboard a single healthy acre of ground. The whole western side of that vast continent (Africa) is one hotbed of disease."\n\nIt is well known that in all diseases the great restorative agent is pure air, and this is obtained on lofty ranges, along the seacoast, or elsewhere, inaccessible to the influence of malaria. This fact has been established in India beyond all doubt, and extensively acted upon, irrespective of expense, it being known that life is sure to be saved by it. In the West Indies the same sanitary measure has been taken, in the formation of a camp, at a\n\nNew Castle, the attitude of which defies the approach of the most pestilential lithoral poison.\n\nBut it appears that, until lately, there has been scarcely any knowledge amongst Englishmen that the West Coast of Africa is garrisoned by British soldiers, whose lives are as precious as any other soldiers, and who go heartily to fight for their sovereign against, not only barbarous tribes, but also against the pestiferous, ghastly miasma that poisons the atmosphere of many parts of this Coast. This was abundantly proved in the late disastrous expedition against the King of Ashantee, where men and officers died without number, and without even seeing an enemy. There has been a great neglect respecting the requirements of the West Coast of Africa, and even a simple account of the Coast, in these enlightened days, is received with the same wonder and surprise as the adventures of Mungo Park and Robinson Crusoe. So little, indeed, is known of it, that in print, in public speeches, and in private conversation, it is termed the most unhealthy region in the world; yet still if one takes the percentage of deaths amongst the different stations of the British Army, irrespective of the great sanitary measures used by the Government, it will be found that many of them were by far more unhealthy than the West Coast of Africa. The African Times has always endeavoured to point this out; and as a proof of it, I may state that some time ago, so great and so frequent was the amount of havoc committed on the soldiers quartered in one of the West Indian Islands by disease, that all but one officer were laid hors de combat, so that the troops were entirely withdrawn, and a notice was sent to the colonial authorities that, should they intend to keep the island, they were to increase their police force.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-12-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Island of M'Carthy, about 150 miles up the river, is occupied as an advanced post for the protection of trade in its neighbourhood; its establishment usually consists of a commandant, who acts as magistrate, and is generally the military officer in command, of two assistant-surgeons and about thirty men. It is certainly of advantage to the trade of the upper river that there should be such a post, but the climate is so unfavourable to the European constitution, and the expense involved in the maintenance of even this small establishment is so large, that it becomes worthy of consideration whether it could not be placed upon a smaller and more economical footing without seriously imperilling the interest for the protection of which it was established.\n\nFor the purpose of keeping up its communication with M'Carthy's Island, and for the general navigation of the river in connection with the protection of its trade, the Government has the services of a small paddle-wheel steamer, which discharges this duty very effectually. As it appears this vessel is only under steam during part of the year, it is open to question whether her more frequent employment on the river would not more than compensate for any danger or inconvenience which may be expected to result from the reduction of the military force at M'Carthy's Island.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In my last account I brought your readers' notice to the condition of the colony on my first visit, in 1865. I made another trip in July, 1864, during a season which all ground-nut traders called good, as the rains were plentiful, and there was every prospect of a good crop. I was surprised to see large and well-regulated drains made or making in almost every part where I went, walled on either side with stone or bricks—running from one side of the town to the other, and emptying into the sea. A great many were in an imperfect state, some of which were interrupted by the approach of the rainy season.\n\nIt was pleasant to see fine squares in the middle of the town, all covered with the green Bahama grass, and some of the drains supplied with railings. It struck me at once that there was a wonderful change in the interior of Bathurst since I last had seen it. There were good bridges in the centres of the streets, where in 1855 I had to walk knee deep in water. There was no more an inundation from the muddy swamp at the back and left of the town, a proper sea embankment having been made by the present Governor, which led to the securing of a large tract of land from the water. This land has been a great source of revenue to the Colonial Government, as it was afterwards divided into lots, and sold at a very advantageous rate, bringing over 600l. to the colonial coffers. The road to the burial-ground, which was in a fearful state of swamp, and in many parts covered over with water, is now converted into a hard road, and forms a pleasurable walk.\n\nAt this visit I rode to the cape. It is a distance of about seven miles. The road from St. Mary's to the ferry was excellent and hard—a good carriage drive. The boat employed in the ferry is an antiquated piece of workmanship, perhaps about fifty or a hundred years old, of an American origin, equally broad in stern and bow, and worked by paddles manned by four men. Sometimes the boat is drifted about 300 yards beyond its landing-place. I have never seen such an ugly piece of mechanism, and it is tiresome to see the poor men labouring to make this huge log move; and although it is said that the colony is in a state of bankruptcy, I hope they will soon be able to replace it with something more modern and workable. The road from the ferry to the cape is partly good and partly bad, the latter portion being rapidly repairing by the civilian prisoners. The material used by the Governor is the shell of the common cockle, mixed with those of other gregarious mollusks.\n\nAll along the road are large Bombax, or monkey bread trees, and I noticed hollows scraped out of a great many of them; and on inquiry I was told that they were so ordered to be done by the Governor, to form rests for the women who carry loads on their heads.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REPORT TO THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL FOR THE GAMBIA ON DYKES AND DRAINS', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Island of St. Mary's much resembles in formation the parallel ruler employed by navigators when pricking their charts; the right ruler represents the strip of sand on which Wellington-street, Government House, and the two hospitals are built, and the left ruler shows Soldier Town. The space between may be considered as the old racecourse, considerably below the level of the sea. This plain is partially made ground, for I see by the records of the colony, that originally Soldier Town was an island, a creek running at high tide right through from Half Die to the Pontine Marsh, forming St. Mary's into two islands; and it was seriously in contemplation at one time to form a canal admitting boats laden with produce, protected by lock-gates; and this probably was the cause of the double drainage so puzzling to a new arrival. The early settlers, observing the set of the tides, found it the best plan, when they relinquished their proposed canal, and followed the natural highway, only to convert the creek into a drain, by importing earth from the mainland, to wall up the creek, confining the water to a narrow deep space, instead of allowing it gently to ebb over a large space. At one time, indeed, I thought the drainage of the island was constructed altogether on a false principle, trying to make water run up hill; but I now see that the system of double drainage is the best that could be adopted, when the artificial formation of part of the island had to be taken in consideration. The racecourse, or left ruler, drains to the Pontine Marsh, and to the river round by Arrafal's Creek and the right parallelogram of sandbank drains to the sea by cutting through the bank on which stands Wellington-street, and making an artificial level protected by sluice-gates; for if all the rain and sea water were allowed to flow to the Pontine Marsh, the accumulation at high tides would be too great, swamping the inhabitants of Perseverance-street and a great part of Soldier Town, and probably the weight would be too much for the present gates at the Box Bar.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Copy of the Report of Col. Ord', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In point of healthiness Sierra Leone does not contrast unfavourably with any other settlements. Indeed, the garrison, who are quartered on a hill 400 feet high and overlooking the town, are singularly exempt from epidemics and from the more fatal form of African fever. It is now a subject of regret with many of the inhabitants, that they did not originally establish their permanent residences, or at least country houses, on the high lands surrounding the town, when at an elevation of 3,000 feet they would have been entirely free from the dangers to which they are now exposed in the low-lying ground of Freetown, where all their houses are situated.\n\nGOLD COAST.\n\nThe territory on the Gold Coast which is recognised as British consists of a large number of forts and posts, many of them abandoned or in ruins, which have come into our possession either by settlement, capture, or purchase, during the last 200 years, together with the line of the sea-coast adjacent to them.\n\nThe Dutch Government also possesses many posts and forts on the same line of coast, and it is understood and allowed by the natives that whatever portion of the seaboard is not Dutch is British territory.\n\nThe territory actually under occupation at the present time consists (in addition to the coast) of the Fort of Dixcove, in the Ahanta country; of Cape Coast Castle, and Annamaboe Fort, in the Fantee; Winnebah, in the Agonah country, and of Accra, in the district of the same name. Quittah Fort, on the River Volta, has not been occupied since 1856.\n\nImmediately in rear of the 300 miles of coast along which these posts are situated, and extending to a distance of about eighty miles inland, is a country inhabited by a number of native tribes, the principal of whom are the Wassaws, Denkeras, Akims, Assins, and Fantees, the whole of whom, with the exception of a small number residing immediately in rear of some of the Dutch posts, are included in what is termed the "Protectorate."\n\nTo the eastward of the settlements is situated the powerful and barbarous kingdom of Dahomey, and to the north of the Protectorate extends the equally powerful and barbarous kingdom of Ashantee. The protected tribes thus form a complete barrier between the colony and these two warlike and dangerous bodies of savages.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.612, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: The colonial postal system in Africa was inefficient and unreliable, causing significant communication issues and hardships for Africans.
result: The claim that the colonial postal system in Africa was inefficient and unreliable, causing significant communication issues and hardships for Africans, is supported by observations from The African Times but not directly addressed in the General History of Africa textbook. The textbook discusses colonial infrastructure, such as roads and railways, primarily in the context of resource extraction rather than facilitating inter-African communication, and focuses on economic exploitation, inadequate educational facilities, and broader socio-political impacts of colonialism, leaving a gap in the discussion of the postal system's role in communication issues. In contrast, The African Times provides detailed accounts supporting the claim, highlighting numerous instances of non-delivery and loss of mail, such as complaints about the non-delivery of the African Times to subscribers in the Gambia and misplacement of letters by the steamer Lagos. Reports of letters being delayed or sent to wrong destinations, like those posted in Accra for Cape Palmas arriving ten days late, further illustrate the system's inefficiency. The articles also mention the lack of a consistent mail schedule, with steamers arriving unexpectedly or not at all, leading to delays and confusion. Administrative chaos, such as postmasters holding multiple roles and unauthorized extra postage fees imposed by officials like Charles Forsythe, exemplifies the hardships faced by Africans due to the unreliable postal system. However, these articles focus on specific regions and incidents, not providing a comprehensive overview of the entire colonial postal system across Africa, which is a notable difference from the broader claim.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that the colonial postal system in Africa was inefficient and unreliable, causing significant communication issues and hardships for Africans. The articles highlight numerous instances of non-delivery and loss of mail, such as the repeated complaints about the non-delivery of the African Times to subscribers in the Gambia and the misplacement of letters due by the steamer Lagos. There are also reports of letters being delayed or sent to the wrong destinations, as seen in the case of letters posted in Accra for Cape Palmas arriving ten days late. Additionally, the articles mention the lack of a consistent mail schedule, with steamers arriving unexpectedly or not at all, leading to further delays and confusion. The inefficiency of the postal system is further exemplified by the administrative chaos, such as the postmaster holding multiple roles and the imposition of extra postage fees by officials like Charles Forsythe, which were not sanctioned by the government. These issues collectively illustrate the hardships faced by Africans due to the unreliable postal system, aligning with the claim. However, the articles do not provide a comprehensive overview of the entire colonial postal system across Africa, focusing instead on specific regions and incidents, which is a notable difference from the broader claim.

[{'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the economic field', 'content': "Was the colonial impact on Africa in the economic field, then, such a very enviable one? Far from it, and most of the present-day developmental problems facing African countries can be traced to this.
In the first place, as M. H. Y. Kaniki has pointed out above (Chapter 16), the infrastructure that was provided by colonialism was not as adequate nor as useful as it could have been. Most of the roads and railways were constructed not to open up the country but merely to connect the areas having mineral deposits and potentialities for the production of cash crops with the sea or, to quote Fieldhouse, 'to link internal areas of production to the world commodity market',$^{20}$ and there were hardly any feeder or branch roads. Nor were they meant to facilitate inter-African travel and communication. Such infrastructure as was provided was meant, then, to facilitate the exploitation of the resources of the colonies and to link them with the metropolitan countries but not to promote the over all economic development of Africa nor to promote inter-African contacts. In the second place, such economic growth as occurred in the colonies was based on the natural resources of the area and this meant therefore that areas not naturally endowed were totally neglected. This led to sharp economic differences in the same colony. These differences, in turn, accentuated and exacerbated regional differences and sentiments which have been a great impediment in the way of nation-building in independent Africa.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.596, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy: the former British zones', 'section_title': 'Marketing', 'content': "Occasionally African producers defended their interests collectively through hold-ups (refusals to deliver produce to market). There were several such hold-ups in the Gold Coast where cocoa farmers were substan› tially exposed to international market forces. The most serious cocoa hold› up, between October and December 1930, has been described as 'an economic strike for higher prices' and was 'directed against the large expatriate buying firms and their monopoly control' over the Gold Coast economy.$^{79}$ In addition to withholding their cocoa, Gold Coasters boy› cotted European goods. Arrests were made and fines imposed by chiefs to maintain the hold-up. The effectiveness of the movement threatened the very foundation of colonial economic relations, as the colonial govern› ment, like the expatriate firms, depended on the cocoa trade for its revenue. Evidently the movement was against the interests of both sides. Accord› ingly, the colonial administration broke the movement by force, fining and imprisoning chiefs who supported the hold-up.$^{80}$ During the 1937/8 cocoa season another big hold-up was staged against the most important cocoa exporting firms which had formed an agreement to buy cocoa at a fixed maximum price. This time, the hold-up was extended to Western Nigeria, and it ended only with the intervention of the British government. A commission of enquiry headed by Nowell$^{81}$ revealed that the marketing system, which involved thousands of intermediaries, was both inefficient and wasteful, and was disadvantageous to both the producers in West Africa and the consumers in Western Europe.
The United Africa Company (UAC), an amalgamation of many former British firms, was the most prominent and most powerful firm in West African trade after 1920. It alone handled nearly half of West Africa's overseas trade during the 1930s, and dominated British West Africa, 82 especially Nigeria. Colonialism was imposed on the people, violently in most cases, even if the violence was sometimes disguised in the form of law. African responses to the initial impact combined military confrontation with diplomatic efforts in a vain attempt to preserve their independence. Where Africans did not engage in military or diplomatic activity, they acquiesced or remained indifferent, except where direct demands were made on them. The establishment of colonialism meant the reorganization of the political and economic life of the people. Taxes were introduced. Forced labour and general deprivation of political rights were practised. Some Africans responded to these changes violently. Others acquiesced. In Tanganyika and Uganda, some Africans had moved to peasant pro› duction of cash crops, particularly cotton and coffee. In Kenya, Africans were denied the production of cash crops. The economy there was settlerbased. Various African responses to this position have been outlined. More were to follow in the period after the First World War.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.598, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': "Moreover, nowhere and at no level did the facilities provided meet the demand nor were they evenly distributed. As even Lloyd admits, as late as the mid-i930S, 'government expenditure everywhere remained low, amounting in the mid-i930S to only 4% of total revenue in Nigeria and the French territories, and 7% in Ghana'.$^{36}$ Nor were these schools and institutions properly distributed in each colony. Most of the post-primary institutions were found in the main urban centres and in some countries most of the secondary schools were found in one town. In the Gold Coast for example about 80% of the secondary schools were found in Cape Coast. In Uganda, by 1920, there were 328 elementary schools in Buganda and only 34, 24 and practically none in the Western, Eastern and Northern provinces respectively.$^{37}$ Facilities for education were so inadequate and so unevenly distributed, because the colonial powers did not aim at pro› moting education for its own sake or for the sake of the Africans, but rather, to quote one African scholar, 'to produce Africans who would be more productive for the [colonial] system'. 38 Besides its grossly inadequate nature numerically and its uneven dis› tribution, the curricula provided by all these institutions were determined by the colonial rulers and were closely modelled on, if not carbon copies of, those of the metropolitan countries and therefore irrelevant to the needs of the continent. By 1914, with the sole exception of Ethiopia and Liberia, the whole of Africa had been subjected to the rule of European powers in colonies of various sizes which were generally much larger physically but often bore little or no relationship to the pre› existing polities. But it was not African sovereignty and independence alone that had been lost at that time. It represented also an assault on established cultures. As Ferhat Abbas pointed out in 1930 in reference to the French colonization of Algeria, for the French, colonization was 'simply a military and economic venture defended thereafter by the appropriate adminis› trative regime'. But for the Algerians, it was 'a veritable revolution, over› throwing a whole ancient world of beliefs and ideas and an immemorial way of life. It confronts a whole people with sudden change. This situation is bound to lead to a moral and physical disequilibrium, the barren› ness of which is not far from total disintegration." The nature of colonial› ism depicted here is true not only of French colonialism in Algeria but of European colonialism throughout Africa; the difference being one of degree not of kind, one of style not of substance. In other words, then, during the period 1880 to 1935, Africa did face a very serious challenge, the challenge of colonialism.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.599, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': "'Native policy'", 'content': "These explanations and arguments in respect of shortage of personnel and the need to reduce cost to the barest minimum are themselves directly related to a more fundamental problem which dictated the adoption of the conjunctive system of administration by all the colonial governments in the twentieth century. But colonialism completely isolated and insulated her from these changes and kept her in a position of dependency. I do not see what we have gained by changing Colonel D'Arcy (most unfit though he was to be at the head of affairs) for Admiral Patey—a naval officer of less than ordinary intelligence; while the evils of the new system (as I suppose we are to call the present chaos) invented by "the African Soapy Sam" (Governor-General Blackall's present popular cognomen) are becoming every day more ridiculously and ruinously apparent. Just look at this. Admiral Patey is not only Administrator, but is also Collector of Customs, Cashier, Colonial Treasurer, &c., &c. If he were a capable man perhaps this might pass, but I do not believe that he has the slightest idea of checking or examining the public accounts. The young men managing the different branches of the public service pay into his hands therefore just what money they please. It is only to be hoped that they are all incapable of error as well as of any purposed fraud, but taxpayers think there ought to be some efficient check. Mr. Kneller, the Collector of Customs, left by the April packet on sick leave; Admiral Patey of course succeeded to the office; now Admiral Patey is to go to England—doctors say he must or he will die here—and in his absence the Collector of Customs ought to be Acting Administrator; but as he is away, who is to be Administrator in the absence of both these luminaries? Perhaps "Soapy Sam," who has only just landed, has come up to set this matter right.

You have often before exposed the deplorable state of affairs in our Post-office—but, alas! we have no redress. Our papers are lost as heretofore; in fact, this has become so common, people cease to talk about it; there is nothing for us seemingly but to "grin and bear;" but there is a great public wrong in the Post-office being in its present hands. The Postmaster, who has become a pet of Admiral Patey's, is also Acting Clerk of Courts (the Clerk of Courts being a fiction), Clerk of the Crown, and is to be Colonial Auditor, &c. Now he has been in business, he has failed, has compounded with his creditors—but not paid them the composition—he is still trading, yet he has charge of the money order department, receives money here, gives orders, may or may not trade with the money, has not given, and cannot give any security. Can you wonder that, as the taxpayers are responsible, and would have to pay should there be any loss or defalcation, there should be some uneasiness and grumbling about it? Your comic paper _Punch_ comes out here, and I get a look at it sometimes. I remember his saying that when a man has proved himself utterly incapable for everything else, he has established his fitness for a Government situation. We have pretty good proof here always, from Governor-General downwards, of the correctness of Mr. Punch's view of these matters. Might we not even go to some of your Home Departments—Downing-street, for instance?'}, {'id': 1666, 'article_title': 'EXTRA POSTAGE ON LATE LETTERS—FAVOURITISM.', 'full_section_title': 'EXTRA POSTAGE ON LATE LETTERS—FAVOURITISM.', 'last_edit_date': '09-10-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1869#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_10_1869', 'content': 'Sir,—I beg to call your attention to the deeds of some of our officials on the West Coast, if you would allow me only a small space in your invaluable journal.

Our postmaster, Charles Forsythe, who holds so many appointments—viz., clerk and cashier in the Colonial Secretary's Office, postmaster, notary public, &c.—and who is reported to be also doing business in the style and firm of Henry Williams and Co.—[we thought this was prohibited by the Home Government?]—has for a few months printed a notice respecting postage of letters, "that late comers are to pay extra postage." Considering how uncertain the departure of the steamers is from this place, this is very unjust—the post-office ought to afford the greatest facilities possible. And yet, not only is this notice given by Mr. Forsythe, but it is also approved by Governor Glover, and that all these extra fees received are for the postmaster! Now this I may call a false pretence of receiving money in the name of the Government. Mr. Forsythe is a Timneh Creole, redeemed by the sheriff of Freetown when a boy, to whom he owes his education, and has got up to such favour that it is said, whatever he suggests to the Governor is sure to be done.

These extras are taken from Africans, who are not interested with Mr. Forsythe. I was in the post-office at the closing of the Antenian's mail. There were several persons whom I may call his favourites, who were late according to the specified time, but he did not take a pin as extras from them; others who saw this, of course, expected not to pay the extra tax; but he demanded the extras, and told them if it was not paid he would throw their letters to them, and they would then see whether they could post them or not.

I shall be most happy to know from you, Mr. Editor, whether the habit of receiving extra postages is practised in England, and whether this mode is sanctioned by the General Postmaster of London to be adopted here. There are always too many letters now left behind, simply because the parties are late, and could not afford posting them according to Mr. Forsythe's new taxing regulation, which is a great hardship when the reply ought to have gone by the same steamer.

If you love poor Africans as your real friends, please try and help us in this thing.—I am, Sir, yours obediently,

WILL O' THE WISP.

**NOTE BY THE EDITOR.**—An extra fee is paid in England on late letters, but it is affixed to the letter in stamps, and is not a perquisite of the postmaster, but goes to the Post-office revenue. We are sorry to hear of impediments in posting at African post-offices. As the postmasters have really so little to do, we think it is incumbent on them to keep the letter-bags open for every one until the last moment possible. Postmasters are servants of the public, and should give the public the greatest possible accommodation.—ED. A. T.

---'}, {'id': 4288, 'article_title': 'Administrative Perfection: The Mail not Forwarded to Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Administrative Perfection: The Mail not Forwarded to Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': '07-16-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1881#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_09_1881', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, River Gambia, 16th July, 1881.

Dear Sir,—It is with much regret that I have to inform you of what happened here on Sunday, the 10th inst.

The s.s. "Benguella" arrived from England about 8 A.M. of that day; she was therefore a day late.

When the outward mails were landed and taken to the Post Office, the purser wrote to the Postmaster requesting him to close the mails at 1 A.M. of that day. It is said that, as is the practice, the Postmaster forwarded the purser's note to the Administrator, Dr. Gouldsbury, who approved of the time as given by the purser.

As the "Benguella" had a small cargo for this port, it was all out of the vessel about 12 noon, and the captain who had given notice to clear his ship at the Customs at 1 P.M. came on shore, and had his clearance.

The Postmaster, who had closed the Post Office at 1 P.M., appeared to have got the mails ready in time, but before he could send them off to the "Benguella," a message came from Dr. Gouldsbury, requesting him to wait for the despatches. In obedience to the Administrator's command, the Postmaster had to wait until about 2.30 P.M. when the captain of the "Benguella," being tired of waiting and not wishing to lose further time, took up anchor and left the port for Sierra Leone; the mail bags were of course left behind, to the great disappointment and inconvenience of the public.

Now, Dr. Gouldsbury had over three days to reply to such despatches that he may have received from the Governor-in-Chief, by the steamer of the 7th inst.; but why he was unable to get them ready in time is known to the public.

The air at Government House being, I suppose, foul, the worthy Doctor resorts to the barracks for pure air during the day. There he may be seen at almost all hours of the day. He acts the part of the gallant, and one who shall be nameless that of the buffoon, in the dramatis personæ, "He Stoops to Conquer" as composed by a regimental sergeant at the Gold Coast, during the last Ashanti war.

The enclosed notice has been placarded in the streets of Bathurst. The Administrator has laboured in vain to fix the blame upon the captain of the "Benguella," but the public will not be carried away by such tinsel logic as that which is set forth in his notice.—I close, yours, &c.,

TIMBO.'}, {'id': 5190, 'article_title': 'The West Coast', 'full_section_title': 'The West Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_09_1885', 'content': 'It will hardly be credited that two letters of mine posted in Accra for Cape Palmas early in May did not arrive at Cape Palmas till ten days after I arrived there—viz., 31st May—and then came by a steamer from Sierra Leone, having been taken past and put on board the outward steamer. Conduct of this kind all along the coast causes opposition steamers to come out; and no wonder at it!—Yours truly,'}]

Sir,—Knowing your deep interest in all things pertaining to the interest of this country, we naturally come to you with our complaint. Last August the Royal Mail Steamship Company sent a "time-bill" to this river, stating that we were to have but one steamer a month, and that would be sent on the 5th, instead of on the 28th. We were willing to acquiesce, if the steamer was regular and gave us some few hours to read and answer our letters. But mark the way we are being served by this Company, which, if I mistake not, is bound by contract to send mails here once a month. Quite unexpectedly, the regular mail steamer called here on the 24th of September, and from that time until the present date we have had no opportunity of forwarding our letters to England. Captain Mercer, with the McGregor Laird, came to the bar on the afternoon of the 8th October, and after leaving the mail bag on board the cutter boat, instead of sending it up the river, steamed away immediately, without waiting for the homeward letters. This has caused much delay and expense here, and great anxiety to our friends in England. One gentleman who has been dangerously ill has been taken to the bar twice in an open boat to meet the steamer, but has had to return disappointed. Another from a distance has been staying here about a week with his boat's crew; who will pay for his loss and expense?

Earnestly desiring you very abundant success in your honoured work; I am, yours most sincerely,', 'last_edit_date': '1870-01-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_01_1870#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE MAILS TO THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '_The Standard_, of December 27, has the following:—

_To the Editor of the Standard._

Sir,—As you are always so ready to advocate the cause of the aggrieved, can you or any of your correspondents inform me and my fellow-shippers how and when the mails for the West Coast of Africa go and come, the contract for carrying them by the African Steamship Company having, it appears, expired. We are now at the mercy of the British and African Company, and I should imagine Government arrangements with them are far from satisfactory; insomuch that the only announcement at the Post-office is that letters will be dispatched "as opportunity offers," and upon application there a day or two since, the clerk who applied was informed that no one could tell when the next mail would be. Before the contract with the African Steamship Company expired, it was no uncommon thing for the mail from Sierra Leone, an eighteen-days' mail, to arrive six and eight days overdue. This was bad enough, considering how we may anticipate letters from Australia, China, or the Brazils to the day—but now not even to know when to look for letters, or, what is worse, to be in total darkness as to when the mails are dispatched hence, it appears monstrous. Our trading relations with Sierra Leone are considerably on the increase, and to have such an effectual check as this placed on our transactions with our friends in that colony, really seems too bad.—Yours truly,

_A Perplexed Merchant._

December 24.

Speer, died this morning, after a few weeks' illness.—Yours truly, F.", 'last_edit_date': '1882-10-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1882#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHRISTIANSBORG, ACCRA, OCTOBER 13, 1863.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I have written to Mr. — again, but I was told the other day that the late Chief Civil Commandant threatened him with an action if he did not keep quiet about the post-office. Though I do not believe that Mr. — has been intimidated, still such things are not pleasant. As for the post-office of Accra, there have been many things done which would...

**NOVEMBER 23, 1863.**

**53**

stand a close scrutiny. Especially the postage is a cause of much inconvenience. The post-office of Accra is only a branch office, and the letters have all to be landed at Cape Coast again, to be stamped there. I know that this causes much inconvenience. Calculations of postage are often incorrect, or rather, they differ with the calculation of the post-office officer. I have known of letters prepaid to Switzerland, and when they arrived there, the postage was demanded again. On complaint, the postmaster gave the reply, that the letters must have been sent on board directly, instead of sending through the office (!!) Now, of course it is difficult to prove that the letters were sent to the office and paid for, because only one person is sent with the letters, and he cannot produce any witness to substantiate the charge. **Why are we, on the Coast of Africa, still deprived of the benefit of stamps? Why do our postmasters not allow us to fix English postage-stamps, which we buy in England, upon our letters, and by these means save the postmaster from temptations?** There was once a secretary to the Chief Civil Commandant who used to keep the money, and either crossed out the "paid" or kept the letters back altogether. When he saw that this and other mischief was coming to light, he disappeared.

There are several shocking murders reported among the Go and Croboe people.—Faithfully yours,', 'last_edit_date': '1863-10-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Discontinuance of the Post-office Subsidy for West African Letters', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The arrangement which had hitherto subsisted between the British Post-office authorities and the African Steamship Company for the conveyance of mails, once a month, with specified days for departure and arrival, and which came to an end last month, has not been succeeded by any new one. Consequently there is no monthly mail packet, and the steamers of the 24th of each month will no longer be under any obligation, as regards the Post-office, to leave on that day, or to call at the same ports as before. If they continue to do so, it will be because it suits the Company's arrangements, or its agreements with the British and African Steam Navigation Company, made during the existence of the contract with the Post-office. One or two deviations from the former practice have already been notified. The Gambia will be henceforth cut off from all direct steam communication with Great Britain; and it seems quite possible that the Cameroons will also be no longer visited. As there is, or is to be, an intercolonial steamer between Bathurst and Sierra Leone, the only practical difference will be, as regards letters, to and from Bathurst, that they will be some time longer _en route_. This, at least, is all the difference that the Post-office authorities will see, even if they care to look at all into a matter so very insignificant to them; while, as regards the people at the Gambia, we rather fancy, by what we have heard from time to time, that the leading mercantile houses there, all of whom have ships of their own, or charter ships out and home, will not weary the Government with prayers for restoration of direct communication. We shall soon hear how the change affects our Native African friends, and shall not fail to make known their views; although, since our successful labours in their behalf to prevent their being handed over, like so many sheep or oxen, to France, we have, with a few exceptions, received no payment from our nominal subscribers at the Gambia. It is not our intention at this moment to prejudge the working of the new system as regards the West Coast generally; but important interests have of late grown up there, to which something like certainty as to the time of arrival and departure of at least one of the monthly steamers, may be of importance. While writing this, on the eighteenth day of the month, the fact is before us that neither the steamer marked as due on the 8th inst., nor the one marked as due on the 14th inst., has yet arrived at Liverpool; contrasting unfavourably with the appointed monthly mail steamers which have rarely been more than a day or two overtime; and on those occasions the delay has been owing to unavoidable circumstances. Of course we must expect free steamers to look entirely after their own interests; and that cargo, rather than a strict adherence to any specified time, will be the object of importance with them. Here we shall let the matter rest for the present. We thought it necessary to give prominence to the fact of the change which has taken place, in this way, that every one on the West Coast may be made aware of it; and the subject will be noticed by us in future from time to time as circumstances may demand.", 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are sorry to learn that, although some of the post-office abuses were remedied, the old leaven still works. The fault, therefore, must necessarily be at the Bathurst Post-office, and a further reform there is indispensable. The following letter, accompanying other documents, has reached us from a reliable source:—', 'last_edit_date': '1864-10-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Currency and Other Grievances of African Traders', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Chairman of the African Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has received a memorial, signed by traders and residents at Bathurst, protesting against the transference of the Gambia mail service from British to French vessels, detailing grievances in regard to the currency of the settlement, and asking the co-operation of the Chamber of Commerce in enlisting public sympathy.

We learn with much regret that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has been pleased to direct that the subsidy at present paid for the monthly mail service between Liverpool and this settlement should be discontinued, as he is informed that the general feeling in the settlement was against its continuance. We cannot suppress our feelings of surprise at the above statement, and at such a seeming disregard respecting a matter which so much concerns our interests, as represented in the memorial, addressed in May last to the Colonial Office, on behalf of the West African settlements, protesting against the measure from the outset. In the face of the facts set forth in this memorial, it is impossible to doubt that the discontinuance of the mail service, hitherto carried on by the British and African Steam Navigation Company, will seriously affect our commercial relationship with the merchants and manufacturers interested in the trade of the Gambia. The establishment of our trading connexion direct with Great Britain is due entirely to the maintenance of the monthly mail communication by the steamers running between Liverpool and the settlement, and but for which it might have been impossible.

We, therefore, regard with serious apprehension the ruin which threatens an enterprise which many of us have embarked in in the earliest days of our lives, and which will cut off from us the fruits which it has been our desire to enjoy in old days. Not only will such a measure cut off our source of supplies, but oblige us to be at the mercy of the French merchants, who already command the trade; and we shall be deprived of the facilities which hitherto have enabled us to maintain competition with our French neighbours in the trade, and will cause tastes and preferences by the natives in the interior of the district, and the wish of the natives for British manufactures will be checked.

The discontinuance of the mail service will also affect the export trade in ground nuts, which has been only recently created, and the results of which have led us to hope that a fair field of competition would be opened against the French market, where the great bulk of this produce has hitherto been consigned. By the service of the mail steamers, cheap food and provisions are within the reach of all classes in the community, and, in the event of this service being discontinued, a state of things altogether unpleasant will be brought about by those in whose hands the advantage lies.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West African Mail', 'section_title': '', 'content': "## WEST AFRICAN MAILS.—OFFICIAL NOTICE.

**GENERAL POST OFFICE, OCTOBER 9, 1872.**—The contract made between Her Majesty's Government and the African Steamship Company, in July, 1866, for the conveyance of mails to and from the West Coast of Africa, has terminated. Notice will be given as soon as any arrangements for the future conveyance of letters, &c., to the several ports on the West Coast have been concluded; and, in the meantime, such letters, &c., will be dispatched by each opportunity that offers.

## WEST AFRICAN MAIL.

**LIVERPOOL, Oct. 19.**—The British and African Steam Navigation Company's steamer, Volta, arrived here to-day with a quantity of specie and eleven passengers, as per list at foot.

Trade was about being re-opened at Lagos, in consequence of the roads from the interior to the Coast being unobstructed by the natives.

Mr. Anderson, one of the negotiators of the Liberian Loan, had been shot at Monrovia in some private dispute.

At nearly all the ports on the West Coast the health and trade were generally good.", 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MAILS FOR THE WEST & SOUTH-WEST COASTS OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '(Correspondence for Sierra Leone, Sherbro, Cape Coast Castle and Accra will not be sent by the steamers of May 5 and 19, unless specially so superscribed, as the direct Packets leaving on the following Saturdays are due at those ports some days earlier.)

hh: The concentration of government appointments among a few unqualified individuals in colonial Africa led to inefficiencies, dissatisfaction, and corruption.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of how the concentration of government appointments among a few unqualified individuals in colonial Africa led to inefficiencies, dissatisfaction, and corruption. The General History of Africa highlights how colonial powers often appointed chiefs and leaders without traditional legitimacy, transforming them into administrative officers rather than genuine leaders. This manipulation eroded the prestige and respect for traditional rulers, sparking revolts and dissatisfaction among the populace. The reliance on intermediary structures, such as 'warrant chiefs,' further exacerbated discontent as these individuals were seen as instruments of control rather than partners. The systematic exclusion of educated Africans from positions of responsibility created an artificial scarcity of qualified administrative personnel, contributing to inefficiencies and dissatisfaction. However, the textbook does not explicitly link these issues to corruption. In contrast, The African Times articles explicitly address corruption, illustrating how multiple government positions were often concentrated in the hands of a single individual, such as Dr. Sherwood, who held numerous roles but was unable to perform all duties effectively, leading to inefficiencies and reliance on underpaid assistants. The exclusion of qualified natives from government positions in favor of a few favored individuals often resulted in corruption and mismanagement, as seen with officials like Admiral Patey, whose incompetence and dishonesty led to unchecked financial practices. The articles also discuss systemic issues, such as the lack of representation and accountability, which exacerbated inefficiencies and corruption. Together, these sources illustrate how the concentration of power among unqualified individuals contributed to widespread administrative failures and public discontent in colonial Africa.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that the concentration of government appointments among a few unqualified individuals in colonial Africa led to inefficiencies, dissatisfaction, and corruption. This concentration of roles is criticized for being unjustifiable and leading to inefficiencies, as Dr. Sherwood was unable to perform all his duties effectively and had to rely on underpaid assistants. Furthermore, the articles discuss the broader systemic issues, such as the lack of representation and accountability in the colonial administration, which exacerbated the inefficiencies and corruption. These observations align with the claim by illustrating how the concentration of power in the hands of a few unqualified individuals contributed to widespread administrative failures and public discontent in colonial Africa.

[{'id': 595, 'article_title': 'Want of Employment in the Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'Want of Employment in the Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'Sir,—Whilst this cry is being uttered by many intelligent persons in this place, I am sorry to find that the few official gentlemen holding the Civil Government offices are so pressed with offices as to cause a universal cry among them of "We are incapable of performing all our appointments together."

As an illustration, I shall give you the names of a few, and the various offices they hold, and ask, is it justifiable on the part of the authorities here to confine Government appointments only to a few persons? or is it so in every other of Her Majesty's settlements?'}, {'id': 595, 'article_title': 'Want of Employment in the Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'Want of Employment in the Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': '

I commence with our Colonial Surgeon, Dr. Sherwood, who, besides this, is holder of several other appointments, which would do for five other persons, if no distinction of colour was made; for he is also the "Overseer of Palm Wine," "Clerk of Council," "Registrar of the Vice-Admiralty Court," "Coroner," and "Sheriff." To discharge his duties as Overseer of Palm Wine, which he knows nothing of, he employed a young man (who was doing this work for our now Acting Secretary, whilst holding it, for upwards of three years, if my memory serves me right) for a small salary, not half the amount it produces. Then, as "Clerk of Council," is it right that every one should be acquainted with the transactions of the meetings? If he cannot keep the minutes himself, ought he not at least to employ a proper person, who would seek his own interest by not divulging the contents of the book in which records are made? Instead of which, he employs any one he can first get after Council-day. Go to Mr. Barrack Surgeon. He will tell you as clearly all about it as if he were present at the meeting; or to Mr. Hospital Clerk, or to our Wesleyan schoolmaster, who will be sure to tell you. But these are not all. He gives this book to any writer he chances to meet first—say to any one who will take little or nothing for doing it, and who, not being bound to secrecy, may show it to any of his friends. Thus the subject of our councils is universally known directly. But notwithstanding this assistance of the black young men to this man in making money, they are to him as vinegar is to the teeth: he hates them with an inveterate hatred. Our Collector of Customs is, too, a holder of three other appointments—viz., "Registrar of Courts," "Clerk of the Crown," and "Superintendent of Pilotage." Our late Postmaster, of whom you have been complaining, is now "Clerk in the Customs Department," "Bonded Storekeeper," and "Storekeeper of the Merchant Gunpowder Magazine." For the latter appointment he is receiving a liberal salary, out of which he is paying a man 1l. 8s. per month. Thus, then, you see that our Government appointments are confined only to a few. It is with extreme regret that I have also to complain of our Colonial Hospital, to which, if a native who may have arrived but two days from the mainland be sent for medicine, or to remain there to receive medical attendance, it would be refused, although he might be dying. But I believe the reason is that the doctor has committed the charge of the hospital to a young man who was once cook's mate on board the Kelpie, and is now employed as Colonial Dispenser. On the 18th inst. a native gentleman, in conformity with a notice which has lately appeared to the public, that "every person or persons who may require medicine should send to this department for the same with cash," sent to them for I don't know exactly what. The answer was, "You, Sir, must not consider this place as Mr. Quin's or Messrs. Forster and Smith's shop, where you can buy a half yard of baft,"...'}, {'id': 1116, 'article_title': 'River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': '05-18-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_06_1867#article-1', 'issue_date': '22_06_1867', 'content': 'Sir,—With the exception of the hospital affairs things are not a bit better here. I do not see what we have gained by changing Colonel D'Arcy (most unfit though he was to be at the head of affairs) for Admiral Patey—a naval officer of less than ordinary intelligence; while the evils of the new system (as I suppose we are to call the present chaos) invented by "the African Soapy Sam" (Governor-General Blackall's present popular cognomen) are becoming every day more ridiculously and ruinously apparent. Just look at this. Admiral Patey is not only Administrator, but is also Collector of Customs, Cashier, Colonial Treasurer, &c., &c. If he were a capable man perhaps this might pass, but I do not believe that he has the slightest idea of checking or examining the public accounts. The young men managing the different branches of the public service pay into his hands therefore just what money they please. It is only to be hoped that they are all incapable of error as well as of any purposed fraud, but taxpayers think there ought to be some efficient check. Mr. Kneller, the Collector of Customs, left by the April packet on sick leave; Admiral Patey of course succeeded to the office; now Admiral Patey is to go to England—doctors say he must or he will die here—and in his absence the Collector of Customs ought to be Acting Administrator; but as he is away, who is to be Administrator in the absence of both these luminaries? Perhaps "Soapy Sam," who has only just landed, has come up to set this matter right.

You have often before exposed the deplorable state of affairs in our Post-office—but, alas! we have no redress. Our papers are lost as heretofore; in fact, this has become so common, people cease to talk about it; there is nothing for us seemingly but to "grin and bear;" but there is a great public wrong in the Post-office being in its present hands. The Postmaster, who has become a pet of Admiral Patey's, is also Acting Clerk of Courts (the Clerk of Courts being a fiction), Clerk of the Crown, and is to be Colonial Auditor, &c. Now he has been in business, he has failed, has compounded with his creditors—but not paid them the composition—he is still trading, yet he has charge of the money order department, receives money here, gives orders, may or may not trade with the money, has not given, and cannot give any security. Can you wonder that, as the taxpayers are responsible, and would have to pay should there be any loss or defalcation, there should be some uneasiness and grumbling about it? Your comic paper _Punch_ comes out here, and I get a look at it sometimes. I remember his saying that when a man has proved himself utterly incapable for everything else, he has established his fitness for a Government situation. We have pretty good proof here always, from Governor-General downwards, of the correctness of Mr. Punch's view of these matters. Might we not even go to some of your Home Departments—Downing-street, for instance?'}, {'id': 1964, 'article_title': 'GAMBIA—ITS ADMINISTRATION AND THREATENED CESSION.', 'full_section_title': 'GAMBIA—ITS ADMINISTRATION AND THREATENED CESSION.', 'last_edit_date': '12-12-1870', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1871#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_01_1871', 'content': "To show what an outrageous job this providing a pension for Mr. Richard Pine is, I am bound to state that after the Colony of the Gambia was relieved of this gentleman, as was fondly imagined, by his translation to another colony and a higher office, the appointment of Queen's Advocate was filled up by bestowing it on a gentleman who was clerk in the Custom-house at the Gambia, who managed after he was appointed, by a judicious system of obtaining leave of absence as often as he could, to get called to the bar in England; and this individual has also managed after a few years' service to get a pension on the plea of ill-health of 133l. 6s. 8d. per annum, which he is now drawing from the unhappy Gambia Revenue, although he is present well enough to go to India, where he is adding to his pension by practising in that country, although his health was so ruined as to unfit him for the discharge of the duties of his sinecure on the West Coast of Africa. The hard-working, industrious, toiling population of the Gambia are thus called upon in the short space of eight years to contribute two pensions to two ex-Queen's Advocates. If we go on like this what will be the result? Answer it who can. It may well be said of the Gambia people, *Sic vos non vobis mellificatis apes.* This is piling Pelion upon Ossa with a vengeance.

The people of the Gambia and the public have been told more than once that the great object in establishing and maintaining the settlements thereupon, and other colonies on the West Coast of Africa was for the purpose of suppressing the slave-trade; but now that infamous traffic has disappeared, owing to the high principles and honest loyal dealings of British merchants in the West Coast of Africa, who, by establishing legitimate trade, and opening up the resources of the country, *relying on the support and protection of the mother country,* have rooted out this detestable commerce and developed the true riches and wealth of the West Coast of Africa to a limited extent, are left not only without protection, but are taxed without being represented and compelled to provide outdoor relief for the halt and decrepit so-called public servants, who, from the moment that Imperial protection was withdrawn, have no further claims upon them. The colonists of the settlements on the West Coast of Africa now require all their funds to protect themselves from the inroads of the savage people by whom they are surrounded, and not to have their resources squandered away by incapable worn-out men, appointed by the Colonial-office to discharge functions for which they were never adapted, and frequently, as I have often heard it said, to relieve the purlieus of Downing-street and the Horse Guards of their presence."}]
