[{'document_title': 'A Memorial of the Natives of Bathurst Asking the Remedy of Serious Evils', 'section_title': '', 'content': "To His Excellency Samuel Rowe, C.M.G., Governor-in-Chief of the West African Settlements, &c.

The Memorial of the undersigned native inhabitants of Bathurst respectfully showeth—

1. That your Excellency's memorialists having observed with regret the state of things in Bathurst, humbly crave leave to submit their views to your Excellency, with a request that they should receive your Excellency's consideration.

2. For the past few years a system has been introduced to this Settlement of utilizing convict labour in cases where the labour of mechanics and other artisans is absolutely required. The effect of such an anomalous procedure has been to discourage native industry, and to hamper all exertions tending to the development of their capacities.

3. Your Excellency's memorialists would not be understood to question the right of the government to convict labour in so far as it is available without detriment to the prosperity of the community; they would, however, submit that the practice of apportioning public works amongst convicts and policemen to the utter exclusion of artisans of competent skill in the place is not only displeasing, but is calculated to produce bad work in the Settlement, although money is economically expended on their construction.
**63**

4. As one of the results of this niggardly policy may be instanced the condition of the streets in the rains, when it would be expected that active steps would be taken by the authorities to prevent their being overflowed with water. The drains, already overgrown with weeds, simply through neglect, conduce not a little to the impediments offered to peregrinators, by means of which they are obliged to wade knee-deep in the mud to get to their destinations. Convicts, like any one else without the necessary qualification to perform works of public importance, may be of use in patching up the streets with loose earth to be washed away in the rainy season; whereas if a few more pounds are granted to expend on really competent persons to have the drains properly kept, and the streets macadamized, not only the subsidiary, but the main object of Government would be attained.

5. In former years an impetus was given to the natives, most of whom then fondly believed that encouragement would be continued to them in whatever branch of industry they embarked themselves. The course of action initiated by your Excellency's predecessor in office, has checked your Excellency's memorialists from indulging in these fanciful chimeras. They would, nevertheless, point out a few drawbacks and grievances to their advancement, which it is in your Excellency's power to remedy.", 'last_edit_date': '1879-03-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MISAPPLICATION OF THE GAMBIA REVENUES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It does not much matter in which of the British West African Colonies and Settlements we inquire as to the expenditure of the revenues raised there. The same practice is found to prevail in all of them, with some exception as regards Lagos, where works of public utility have been allowed a share. There is the same squandering of the public money upon official favourites everywhere, and everywhere an almost total neglect of those matters upon which the progress of towns, and districts, and countries depend. But for the present we will take Bathurst. Look at Bathurst. The imposts on trade and commerce have been, within the last three years, most prejudicially increased because of former lavish extravagance. The revenue must be above 20,000l. a-year. The colonial steamer for protecting and assisting trade up the Gambia, which formerly absorbed some 5,000l. a-year, has disappeared from the estimates and from river navigation, and what is being done with the money? In March last we were called upon to notice that, although the revenue has for many years past fluctuated between 15,000l. and 20,000l. a-year, not even a fire-engine has been provided for the town of Bathurst, so that when a fire breaks out in any of the native habitations, there are none of the means used in civilised countries for arresting its progress; there is a general danger, and much loss and privation is the result. In our June number an intelligent correspondent says that on all sides there is deterioration and no renewal—the sea-wall has been allowed to go out of repair, the roads are neglected and have become almost useless; while the writer of another letter in the same number inquires why such and such houses are hired by the local authorities unnecessarily at a great expense of public money, and only for the advantage and profit of some favoured individuals. It is from beginning to end a system of waste. There is so much a-year to be spent, and the question has been, not how much good may be effected for the Colony with it, but who is to have a share in it? Is it not shameful? Is it any wonder that the people complain? Little or nothing done for education; nothing for the assistance or protection of trade on the river; no bridge built over Oyster Creek, so that there may be always an open road into the healthy districts of British Combo;* not even a fire-engine to save the houses of the poor people from destruction; sea-wall out of repair, and roads neglected. We only give these as a sample of the really vital necessities that are not attended to, while what is amply sufficient for these purposes is uselessly squandered in other directions where it only benefits unjustly a few favoured individuals. Do not let us be misunderstood. We do not accuse the present chief local authority, the present Administrator, of squandering the revenue by any acts of favouritism. The worst we should say of him is that he allows the continuance of abuses scandalously perpetrated by others, such as the rental of the houses mentioned by "Public Interest" in our June number. Rather, the complaint made against Admiral Patey is, that having succeeded in getting a large sum into the colonial chest, he is not willing to expend any of it even on those most indispensable works—roads, bridges, and sea-wall.† For a moment there is a fit of official parsimony, and the misapplication consists in shutting that money up in the chest in useless inactivity, which ought to be made the instrument of present and future good to the colony. We venture to call the serious attention of the Administrator, Admiral Patey, to these things. Why should he not make his administration memorable on the Gambia by the correction of old abuses, and the application of some portion of the surplus funds he so happily possesses, on objects that will bring him thanks and blessings from a grateful people. Let him begin by importing that most necessary adjunct of civilisation, a fire-engine; and then form a volunteer fire brigade; teaching the natives how they may most usefully employ themselves in extinguishing a conflagration. We really long for the opportunity of praising Admiral Patey or some other of our West Coast administrators. We have volumes of laudation ready for them if they will only give us proper occasion for using it, for the fact is they have afforded us so little chance of applying any portion of it during the past eight years, that the accumulation on hand is quite embarrassing. We should like to see a healthy emulation among them as to who should establish a claim to the largest portion of it. Will an emulation in good, among West Coast officials really show itself, and gratify our anxious desires? Alas, we are long waiting for it.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Shameful Neglect of the Drains at Bathurst', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, August 15.

Sir,—Will you kindly call attention again to the state of our treasury and the state of our town—the one running over with money, the other with water and filth? Our people are complaining very much; and well they may. Our Administrator, who has gone off again to England this year, seems to think that levying taxes and getting money into the chest is all that is necessary in Government; he does not think of making any improvements, but only to hoard up money. The balance reported at the end of June quarter was 10,000l., yet our streets are now swampy and unpassable from the constant pouring down of the rain during the last few weeks. One passing in the streets has now to wade in water and mud knee deep, because the drains are utterly neglected, and no labourers employed to clean them out, so as to enable them to carry off the water. It is reported that even the merchants, who seem, under the leading of Mr. Brown, to be now our implacable enemies and oppressors, have written a complaint to the Administrator, as they fear that, if the drainage is not immediately attended to, some dreadful sickness will soon come down upon all the inhabitants, white as well as black.—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Bathurst, River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—The rainy season here is about over, though, of course, we shall have some rain in the beginning of next month, with occasional tornadoes. The rains have been so plentiful that the crops promise to be heavy and good, and famine is already disappearing. The season up to the present has been unusually healthy; part of this may be attributed to the improved state of the drains and streets, under supervision of the acting Colonial Engineer. N.B.—This is generally the case when the office is in the hands of an acting man. When the permanent man is here, economy, dirt, and disease go hand in hand.

Thieves have been as plentiful as the rains. Some time ago they broke open the Customs' stores and took three baskets of colar nuts out, had shipped two baskets in a canoe, and were in the act of shipping the third one when they heard the night patrol passing, got frightened, and fled with their canoe, leaving the third basket on the beach. Now, there was one constable as sentry at this store, and another at the Customs' gate across the street, yet neither of these men heard or saw the thieves. Query: Are they and the police in collusion? The fact is, the Government ought to bring in a sort of vagrant law to check the congregation of loafers and bad characters in Bathurst. Such people, having committed crimes in other parts of the river, flock in here, and any day you will see scores, aye, even hundreds, of native men lounging about under trees, sleeping or conversing. These men never work, have no known business; most of them are known to the inhabitants here as bad characters; they remain here for weeks or months until they can make a haul, when they disappear, and are absent as long as the plunder lasts.

The French in Senegal have a good way of dealing with these fellows. The police go round and take down their names each day, inquire their business or occupation, when, if after a reasonable time they are found not to have any business or occupation or visible means of support, they are marched out of the towns.

One of the officials of the Courts here has played a neat little game—if it succeeds. Some time ago he requested an old man here to send up the river and get him a small girl as a slave, from Fody Cubbai, whose raids still continue in the Jolah country, promising to pay whatever price would be demanded. In due time the girl came down in charge of two men—the price asked, 40 dols. Our official takes the delivery of the chattel, and tells the men he will pay them in a few days. They waited, but did not get the money. They began to press him, and at last demanded the girl back. He then told them to come to him, and he would get the money from a friend; so took them to the Police-office, and gave them in charge for slave-dealing, and had", 'last_edit_date': '1880-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1880#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AN AFRICAN, RE THE CHARGES AGAINST ADMIRAL PATEY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "selves to Bathurst, and are always seen within the precincts of the gaol. Mr. Reffles, who has been a sufferer from the loss of 80l. cash and jewellery stolen by one (or more) of those vagabonds (who had no punishment for his hard labour but to be employed as servant to the gaoler) approves of the shot-drill and treadmill system, and had suggested that it would be the only means of relieving the colony of those vagabonds, and the revenue of its large expenses for maintenance, and he is much pleased to learn that it has been so. They can assure you that there was never a time, far back as they could remember, when one per cent. of the real Bathurst inhabitants or their descendants have been found within the walls of Bathurst gaol. Why should such a peaceful people be always molested by foreigners from different colonies, and by being deprived of their small property, which might be increased and would enable them to be in the position of giving their children sound English education and several other things for the benefit of themselves and their country? How keenly would it be felt by one who for twenty years' labour could manage (say only) to lay aside 40l. for his future benefit, and, after all his proposals, to be robbed of this amount? Or, put yourself in the place of that individual—would you not be ready to ask for an increased punishment (they mean reasonable), such as treadmill and shot-drill, so as to prevent your neighbours being served out as you were? Surely you would.", 'last_edit_date': '1870-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1870#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Bathurst, River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'them locked up. Having done this, he went to the old slave broker, and told him the two men were locked up, and that if he—the slave broker—did not run away, he would be locked up also. The old man took the hint and disappeared; the other men were brought before the magistrate, and were remanded for the Sessions. Now this official is but a specimen of Administrative favouritism. He was a notoriously bad character; at one time a convict, afterwards a spy for lawyers, or a bailiff. No one else would employ him; but over two years ago he did some shady business for the Government, and was appointed to office. This was at the time complained of by the colonists, as they considered him a most unsuitable man to hold a trustworthy position, and it was unsafe for the lives or liberties of people to be, to a great extent, under the control of such a man; but our objections were ignored by the Administrator. There have been complaints since of the way he acted in his office. The Government were not limited in choice when they appointed him; they could have chosen from several other candidates, who were quite as capable, but being respectable men, they might have asked a slightly higher salary. But this would not do, as here, men as well as material, must be cheap and—nasty.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1880#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Pestilential Swamps at Bathurst—Remedy', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have received from Gambia copy of a petition signed by about 136 native inhabitants of Bathurst, and which has been recently presented to the Acting Governor-in-Chief, Mr. Pope Hennessy, at Sierra Leone, by a person sent from Bathurst for that purpose. The petitioners describe themselves as liberated Africans, Jolloffs, and their descendants,—natives of Bathurst, and British subjects. It would be quite impossible for us, under any circumstances, to insert this lengthy petition in our columns, independently of its containing some very strong statements which we could not print without having producible evidence in our hands to justify us in so doing. We will, however, endeavour to state in brief the substance of the petition. The petitioners refer to military services in defence of the colony formerly rendered by them; state how much they were opposed to the sometime-since projected cession of the Gambia to France, which opposition, they affirm, brought on them the ire of Sir Arthur Kennedy; and declare their willingness to act as an armed police and take charge of the barracks (as they formerly did), provided they may have their own countrymen as sergeants and corporals, and not be placed under Sierra Leone men. They then call his Excellency’s attention to the filthy state of Bathurst, owing to the want of a proper town inspector, and an experienced local engineer. Also, to the great grievance of insolvent laws not having been introduced in the colony; and to the grievous injury resulting to them as traders, owing to the want of adequate protection in the river, as exposed in a letter addressed to the Administration in June last, by the European merchants, &c., for the information of the Secretary of State for the Colonies. They there allude bitterly to the fact of offices which they are competent to fill being now in the hands of Sierra Leone men, imported into the colony expressly, to be there advanced over their heads, and call for the dismissal of those persons, as well as of others who have served their full term of years, and the appointment of some of their own number to the offices then made vacant. This is followed by allegations of a very serious nature against Captain Cooper, the actual Acting Administrator, and Dr. Spilsbury (an African of Sierra Leone), the Colonial Surgeon. The concluding paragraph of the petition prays for an inquiry into the amounts that have been levied upon them during twenty-two years, in yearly rates, market, ferry, and Customs’ dues, and whether these have not been sufficient, if properly applied, to drain the town, pave the footpaths, &c.

THE KINGS AND CHIEFS OF THE FANTI CONFEDERATION.  
TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.  
Cape Coast, November 28, 1872.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-01-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bathurst Complaints', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are indeed pained to learn, from the Memorial addressed by some of the native inhabitants of Bathurst to the Governor-General at Sierra Leone, that the injudicious and dangerous economy and neglect which we have in other years exposed continues at this town on the Gambia. This indifference and neglect, which we feel justified in designating criminal, not only interferes with the progress of civilization, but subjects the community, both European and native, to renewed outbreaks of those destroying pestilences which have from time to time decimated the town of Bathurst. Year after year the educated native inhabitants, as well as Europeans, have protested against the continued permission by the authorities to the natives from the river villages who flock to Bathurst for trade, to perambulate the town in a state of nudity, and perform all the operations of nature when and where they choose, without the slightest regard to decency, and in defiance of all sanitary regulations which ought to be enforced in any town under British rule and law. We are at a loss to understand why such things should be—why British officials should continue to tolerate them, as if a decree had gone forth that it was not desirable that the blessings of civilization should extend in Africa. Bathurst, and all other towns on the Coast under British government, ought to be brought fully under civilized regulations, and become spots from which civilization should radiate into the neighbouring territories. That they should not be this, is a gross neglect of duty on the part of the authorities, and reflects deep disgrace on Great Britain. It is absurd to suppose that there could be any real difficulty in insisting upon public decency within the town of Bathurst. While the unclothed natives from the river villages are allowed to come into the town in their unclothed condition, and treat the town in every way as if it were the bush or fields in which they reside, they will no doubt continue to do so, and look with ignorant and barbarous contempt upon the inhabitants who are not permitted, and would no longer permit themselves, the offensive freedom from all self-restraint which they, the "untutored savages," enjoy. Is it too much to expect that British authority will now at last interfere on the side of decency and health? The "untutored savage" would not forego the substantial benefits he or she derives from his or her visits to Bathurst because compelled to wear a proper cloth and conform to certain sanitary regulations; and, accustomed to these self-restraints within the town of Bathurst, they will thus have entered, however superficially, into the arena of civilization, and become more accessible to the propaganda of civilization among themselves. Important, however, as this change for which we call would really prove to be, it is but secondary when viewed in connection with that continued neglect of the drains, and that continuous horrible condition of the place of sepulture, respecting which the Memorialists protest. Everyone who has watched and recorded the ravages of epidemics on the West Coast of Africa must remember but too well the awful visitations to which Bathurst has been subject. Only last year it was threatened with one of them, and not a few persons perished from its advancing breath, when, happily, a sudden meteorological change drove back the fearful enemy. In some of our letters we find fears expressed that the present season may be rather an unhealthy one on the West Coast, and the mere suspicion that it will be so ought to induce precaution on the part of individuals and authorities. The latter are to a certain extent answerable for the lives of the population over whom they rule; they are fully answerable to the extent of removable causes; and among removable causes, that of pestilential drains, of filthy thoroughfares, and of graveyards in which the decaying dead are exposed to public view, filling the atmosphere with poisonous gases, must certainly be included. By the time this number of our journal reaches Bathurst the fiend of pestilence may—though we fervently pray it will not—may, we say, be upon the town. Should such, unhappily, be the case—should there be a new holocaust of victims offered up on the shrine of official incompetency, indifference, or neglect,—we shall cry loudly for retribution on those who shall have thus trifled with the lives of a community, to protect and defend which is one of the most sacred of the duties with which they are charged.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'All labour is performed by the domestic slaves of the family, who, as a rule, are kindly treated, and are not often parted with, except under circumstances of necessity.

There is some reason to suppose that coloured traders and trading agents, when following their avocations at a distance from the settlements, occasionally engage in slave-dealing transactions with the natives; but these operations are conducted beyond British jurisdiction, and as yet it has been found impossible to bring any case home to an offender.

In point of unhealthiness the climate of the Gambia probably varies little from that of the other settlements. There is considerable sickness during and after the rains; but many of the merchants, finding that their business makes but light demands upon them during that season, are in the habit of passing in England the worst months of the year. Military officers who suffer in health to any considerable extent are at once invalided, and civil officers are afforded every facility for obtaining the advantages of a change of climate: thus not only are very few Europeans compelled to remain in the colony for any length of time without a change, but there is also a consequent diminution in the number of deaths from the effects of the climate.

It has often been urged that the unhealthiness of the Gambia is largely due to the unfavourable situation of Bathurst, the capital and seat of trade, on the low-lying and swampy Island of St. Mary, and it has been suggested that a great improvement would be effected in this respect by the removal of the seat of government to the more airy and elevated situation of Cape St. Mary.

There can be no question of the superior healthiness of the Cape, and on this account alone the transfer would be very desirable; but

although the government offices might be removed there, it is certain that the merchants would not on this account alone consent to incur the heavy expense of moving their store-houses and long-established places of business from the safe anchorage and convenient landing-places of the river to the exposed situation of St. Mary, which is in no respect so well adapted for the purposes of trade. So long, therefore, as Bathurst remains the seat of trade, it is necessary for its convenience that the custom-house and other public offices connected with it should not be removed from its neighbourhood.

One cause of the unhealthiness of Bathurst is the existence in the immediate neighbourhood of the town of an offensive and pestilent swamp; but from a recent report of Major Clarke, R.E., it appears that, for the sum of about 7,000£, the whole space, covering nearly 1,000 acres, could be closely and efficiently drained. Unfortunately, the circumstances of the colony forbid the hope that it will for a considerable time to come be in a position to afford this outlay, even for a work of such paramount importance to its interests.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE TORTURE SYSTEM IN CAPE COAST PRISON.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have no doubt there have been and are some honourable men connected with the Cape Coast administration who have deplored what was going on, but who, not being legally responsible, overlooked their moral responsibility, because they could not admit it without interfering with heads of departments or denouncing those with whom they were compelled to live and associate. It is thus, where there is no organ of public opinion, that evils and abuses grow and abound, until they attain to an offensive turpitude that renders it impossible for them to be longer concealed. And then they come upon the world like the pestilential vapour of some rotten marsh, where the poison has loaded a dead atmosphere, which becomes at last overcharged. Such a marsh and such an atmosphere may well be said to describe Cape Coast, if all that we hear be true, and a strong wind of public indignation and Government power alone can purify them.

We sympathise strongly with the authorities at home when charges of this nature are brought against their officials in such a colony as that of Cape Coast. It is so difficult for them to ascertain the truth or falsehood of the accusations thus made. They cannot be expected on every such occasion to send out a commission of inquiry; they must feel great reluctance, and even repugnance, to discredit in any way their employés, whom it is necessary, in the interests of the public service to support as much as possible. They seem, therefore, to have no other course.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1864#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Official Favouritism and Waste', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—We have scarcely any news of importance to communicate.

The town of Bathurst, thanks to Acting-Administrator Mr. Berkeley, is now in a better condition than it has been for the past few years; but, alas! the reign of selfishness and of petticoat government has again been forced upon the people of Bathurst, for Governor Gouldsbury has resumed the government, after a promenade from Bathurst to Timbo, and thence to Sierra Leone. Mr. Berkeley's post as Collector and Treasurer is to be held during his six months' absence on leave by Mr. J. C. Bauer, our Colonial Engineer of blushing notoriety. This is as things should be, judging from the interest taken by Dr. Gouldsbury in Mr. Bauer.

It is difficult to conceive why a man utterly unfit to discharge the duties of his office, as Mr. Bauer is, who at the same time has already more than enough on hand, and having to see to the construction of the Oyster Creek Bridge, about four miles from Bathurst (a laugh!), besides which, as the Inspector of Nuisance, whose service is specially required in the rains, should have been singled out as the best officer on the spot to hold the acting appointment of Collector and Treasurer.

It is evident, as the duties in Mr. Berkeley's absence will necessarily fall to the lot of the neglected native officials, both at the Treasury and Customs, that Governor Gouldsbury, in view of heaping imaginary honours upon the head of the Colonial Engineer, has thought fit to crown this officer's useful labours with some official mark of recognition.

Mr. Bauer may no doubt be an excellent officer in the eyes of Dr. Gouldsbury, and we might hope the film that has covered those eyes of the doctor for the past few years would one day be removed, and the deep interest soon be clashed by some sort of a reaction.

If we turn to review the Colonial Engineer's Department since Dr. Gouldsbury's administration, we shall find that, although parsimonious in the extreme where doubtful interest is not concerned, although all public improvements have been neglected, although all public buildings are in a dilapidated condition, Dr. Gouldsbury has allowed many thousands of pounds to be actually wasted by the Colonial Engineer.

Let an inquiry be instituted, and an account of the cost of that Department for the past four years be prepared. At the same time let the Department be fully credited with any useful work done, minus the several works begun, money wasted upon, and eventually abandoned. Let all these be done, and we know what the result would be.

"But," says Dr. Gouldsbury, "the Colonial Engineer is a very good officer." He may be so in his estimation, and no wonder, for he may have his reasons; if, however, those reasons were of a public nature, the public would long ago have known and appreciated them.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-07-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Memorial of the Natives of Bathurst Asking the Remedy of Serious Evils', 'section_title': '', 'content': "6. The cemetery of Bathurst requires attention. During the spring tide of last year, the local government felt itself compelled, perhaps for its own safety, to proclaim that those of your Excellency's memorialists whose relations' coffins were exhumed by water should look after their dead, no precaution whatever having been taken to preserve the remains of those for whose memory your Excellency's memorialists cherish the highest respect in God's acre. A mock attempt to keep away the water by Mr. Bauer, the engineer, whose signal failure your Excellency's memorialists are willing to attribute to the parsimony of the government, which endeavoured to make use of mangrove and empty barrels to stop the sea encroachments, instead of erecting substantial dykes, or embankments for the purpose. The safety of the people could hardly have been in contemplation of the government, or steps in the right direction might have been taken to bring about this desirable end.

7. Gutters are urgently needed at Half Die. The streets in that part of the town are literally overflowed with water, on the subsidence of which a very sickening smell is produced by the filth generated by fecal matters, whose decomposition is accelerated by stagnant waters. The construction of sewers would drain off those offensive matters, and render the atmosphere pure and wholesome.

8. Dry earth closets are in great demand in this settlement. The expense of erecting these is trifling when compared with the beneficial results that would flow from them. Strangers visiting these shores very often find themselves obliged to attend to the calls of nature, in places where a sense of decency should deter them from using. The reason for this is to be found in the want of public closets. Regret is often expressed at the unhealthiness of Bathurst, which is to a great extent enhanced by the filthy habits of Mandingoes, and other aboriginal tribes who come to Bathurst for trading purposes. The erection of these closets, in various parts of the town, would lessen the unhealthiness produced by the stench emanating from the excrements and nuisances of the tribes alluded to. *Your Excellency's memorialists humbly solicit that an ordinance be passed declaring it unlawful for Jolahs, Sereres, and others to walk the streets stark naked.*

9. In connection with the matter lastly herein above alluded to, may be mentioned the desirability of appointing a sanitary inspector or water police, whose duty should be to prevent the sick that are brought from the rivers, and foreign places, being thrown on the wharves to take care of themselves, or die. The establishment of a water police force, apart from effecting the object herein mentioned, would restrain dishonest persons from infringing the revenue laws of this Settlement, and from making clandestine removal of goods at night.", 'last_edit_date': '1879-03-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Weeping and mourning are at the Gambia; desolation and woe have fallen upon the unhappy town of Bathurst. A pestilential fever, against the threatened approaches of which no efforts at prevention were made by ignorant, incapable, and criminally erring officials, marched up from the foetid swamp, descended into the habitations of rich and poor, European and native; and death, terror, and dismay reigned supreme over all. The graphic letter on our 2nd page tells a little of the fatal tale. The Chief Magistrate, a young man in the full vigour and strength of life, four Europeans, and three natives, fell victims in one day. Well might the poor stricken people believe that this was only the vanguard of the Yellow Fever which had made its ravages at Senegal; and against the probable coming of which we had warned the besotted officials, who were too intent, each on his own little game, to heed our earnest entreaties to set their house in order. A heavy responsibility for the precious lives that have been taken away, should lie at the door of those whose duty it was to take adequate measures for the preservation of the public health. The large surplus which is the present boast of the Gambia Treasury—to create which the public service has in many ways been starved, and for creating which personal promotion is no doubt expected—is now made loathsome by the putrid corpses of victims whose lives have been sacrificed to it. Cynics and profound moralists equally affirm, that at the present time nothing is worshipped but money. The officials of Gambia and Sierra Leone may be adduced in support of the truth of this stigma. We earnestly hope the results will not be as fatal in the latter place as in the former. But when blundering, incapacity, and selfishness had done their worst, a kind Providence stepped in with its healthy Harmattan wind, and the pestilence gradually abated. We hope the influence of that health-giving wind will be felt at other parts of the Coast. Its absence last year was deeply deplored at Lagos, where small-pox and other fatal diseases then prevailed. But although the pestilence has been killed for a time at Bathurst by the Harmattan, we hope the present safety will not renew the guilty official apathy; and that the lives of the inhabitants will be deemed of more value than a few hundreds of pounds, more or less, in the Treasury. We say advisedly, guilty official apathy. Look at paragraphs in a letter from Bathurst in our last month's paper, page 2: "The streets and drains are very dirty, the effluvia from the latter very bad; the native yards in a filthy state; and though we pay local rates of 400l. a year, and there is a surplus now in the Treasury of 6,000l., yet not a penny can or will be spared for sanitary measures, because Mr. Bauer" (the Colonial Engineer) "will not act;" and yet we are face to face with a most sickly season; fever fast approaching to an epidemic in virulence; deaths are rapid and numerous, natives as well as Europeans. Still nothing is done!" Our correspondent goes on to say that some months ago, "We sent a petition to the Colonial Secretary, complaining of the inefficiency of the Engineer Department, asked for a Board of Inquiry, and engaged to substantiate all our charges. Dr. Gouldsbury" (the Administrator, who is a most intimate friend of Mr. Bauer and his family) "wrote to Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, to the effect that our statements were false; our complaints personal feeling; that Mr. Bauer was a 'most zealous and efficient officer,' &c. The Colonial Secretary wrote back to us to the effect that, in view of the Governor's report, he gave no credence to our statements, and would not grant any inquiry." In other words, the memorialists of Bathurst had the lie given to them, in the same way that it was also given to those of Sierra Leone; in both cases upon the mere ipse dixit of the erring Governor. Alas! what a commentary on all this is the fearful mortality that has plunged Bathurst into wailing, lamentation, and woe; a mortality distinctly traceable to Engineering and Administrative favouritism and incapacity or heartless indifference. Do not these events furnish a startling proof of the necessity of combined action on the West Coast, that all the settlements and populations, European merchants as well as natives, should have our constant help to bring their wants and just complaints in such a way before Her Majesty's Government, that it shall not be in the power of erring officials, however high their grade, to call down Imperial insult on an injured people; and obstruct the course of reforms on which the lives of the inhabitants and the prosperity of the Settlement depend?', 'last_edit_date': '1879-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1879#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CONDITION OF THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '5. Although rates are regularly levied for the purpose of repairing drains and making other local improvements in Bathurst, and the attention of the Administration has been repeatedly directed to this subject, yet the sanitation of the town is in a most neglected condition, and Half Die and Newtown, the most unhealthy localities, left to take care of themselves. In the rainy season, the town is generally inundated from want of responsible persons to take care of the Sluice Gates, causing great loss and damage to property. The Colonial Engineer, whom the Colony pays £550 a year, is always on leave during the rains, when his presence is most needed to study the condition of the place.

6. An Ordinance to repeal the Trade License Ordinance, 1893, and to make other provisions in lieu thereof, was passed at the Legislative Council held on the 18th ult. The provisions of the Ordinance in question are one-sided, and, above all, unconstitutional. The Colony is dependent for its prosperity on the trade carried on in the Rivers. Local taxes as such cannot bring a Revenue, and when the Administration under the pretext of protecting the large mercantile houses, which are well able to take care of themselves, from being defrauded by their traders, restricts liberty of commerce in the rivers and renders it possible for licenses to be arbitrarily refused to applicants for the same, it deals a fatal blow to the prosperity of the Colony whose resources, as it is well known, are very limited. Section 4 of the Ordinance reads as follows:—

"That it shall be lawful for the Colonial Treasurer or any such Commissioner to refuse to issue a license to any applicant, unless such applicant shall first produce a certificate signed by a member of either the Executive or Legislative Council and by two Justices of the Peace that he is of good character and a fit and proper person to be entrusted with such license."

The chief objection to this section is that it is unconstitutional, and interferes arbitrarily with the liberties of a British subject. It also opens a wide field for abuse, and practically places the liberties of the entire trading community in the hands of three unofficial members of the Executive or Legislative Council who are themselves merchants. All men are human, business men not excepted; and would it not be a source of temptation for men wielding such a power to place obstacles in the way of their fellow competitors, the other mercantile firms and small business houses? The section providing for the revocation of licenses is also impolitic. It follows that all traders who cannot obtain a license, or whose licenses may be revoked, will be obliged to flock at Bathurst to become a source of danger to the community, as all unemployed necessarily are under the pressure of want and distress.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.649, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial administrations in Africa faced significant challenges and inefficiencies in urban planning and infrastructure development, often neglecting local needs and knowledge.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles both provide compelling evidence supporting the claim that colonial administrations in Africa faced significant challenges and inefficiencies in urban planning and infrastructure development, often neglecting local needs and knowledge. The textbook highlights that infrastructure such as roads and railways was primarily constructed to facilitate the extraction of resources and connect production areas to the world market, rather than to promote overall economic development or inter-African communication. This infrastructure was inadequate and unevenly distributed, with many areas, especially those not rich in natural resources, being neglected. Urban planning often replicated European models, alienating Africans from their communal sensibilities. Additionally, the colonial focus on cash crops led to the neglect of the internal economy, causing food shortages and necessitating imports. The text also notes that colonial administrations did not prioritize industrialization or the development of local industries, further exacerbating economic disparities. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight issues such as poor sanitary conditions in towns like Cape Coast, with a lack of public facilities and ineffective municipal laws leading to health hazards. In Bathurst, essential infrastructure like fire engines, roads, and sea walls was neglected, with mismanagement of funds and prioritization of official favoritism over public utility. The failure of the Colonial Engineer in Bathurst, whose mismanagement of drainage and water supply projects resulted in public health risks and wasted resources, is also noted. Furthermore, the articles criticize the lack of investment in improving communications and public works, with revenues hoarded rather than spent on necessary improvements. While the articles do not explicitly discuss the role of local knowledge, both sources illustrate the colonial administrations' inefficiencies and disregard for local needs, underscoring the broader neglect and mismanagement characteristic of colonial urban planning and infrastructure development in Africa.

[{'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the economic field', 'content': "Was the colonial impact on Africa in the economic field, then, such a very enviable one? Far from it, and most of the present-day developmental problems facing African countries can be traced to this.
In the first place, as M. H. Y. Kaniki has pointed out above (Chapter 16), the infrastructure that was provided by colonialism was not as adequate nor as useful as it could have been. Most of the roads and railways were constructed not to open up the country but merely to connect the areas having mineral deposits and potentialities for the production of cash crops with the sea or, to quote Fieldhouse, 'to link internal areas of production to the world commodity market',$^{20}$ and there were hardly any feeder or branch roads. Nor were they meant to facilitate inter-African travel and communication. Such infrastructure as was provided was meant, then, to facilitate the exploitation of the resources of the colonies and to link them with the metropolitan countries but not to promote the over all economic development of Africa nor to promote inter-African contacts. In the second place, such economic growth as occurred in the colonies was based on the natural resources of the area and this meant therefore that areas not naturally endowed were totally neglected. This led to sharp economic differences in the same colony. These differences, in turn, accentuated and exacerbated regional differences and sentiments which have been a great impediment in the way of nation-building in independent Africa.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy: the former British zones', 'section_title': 'Infrastructure', 'content': "One of the most important aspects of marketing is infrastructure. The construction of railways, roads, telegraph lines and harbours received the attention of the colonial administrations quite early on. Though these facilities helped in the general administration, their main task was to evacuate exports. No wonder therefore that the location and general direc› tion of railways and roads took little account of the general welfare of the dependencies. Most railways ran directly from the coast to interior sources of cash crops or mineral deposits. Only a few lateral and inter-colonial links were established. Railways therefore served only limited areas, and, important as they have been, their role in 'opening up' the continent has certainly been exaggerated.$^{86}$ Only in Southern Rhodesia and South Africa were there more sophisticated railway networks, mainly intended to connect and serve the widely-scattered mining areas and settler farming regions. The cocoa belt of the southern Gold Coast, too, was well served by railways, while the Northern Territories with no export crops, were completely ignored. (See Figs 16.2, 16.3.)
Most of the railways were constructed, owned, and operated by govern› ments or official agencies. Construction of the first railway in British West Africa took place in Sierra Leone during the 1890s. The first train started operating in the colony area in 1897, and by 1909 the main line, crossing the rich palm oil belt to Pendembu, in the east (365 km) had been completed. A branch line from Bubuyan to Makeni in the north (132 km) was opened in 1915. Soon after the work started in Sierra Leone, other dependencies followed her example with even better results. All major lines were built by 1920. In Tanganyika the British inherited the two railways constructed by the Germans earlier during the twentieth century.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The arts in Africa during the period of colonial rule', 'section_title': 'African architecture', 'content': "The cities continued to be developed either as replicas or adaptations of European urban planning, or, as already stated, in rigid 'grid' forms which aided the depersonalization of the African, and his alienation from his communal sensibility. Nevertheless, it must be conceded that pockets of traditional housing were successfully inserted in the heart of the alien structures which rose all over the landscape. Tucked neatly away in the 'high-rising' centres of even the capital cities of the Belgian Congo (now Zaire), Senegal, the Gold Coast (Ghana), Nigeria, Angola, etc., are traditional compounds, overshadowed by the concrete edifices, which date back to the nineteenth century. They are usually centred on a communal well. A circular or rectangular veranda opens into the courtyard and a series of family residences are linked to a common roof and drainage systems which unite and flow into the open gutters on the main streets. Even where the houses consist of more than one floor, the spatiality and interplay of planes reveal the same liberating quality. The contribution of the Brazilian returnees to the continent was, in this respect, quite immense. Even in the minor cities of the African hinterland, isolated instances of an arrested development of traditional architecture from this period continue to create a sense of aesthetic loss in this most immediate of man's creative and utilitarian productions. The modern urban city in Africa constantly reminds one that the environment was never transformed on its own terms, but in the image of the colonizers, with all its alienating consequences, even in the urban-influenced production of other forms of art - the mural, sculpture, music, etc.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': 'Furthermore, though colonialism did introduce some social services as has been pointed out already, it must be emphasized that not only were these services grossly inadequate and unevenly distributed in each colony, but they were all by and large meant primarily for the benefit of the few white settlers and administrators, hence their concentration in the towns. Rodney has shown that in Nigeria in the 1930s whereas there were twelve modern hospitals for 4000 Europeans in the country, there were only fifty-two for Africans numbering over 40 million.$^{34}$ In Tanganyika by 1920, the ratio of beds to population was approximately 1:10 for the European Hospital and 1:400-500 for the African Hospital in Dar es Salaam. 35 In the field of education, what was provided during the colonial days was grossly inadequate, unevenly distributed and badly orientated and therefore not as beneficial as it could have been for Africa. Five different types of educational institutions were established under colonial rule: primary, secondary, teacher-training, technical and university. But while many primary schools had been established by i860 in British West Africa, it was not until 1876 that the first secondary schools, Mfantsipim and the Methodist High School, were established in the Gold Coast and Nigeria respectively, both by the Wesleyan Missionary Society, while the British colonial administration did not establish its first secondary school (Achimota College) in the Gold Coast until 1927. In the Italian colony of Libya, as it has been pointed out already, there were only three secondary schools for the Libyans by 1940, two in Tripoli and one in Benghazi. It was not until after the Second World War that technical schools and univer› sity colleges were established in most parts of Africa. And significantly, only one university college each was established in the Gold Coast in 1947, in Nigeria in 1948, in Uganda in 1950, in Senegal and Madagascar in 1950, in Salisbury in 1953, in Congo Leopoldville in 1954 and Elizabethville in 1956. In other words, university and technical education was not intro› duced into Africa until towards the end of the colonial era.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': "Moreover, nowhere and at no level did the facilities provided meet the demand nor were they evenly distributed. As even Lloyd admits, as late as the mid-i930S, 'government expenditure everywhere remained low, amounting in the mid-i930S to only 4% of total revenue in Nigeria and the French territories, and 7% in Ghana'.$^{36}$ Nor were these schools and institutions properly distributed in each colony. Most of the post-primary institutions were found in the main urban centres and in some countries most of the secondary schools were found in one town. In the Gold Coast for example about 80% of the secondary schools were found in Cape Coast. In Uganda, by 1920, there were 328 elementary schools in Buganda and only 34, 24 and practically none in the Western, Eastern and Northern provinces respectively.$^{37}$ Facilities for education were so inadequate and so unevenly distributed, because the colonial powers did not aim at pro› moting education for its own sake or for the sake of the Africans, but rather, to quote one African scholar, 'to produce Africans who would be more productive for the [colonial] system'. 38 Besides its grossly inadequate nature numerically and its uneven dis› tribution, the curricula provided by all these institutions were determined by the colonial rulers and were closely modelled on, if not carbon copies of, those of the metropolitan countries and therefore irrelevant to the needs of the continent. No less an authority than the Governor of the Gold Coast from 1919 to 1927, Sir Gordon Guggisberg, testified in 1920: 'One of the greatest mistakes of the education in the past has been this, that it has taught the African to become a European instead of remaining African. This is entirely wrong and the Government recognizes it. In future, our education will aim at making an African remain an African and taking interest in his own country.' 39 But though Guggisberg did establish Achimota College to make good this promise, not much was achieved since education in the country con› tinued to be controlled by the Christian missions whose primary aim was to produce people who could read the Bible in English or in the vernacular as well as teachers and priests.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.052, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': "'Native policy'", 'content': "Although there was initially no universally accepted approach to colonial administration in Africa, most lines of thought converged on what might be called conjunctive administration (usually termed indirect rule); that which joined African authorities, in traditionally-held or European-imposed political roles, to the colonial government, but in an obviously subordinate capacity. The reasons for general concurrence on this broad principle of rule are varied. First, the historical pattern of late nineteenth-century colonial acquisition was a formative factor, as size alone added a new dimension to the problem of colonial rule. Secondly the internal penetration of Africa rapidly outpaced the numbers of European personnel available to administer the newly possessed lands. Furthermore, since such penetration extended into many regions yet untouched by European cultural contact, direct rule of any kind would have been an entirely new experience and therefore immediately unworkable. Primarily as a result of these conditions, previously noted by several critics,$^{4}$ the direct rule characteristic of the smaller possessions on the coast gave way to the indirect rule of the larger possessions in the interior. Furthermore, at the turn of the century, the collapse of rule by chartered companies necessitated the establishment of national control over weakly held extensive territories. Yet this condition was in turn met (except in German East Africa) with a type of informal rule similar to the loose methods employed previously by the companies, as was most evident in Italian Somaliland.
There were also reasons which sprang from European cultural percep› tions and announced political intentions. Not only was there widespread acceptance of the principle of empire 'on the cheap', with little or no direct cost to the metropolitan state, but there was also general agreement that the least social dislocation would assure the most indigenous co-operation. In Uganda and Southern Nigeria local rulers and elders joined with either the colonial administration or the missions to establish schools. [{'id': 607, 'article_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'The merchants in the Gambia have a season of recreation and a season of work. As soon as the rains commence, very few, if any at all, remain in town. Making their escape from the unhealthy season, most of them are to be found in England and France, and some even in America. The working season commences in November. The merchants, with their families, arriving, make the place gay. A great many vessels are now in port, loading and unloading, and many arrivals and departures. At this time there are a great many festivals, and everyone enjoys himself in right good earnest.

The houses in the Gambia are very substantially built, principally of bricks and stone, containing large and open rooms, and spacious verandahs. The Mandingo huts are the most miserable erections to be seen in any part of the Coast. Low, dark, and of a round shape, with doorways about three feet or less in height, and two in breadth, they are made as if intended that these sons of the Prophet should make their salaam before they even enter their lots. Goats, sheep, and fowls are fellow-inmates in some of these miserable constructions.

Besides the European population, the most influential inhabitants are the free Jollofs, a race of people, whose principal habitation is at Goree and Senegal, and their interiors, and who own most of the principal buildings at Bathurst. Next to these in influence are a few Sierra Leone people; and then comes the Mohammedan population, consisting of Suninkees, Marabouts, and Cereres, the first of whom are the masters of the land.

A promenade has lately been erected by Governor D'Arcy with Teneriffe stone, entirely at his own expense, for the good of the colony. It is called "D'Arcy's Promenade." The idea is very excellent, but the position is most unhappily selected. It is placed in front of the market, where the stench is sufficient to drive away a mere passer-by. The consequence is, that no one

has ever been seen to walk in it. It should be placed abreast the sea, in a spot where ladies could enjoy their evening promenade. I hope this short notice will influence the Governor to remove it from its present unpleasant position to a more convenient spot, or the nuisance which renders it useless.'}, {'id': 3301, 'article_title': 'Death of the Acting Administrator at the Gambia, and Alleged Incompetency of the Colonial Engineer', 'full_section_title': 'Death of the Acting Administrator at the Gambia, and Alleged Incompetency of the Colonial Engineer', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_03_1877', 'content': 'Captain H. There is serious complaint, also, as to his work on the drains—a very important matter in Bathurst; and even in the affair of the burial of the late Administrator, he is accused of having had a coffin made so small that the body had to be forced into it, and a brick grave so constructed that it gave way when the body was to be lowered, so that a new one had to be made, and it was nearly noon before the interment could be completed. We do not know anything of Mr. J. C. Bauer, the Engineer in question, and shall be very sorry indeed if we have been misled by the above account; but we have a distinct recollection that great evils were said to have been caused some years ago, and much mortality occasioned, by the Colonial Engineer of that period having mismanaged the drainage of Bathurst; and with this in our mind, it has appeared to be strictly our duty to bring the alleged inefficiency of the actual Engineer at the Gambia to the knowledge of those whom it officially concerns, in order that due inquiry may be made. The public health in Bathurst is so intimately connected with efficient drainage, that it was impossible for us to avoid publicly noticing the communication made to us.'}, {'id': 3812, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'last_edit_date': '07-09-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1879', 'content': 'The man convicted of the murder of his child last January, and who has been since lying in gaol under sentence of death, was executed a few days ago. His counsel had tried to bring the case in as one of somnambulistic mania, but the jury could not see it; and, as a comment on the line of defence, the prisoner, while the jury were consulting, made the remark in his native language, "Why that man" (the learned counsel for the defence) "talk so much I killed the child." It is believed that jealousy of the mother of the child caused the murder, but this did not come out in evidence. The Government placed the man since under medical supervision; but being reported as quite sane, the law had to take its course, as an example was necessary to check these murders among natives, which are far too frequent, and seldom come to the knowledge of the authorities, through want of native detectives in the police force.

From Scarcies River we learn that the Sierra Leone Government having put duties on all goods imported into that river—though it is a native river, and one over which the Home Government disclaimed all control or possession some years ago—they stopped a steamer of C. A. Verninck, merchant, of Marseilles, and made her pay 150£ duty on her cargo; and all the French factories there will have to pay heavy duties. C. A. Verninck declares this illegal, and claims 50,000£ compensation. It is too bad the way Great Britain ignores jurisdiction and its sequence, when she has it by treaty, and at other times seeks to manufacture it brand new when it suits her officials.

The Colonial Engineer putting in practice his theory of water by deep-boring pumps versus shallow wells, though warned that experiments years ago proved that the deeper you go after ten feet or so, at Bathurst, the worse the water gets, has just put down a pump in the yard of the Court. He has got very good salt water, but quite useless for internal use. Thus our surplus is muddled away, and useful works, sanitary or otherwise, ignored.

The rains have been very heavy and continuous this season.'}, {'id': 4244, 'article_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'full_section_title': 'THE MEANS BY WHICH BRITISH TRADE IS DOOMED TO PERISH IN THE "GAMBIA."', 'last_edit_date': '05-15-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1881#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_07_1881', 'content': 'Earl Carnarvon refused protection in the Upper River. Well, here is a nice case: Last month the son of the King of Nyan came down with a few followers to Changally, a port in that country, and ordered the traders, all servants of merchants at Bathurst, to lay down while he rode his horse over them. They refused. He fined them $40 each. They refused to pay. He and his men attacked one of the traders with their cutlasses and nearly cut his arm off; the rest took their guns and prepared to fight. The Prince, a mere boy, then went off to another town to get more men. The traders sent off to Bassi—a port near by—to the representative of one of the merchants. He at once armed all the people there, and sent them overland to Changally, while he went by water. They arrived in time. When the Prince and his scamps returned they surrounded them, told them they were prisoners, that no harm would be done to them, but they would have to remain under guard until the King was communicated with. A messenger was sent by the agent to report to the King. The King sent down and asked forgiveness for his son, and sent men to bring him and his companions up in custody to the head town to punish them. The King was warned to keep...

his son quiet in future. Now, but for this prompt action, this young fool would have attacked these traders, beaten them, most likely killed some of them, and surely plundered them of all their goods. Then were the matter reported to the Government "nothing could be done," as "we go into the Upper River at our own risk."

In my last letter I told you Bathurst was assuming "a new face," and familiar objects were disappearing, &c. I forgot to say that the wreck of Creek Bridge has been dragged on shore, and stored; but there is one familiar feature still to the fore. The £100 screw pump in the yard of the Court House, which was driven down wrong end first, and, as was foretold by experienced inhabitants here, would prove a failure, as the deeper it went the worse the water would get, as once you pass, say, ten feet with a well bore, you touch the old bed of the river on which the island rests, and that is very salt. There the pump remains rusting in the rain—a monument of inefficiency, and known to the public as "Charlie's Folly."—Your obedient servant,'}, {'id': 5243, 'article_title': 'The German Expedition to West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The German Expedition to West Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-11', 'issue_date': '02_11_1885', 'content': '"The natives grow sugar-cane and tobacco, the latter so strong that our men had to steep it three times in warm water before they could smoke it, and then a few whiffs were enough! Their chief food consists of yams and kassava, and a kind of cheese made out of 'peanuts' crushed in a mortar with some sugar-cane. This is by no means unpleasant to eat, and was, at any rate, an agreeable change. At this point of the river there are cataracts, but further up it becomes again navigable, even for the biggest war canoes. The temperature averages from 30 to 32 degs. Réaumur, but it sometimes goes as high as 40 deg. At the same time, the nights are very cold. Even before the camp fire we were half chilled, and all the members of the expedition suffered severely in consequence. The Belgian Society has stations all along the river, but they are mere huts, in which no shelter could be had and no provisions. There were no officers in charge of these stations. In fact, the country is in a deplorable state. Getting back to the coast, we sailed north again to Bramia and Dubreeka, where the German flag was hoisted in January last. The French Government claim this station, and refuse to recognise the Protectorate; but Germany will maintain it, and flourishing German factories have been established.

"We had intended to proceed from here to the interior, to carry out investigations similar to those described above; but our experiences on the way to and from Ludema had been too trying, and it would have been impossible to do the work properly in view of the condition of the men. So we sailed again for Europe, and in a few days will make our report to the Foreign Office in Berlin.'}]
