[{'document_title': 'Expenditure on Police and Education at Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'gross injustice to believe it. But if it be so, we can only say that the Governor and his patrons have set up as imitators and followers of the worst of all examples. To tempt first, and afterwards to punish, is said to be the practice of the Arch-enemy of mankind. And here we have first, a demoralising and debasing system pursued year after year by the Sierra Leone Executive, under approval, of course; and then in due time comes forth the edict declaring the citizens to be incapable of discharging properly the duties of jurors. We utterly deny that they are so. To state it thus is to add insult to injury. But if it were so, who is to blame but the Executive, which mentally starves a whole people? We know of no greater cruelty or injustice than thus to impeach men with moral defects and delinquencies which could clearly be traced, if they did really exist, to the evil direction of the accuser. Surely if the object of all criminal law, and the machinery which it employs, be not merely to punish but to deter, Governor Blackall would find in the powerful instrumentality of education a more efficacious and Christian mode of attaining this desired end than that of the costly and immoral action of an exaggerated police force. The prophetic power of Pitt, the philanthropy of Wilberforce, the untiring energy and exertions of a Buxton and a Brougham, have expended themselves upon the social and moral advancement of Africa; and could some of them look from out their honoured graves, they would wonder that after eighty long years the lamp of knowledge should be so scantily supplied in their favoured regions, and brute force alone be in the ascendant. We grant that the latter, the rule of brute force, is the best a Government can adopt if it has determined that a people shall be kept in a low and debased state, or if, having once raised them to the dignity of citizens, it purposes to rob them by piecemeal of all that gives dignity to citizen life, and favours social advancement. Under the drowsy influence of universal ignorance, you may treat men as slaves, and in the fulness of time rob them of the sacred shield of the jury-box; but a wise and honest, above all a Christian Executive would shrink with horror from attempting to debase where it might elevate, or to take away where it is within its power justly to bestow. It is awful to think what must have been the state and condition at this time of Sierra Leone, if the noble Church and the Wesleyan Missionary Societies had not stepped in to the rescue of the people from ignorance and debasement. By and through their noble exertions there is an adequate number of citizens fit in every way for the duties and responsibilities of the jury-box, notwithstanding the disgraceful Government laches in the matter of education. But, as we have before urged, the time has come when this ought to cease. There are ample revenues now at Sierra Leone to enable the Executive to supply education to the people. Since the citizens have no power over the disposal of those revenues, they have but one course to pursue. Let them petition the Colonial-office, petition the British Parliament if necessary, either that some effective voice in the disposal of their money be given to them, or that the police should be reduced, education promoted, the jury-box preserved, the sanitary condition of the colony improved—in a word, that the proceeds of their duties and taxes should be spent for their social and commercial advancement as becomes a free people, and not in the exorbitant employment of brutalising influences, on worthless favourites, and unproductive follies. The people are to be prepared as rapidly as possible for self-government, and the proper means for attaining this end must therefore be employed.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1867#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Local Government of Sierra Leone and the Subsidized Schools', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'That the Local Government believe more in police and gaols, as you have observed, than in the purifying and ameliorating influences of religious education, is self-evident; for whereas several thousands of pounds are annually voted to the former and expended, the few hundred pounds voted to the latter are doled out so niggardly and irregularly, that it seems almost a matter of regret an ordinance was ever passed in its favour. It is much to be feared that one or other of the native gentlemen in Council share in this belief also; for the petition to which you have kindly called the attention of the Colonial Office was to have been entrusted to one of them but he declined having anything to do with it! What is this but a proof that the old leaven has insidiously...', 'last_edit_date': '1876-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1876#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.72, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'DEFICIENCY OF REVENUE AT SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It will be seen in our parliamentary report that a question was asked in the House of Commons relative to a rumoured deficiency in the revenues of Sierra Leone; and the reply of Mr. Lowther, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, shows that the matter is under the serious consideration of Her Majesty's Government. Under these circumstances, it was our intention to give our view of the situation, and of the course that we think should be adopted. We have been prevented at the last moment from doing so, and must necessarily postpone our observations until our next issue. One or two things we feel bound, however, to say. Certainly, it would not be any part of our proposed remedy to withhold the school grant from the underpaid and impoverished schoolmasters in the settlement; or to abolish the annual grant of 500l. to the native pastorate, as was done at the last sitting of the Legislative Council of which we have received notice; or to empty the hospital of its inmates, which seems also to have been somehow effected, most probably with a view to retrenchment. The old leaven is evidently very strong in the lump of Sierra Leone officialism. It will be a difficult task to eradicate it; and it never will be eradicated in any other way than by a very clear and decided enunciation of a firm and enlightened policy of progress on the part of the superior authority in London. The general aspect of affairs in Sierra Leone is by no means satisfactory; and it most certainly will never be improved by measures such as we have above alluded to, which can scarcely fail to lead to an increase of moral darkness, where, alas! such darkness has but too much prevailed. No acquisition of new territory at the Sherbro' could counterbalance such an evil.", 'last_edit_date': '1876-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1876#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The old leaven seems to be strong in Sierra Leone. The Local Government believe more in police and gaols than in the purifying and ameliorating influences of religious education. We say “religious education,” because all education for a long time to come must embrace the religious element, since all the teachers capable of imparting instruction have been educated by one or other of our great Missionary Societies. And well for Africa that it must do so; for education merely secular—education without any attempt to impart with it the restraining influences of Christianity—would curse at least as much as it would bless. Among older communities, the control of public opinion, the existence of a higher moral standard, the general outward profession of religion, may—we do not say they will, but they may—prevent mere secular instruction in schools, to the exclusion of the religious element, from producing those pernicious results which would otherwise most certainly accrue. But in West Africa, among people but lately redeemed from barbarism, and surrounded by a heathen population debased by the most loathsome superstitions and most revolting practices, the results of mere secular education could not be other than deplorable. The old leaven, we have said, still works strongly among the members of the Local Government. The account given on our second page affords sufficient evidence of this. We are glad to have been furnished by it with this opportunity of bringing so important a matter under the notice of Her Majesty’s Secretary of State for the Colonies, whom we know to be especially desirous of extending the ameliorating influences of education among the people of West Africa. We must confess that the contents of the letter to which we have above alluded surprised as much as they have pained us. We had carefully watched the action of the Home Government in the mission of Mr. Laurie and his successor, whose loss seems to be so very justly deplored; and as another Inspector of Schools had been appointed, and there was an annual vote for his services and for the payment of grants-in-aid, it was not possible for us to suppose that a matter in which the Home Government had manifested so deep an interest could be so cruelly neglected. It was beyond our mental reach to imagine a regularly-salaried Inspector of Schools, and no inspection. That such an anomaly should have been permitted is disgraceful to the Local Government, and, we feel convinced, will bring down upon them that rebuke from the Earl of Carnarvon which their conduct deserves. The defrauded schoolmasters, for such indeed they are, have our warmest sympathy; and we thank them for having enabled us to bring the history of their wrongs, and the wrongs of their pupils (for these must necessarily suffer if the schoolmasters are not properly paid) under the notice of the authority which has power to redress their grievances.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.727, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bishop of Sierra Leone on the Education of the West African', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In his book, "Sierra Leone after a Hundred Years" (Seeley & Co.), Bishop Ingham, in reviewing the work which has been accomplished in and around Sierra Leone, observes:—

"It is impossible not to regret that the Church Missionary Society were unable to develop in the schools of the Colony some accurate knowledge of manual trades. The results in aptitude for interior missionary work, in energy, perseverance, and common sense, would have been enormous. ... The other plan (abstract teaching, divorced from material business) has been abundantly tried, and what is the result? Not only does the constant hammering at the brain, of which this raw (negro) youth must now become a victim, produce an unbalanced development, but the precocious memory that will characterise him is a deceptive gauge of progress made, and, like much precociousness elsewhere, the results are disappointing in after life. For this reason, a successfully-passed examination on paper is not the test in Africa that it is in England. ... Can we be surprised that the very last thing he (the negro young man) thinks of is the development of his country or making his father's village better than he found it—and thus his want of accuracy, want of perseverance and skill, and all that goes to make a man master of any situation, remain uncorrected, and put him altogether out of the running. We are convinced that there is a more excellent way, and we regret it has not more generally approved itself to those who have done such good work in other respects in this part of Africa. Other bodies, and notably the Roman Catholics, seem to be far ahead of us in this respect. How far they fail in developing the minds and consciences of the Africans we will not here discuss; but their systems of technical training are thoroughly worthy of imitation."

The Bishop goes on to explain that the work that has been accomplished is by no means to be deprecated—indeed, it is

difficult to imagine how low Sierra Leone must have fallen, mentally and morally, were it not for the mission work carried on in face of such grave difficulties, and upon a soil necessarily so unpromising, since the first occupation of the Colony 107 years ago. But he goes on to illustrate from the physical condition of Sierra Leone; from the manners, customs, and ideas of the Negroes, both lay and clerical; from the suspicion with which the independent States surrounding the Colony regard the morals of its population, the difficulties which face one with such heavy responsibilities as are his.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.721, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Local Government of Sierra Leone and the Subsidized Schools', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—We, being managers of schools in the colony of Sierra Leone, and representing the general body of school managers, desire to address your Excellency on the subject of the continued withholding of the grants-in-aid allowed by the Government, and to make mention of one or two other matters immediately connected therewith.

Your Excellency will have in remembrance that a few of us had the honour of waiting upon you, a year ago, to solicit that the full amount of grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874, might be paid; the managers having only received that portion of it which was due on account of the average attendance of scholars, and nothing whatever on account of subjects.

That meeting resulted in a letter from the Bishop to Earl Carnarvon, which was followed up by a despatch from the Colonial Office, referring it for the report of the Lieutenant-Governor; since which nothing has been heard by us of the subject, either from the Colonial Office or from the local Government. Neither have the managers received any grants-in-aid, nor any portion of any grant which has since become due; so that at the present time there are as many as five half-years of grants, in whole or in part, unsettled for and unpaid.

There are the greater portions of the grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874; and there are the entire grants for the three half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1875, and April 30, 1876.

The particulars in regard to the grants for the half-years ending April 30 and October 31, 1874, are so plainly stated in the letter of July 24, 1875, from the Bishop to Lord Carnarvon, that we cannot do better than refer your Excellency to that letter, a copy of which accompanied Lord Carnarvon's despatch.

For the half-year next following November 1, 1874—April 30, 1875—the schools were only inspected and reported on by the Director of Public Instruction; and a few weeks ago we received notes, informing us that the grant for this half-year would be paid; but though it has been applied for through the usual medium, it has not yet been paid.

For the half-year, May 1—October 31, a few of the schools were inspected at the usual time, and the inspection has since been completed, but the grant has not been paid.

We need not speak further of the grant for the half-year recently closed, as it is at present all in good time to look for its payment.

We desire to express to your Excellency how much we are inconvenienced by this withholding of the grants, and how almost impossible we find it to carry on our schools whilst this support from the Government is withheld. The schoolmasters, to whom one-third of the grants is due, are also feeling exceedingly, being deprived of that portion of their salaries.", 'last_edit_date': '1876-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1876#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Self-Government at Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Will you do me the favour to allow me to make a few remarks upon what I consider the most important part of Mr. Rosenbush's admirable letter printed in your August number—namely, that of self-government in Sierra Leone. Now, what do the people of Sierra Leone mean by self-government? I believe I express the mind of my countrymen when I say that by self-government we simply desire some of those invaluable rights enjoyed by almost every community of British subjects—that is to say, to have the honour of saying nay or yes to those laws or rules of action by which our whole conduct as a people is guided, and most especially to have the privilege of managing, to some extent at least, our pecuniary affairs. In fact, Sir, the power of self-government for which we crave is but a shade better than what is termed in this country "local," or "parochial." It is very far from our minds to diminish the power of the Council. Let them exercise their present authority to the fullest extent, and check any incursion we may dare to make into the laws through having power put into our hands. Nevertheless, Sir, we would pray and supplicate that Her Majesty's Government be pleased to grant and confer upon us an almost uncontrolled management of our "local" affairs. Without questioning for one moment the kind feelings of the honourable gentlemen of the Council of Sierra Leone, I contend that, from the very nature of their appointments, being liable to be removed from one place to another, it is impossible for them to take the same interest in the colony as the native inhabitants. It naturally becomes a matter of very little importance to them whether any material improvement takes place in the colony or not; having to leave it in a comparatively short time. The painful consequence of this is, that we see many important schemes which might be for the well-being of the inhabitants of Sierra Leone are left undone. Mr. Editor, need I remind you of the intelligence which is brought to us by almost every mail, of the havoc the various kinds of fever are making amongst the different classes of the inhabitants of the colony? Is it, Sir, I ask, that these gentlemen are not aware of the principal cause of all this mischief? Do they not know that all this evil arises from the total absence of drainage and general sanitary improvements in the colony? It is not possible to conceive this. In fact, I should consider it an insult to every individual concerned to charge them with ignorance with respect to this matter. And yet, Sir, we see these most material improvements untouched. And why so? The answer is what I have intimated: It is not natural to man to labour for the sole benefit and enjoyment of others. And who will deny that if some of the native gentlemen, who know that the probable lengthening or shortening of their days hangs upon the existence or non-existence of these improvements, had the power of carrying them out, they would use their utmost efforts to do so? I am sure, Sir, your readers will not understand me to be overlooking the overruling power of God. These remarks hold good for many other drawbacks in the colony. Dear Sir, "No one knows where the shoe pinches, but he who wears it." We know our wants and requirements (by we, I of course mean those of us who have had the privilege of knowing better), and I presume to say, that none are better judges as to the best mode of meeting these desiderata than ourselves. In suggesting measures of any kind we should have two objects in view, which the white man cannot have but in his own country—besides our own immediate selves, we should consider how far any plans of ours would affect our posterity.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Petition of Native Pastors and Schoolmasters at Sierra Leone for Payment of the Grants-in-Aid due to them from the Government for the Years 1874 and 1875.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Government scheme of grants-in-aid was inaugurated, therefore, at a time when its benefits were most likely to be felt; for the schools being left almost entirely with the people, they are, as a rule, unable to employ that large staff of men which, as has been observed, was employed by the Church Missionary Society. But what has been the result of the scheme towards which the Legislative Council has made an annual vote of 900l.? The Government, following the Revised Code, which establishes the principle of paying for results, makes an allowance of 6d. each—writing, reading, and arithmetic; whereby the schools became entitled, as the results of two examinations held by Mr. Popplestone the first year, to a sum a little above 400l. And here it may be observed, _en passant_, that in that gentleman the settlement has lost one in every way qualified for his work, and whose memory will long be cherished by all who have had anything to do with him. He regarded his charge as one of great responsibility, and was not ashamed to avow that "the fear of God and belief in a risen Saviour must form the basis of instruction; that knowledge is only good in so far as people are by it made more useful to their fellow-creatures and holier and better before the Almighty." The colony has been most unfortunate in the loss of Europeans who have really had the interest of Africa at heart. On his almost sudden and untimely death, there being no Inspector of Schools, it became with some persons problematical whether the grant that had become due would be given or not; and an application was made to the then Administrator-in-Chief, a gentleman of great legal acumen, who decided that, inasmuch as the fault did not rest with the managers, "the grant" could not in justice be withheld, and it was accordingly given. The wisdom and justice of such a decision appears from the facts (a) that the amount had been voted; (b) that an Inspector, not in love with his work, might find a thousand excuses for not going round to examine the schools; the Government, feeling itself bound to pay by an ordinance of its own framing, would be compelled, _however unwilling_ to do so, to put a pressure on an Inspector, who perhaps, whilst disposed to enjoy the emoluments of his office, might shrink from the onus of a tour round the settlement, though entitled to a travelling expense of something between 30l. and 50l. for a trip.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Immorality in Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—Allow me only a small space in your valuable columns on the subject of the immorality in Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone contains people of all tribes who come there to settle, or to reap the benefits of the land, and then disperse—viz., Englishmen, Frenchmen, &c., the Akus, Eboes, Houssas, Paupans, and Kroos; besides numerous others. Each of these tribes brought with them either civilization, superstition, bigotry, bigamy, adultery, drunkenness, or such like. Now, Mr. Editor, you know that whatsoever seed is sown, the harvest will surely be of the same.

The civilized community of Sierra Leone acted for themselves, and kept their civilization within bounds. The superstitions tolerated by the public generally, they have gone without bounds; hence we find them in our capital streets beating drums, singing wanton songs, and disturbing the public. As for adultery and drunkenness, the fathers and mothers tolerated them; and this being a wise age, the children of civilized or superstitious drunkards or adulterers plunged deeper and deeper in their parent vices, thereby dooming the colony to intolerable evils.

I call the attention of the Government, pastors, parents, day and Sabbath school teachers, to this. Sierra Leone, as it now stands, seems to be an ungrateful and wretched country. Her old men have gone back to Baal, her young men have served other gods. What will she be ten years to come, I wonder? I shudder while I think of it.

Some of our pastors have seen, and are trying to amend, this state of things. Hence we had that elaborate sermon preached at Buxton Chapel by the Rev. the Superintendent of the Wesleyan Mission, who points out the extent of immorality that many parents have tolerated and patronised. May the Lord strengthen him to point out still the many evils that are choking this land!

When I see and weigh the many evils that exist in this country, my heart sinks within me. Our prison-houses are filled with criminals, costing the colony thousands of pounds annually. Look at the Sabbath-breaking; three-fourths of the population are Sabbath-breakers. Drunkards are found by hundreds in the streets annually; women, too, forgetful of their sex, have been found in the most disgraceful state of intoxication. Numbers of families are plunged into distress annually by strong drink; honest men are made rogues; girls are robbed of their chastity and virtue; and many go down to a drunkard's grave and a drunkard's perdition.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-06-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_07_1873#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.734, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FOURAH BAY COLLEGE, SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Will you kindly allow me a small space in your valuable paper to explain my views, and satisfy my friends both here and in England with reference to the letter of "Sierra Leonist," which appeared in your last issue, this month. The writer, whoever he is, has, unconsciously perhaps, put myself and the native clergy in a false position. The letters appeared at a time, Sir, when a misunderstanding existed between the European missionaries and the native pastors, and it would convey an erroneous impression in the minds of people far and near that the native clergy wish to get rid of the European missionaries. I am therefore obliged to state, plainly and unequivocally—especially as my name is mentioned in the communication—that I do not at all participate in the views propounded by "Sierra Leonist" in the letter. Those who know me well will bear me out when I say that I always advocated and, when in England in 1862, urged upon the committee of the Church Missionary Society the necessity of sending out to the colony two or even three university men, of high character and attainments, to take charge of our educational establishments. Such men will, we are sure, secure the confidence and respect of the native clergy. The native Church and the colony are not so far advanced in education and intelligence as to be independent of foreign aid. The supposition then, for it is nothing more, that the native clergy desire to be disconnected from their European brethren must be utterly abandoned, and cannot be maintained without injury to the native clergy. We have not been able to get a clue to the discovery of the writer. I am told it is a trick played upon the native clergy by someone, to put them in the worst light possible during the unhappy affair. With regard to the misunderstanding to which "Sierra Leonist" alludes, I am happy to say that the Bishop has written, and there has been an amicable adjustment.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1868-08-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have received a copy of the report on the census of Sierra Leone and its dependencies. The duty of superintending the taking of the census in this Colony falls, it would appear, upon the Colonial Secretary, who seems to have done the work with much care and thoroughness. The total population is put down at 60,546, and of these only 134 are classed as "Whites." I was not disappointed in my anticipation of an entertaining and instructive visit; but I must confess that I was surprised to find that Sierra Leone possesses the claim it does to natural beauty. I had heard and read so much of its unhealthiness that I had pictured to myself a low-lying swampy coast, fringed with mangrove bushes, and with the other accompaniments of a malarial climate. This imaginary sketch bore not the slightest resemblance to the truth. In the place of a flat, low-lying district I found a mountainous tract of country, formed by two rivers which nearly intersect it. The general appearance of this Sierra is picturesque in the extreme. The sky line is broken by the irregular outline of a number of conical peaks, covered to their summits with lofty forests, which give to the distant scenery a rich and romantic appearance. Freetown is situated on the shore of a beautiful bay, hemmed in by a grand amphitheatre of hills, covered with vegetation. The distance between the town and the base of the mountains varies from three-quarters of a mile to a mile and a half, the intervening space being broken by numerous grass-clad undulations.

Hills ascend almost in regular gradation until they reach the highest peak, and as they are well wooded, the *coup d'œil* is striking and beautiful. A fairer situation for a town can scarcely be imagined, and if the sad experience of the past did not teach us the contrary, it would be pronounced healthy. There is no room to doubt, however, that Sierra Leone is extremely unhealthy, and epidemics of fever occur from time to time which sweep off large numbers of the population. This fever is peculiarly deadly to Europeans, and at the time when there was a European garrison the mortality was immense, whole families being occasionally carried off during one visitation. Happily, few Europeans are now sent to this deadly climate, and the number is yearly decreasing. At the census of 1881 there were only 160 resident whites in the whole of Sierra Leone.
